title: State v. Sweat
description: In this criminal appeal, the court reviews whether the trial judge erred by allowing the State to introduce evidence that appellant was arrested for criminal domestic violence against his wife in October 2001, when appellant was being tried for breaking into the home where his wife was living and assaulting her and others on December 11, 2001.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Johnny Phillip Sweat, Appellant.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3898
Heard November 9, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Senior Assistant Deputy Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent. 
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Johnny Phillip Sweat (Sweat) appeals his convictions 
  of first-degree burglary, assault and battery with intent to kill, and three 
  counts of assault of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Sweat contends the trial 
  judge erred in admitting evidence of a prior bad act of domestic abuse.Â  We 
  affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Robin Sweat (Robin) 
  and Sweat lived together for approximately nine years and had two children together.Â  
  Although they had participated in a marriage ceremony, Robin discovered that 
  Sweat was still married to a previous wife, and, therefore, Robin and Sweat 
  were not legally married.Â  She reported Sweat for criminal domestic violence 
  in October of 2001 (the October incident).Â  While he was in jail for that offense, 
  she moved in with her brother, Chris Hasty, and became romantically involved 
  with Bobby Blake (Blake).Â  The incident giving rise to the convictions at issue 
  on appeal took place on December 11, 2001â€”eleven days after Sweat was released 
  from jail for the October incident.Â  
Sweat invaded a 
  home occupied by Robin; Robinâ€™s brother, Chris Hasty; Robinâ€™s boyfriend, Blake; 
  Hastyâ€™s roommate, John Greene; a friend, Deon Dent; and two children: Robinâ€™s 
  oldest son, Robert; and Deonâ€™s nephew.Â  Sweat, brandishing a knife, forced his 
  way through the front door.Â  Robin and Blake were in a bedroom and the others 
  were in the living room.Â  Sweat began yelling and continued waving the knife.Â  
  Robin and Blake emerged from the bedroom to investigate the commotion.Â  Sweat 
  became more upset when he saw Robin and Blake.Â  Robin, Blake, Hasty, and Greene 
  retreated to a back bedroom, and Blake held the door shut as Sweat attempted 
  to enter.Â  Sweat eventually opened the door enough to insert his armâ€”with knife 
  in handâ€”into the room.Â  He continued to swipe with the knife and severely cut 
  Blake on the hand.Â  
Unable to breach 
  the bedroom from the inside, Sweat exited the house and attempted to enter the 
  bedroom through an outside window.Â  He broke the window, but was unable to fully 
  enter the room because the headboard of a waterbed was blocking the window.Â  
  He returned inside the house, again trying to breach the back bedroom.Â  Unsuccessful, 
  Sweat finally left.Â  He was apprehended the next day.Â  
At trial, the State 
  introduced Robinâ€™s testimonyâ€”first in camera, and then in the 
  presence of the juryâ€”of the incident of domestic violence that took place in 
  October of 2001.Â  Robin, Sweat, and Sweatâ€™s brother and sister-in-law were together 
  when Sweat directed Robin to take off her shirt and show his brother her breasts.Â  
  When Robin refused, Sweat began yelling and calling her a â€œfat bitch.â€Â  He attempted 
  to physically pull off her shirt, and in the ensuing struggle, Robinâ€™s arm was 
  bruised.Â  
A few days later, 
  Robin reported the October incident to the authorities.Â  She explained at trial 
  that she desired to end the relationship and saw the incident as her opportunity 
  to escape.Â  Sweat was arrested for criminal domestic violence.Â  He spent forty-five 
  days in jail, but was released after Robin signed a statement that the October 
  event did not actually happen.Â  At trial, Robin averred that she copied the 
  statement at the request of her sister-in-law and acquiesced in signing it because 
  â€œI was out of the situation.Â  And thatâ€™s all I was worried about, was getting 
  out.â€ 
Additionally, Robin 
  gave a general account of the authoritarian and imperious personality of Sweat, 
  which consisted of: (1) dictating when and what she could eat; (2) hanging up 
  or breaking the telephone if she stayed on too long; (3) compelling her to drink 
  alcoholic beverages; and (4) forcing her to have sex.Â  
Defense counsel 
  moved to exclude evidence of prior episodes of domestic violence on the grounds 
  that it was impermissible character evidence.Â  The State argued that the prior 
  evidence was admissible to show motive and intent.Â  Sweat objected that: (1) 
  the evidence was irrelevant; (2) it could not be shown by clear and convincing 
  evidence; and (3) its prejudicial effect substantially outweighed its probative 
  value.Â  After an in camera review, the trial judge ruled evidence 
  of the October incident was admissible to show motive and intent and to provide 
  a full picture of the events leading up to the night of the attack.Â  However, 
  the trial judge disallowed other instances of domestic violence because she 
  found them irrelevant and unfairly prejudicial.
On appeal, Sweat 
  argues admission of the October incident was error.Â  We disagree and affirm.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Rule 404(b), SCRE/Lyle

Generally, South Carolina law precludes evidence of a defendantâ€™s 
  prior crimes or other bad acts to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt for the crime 
  charged.Â  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); State 
  v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Mathis, 
  359 S.C. 450, 597 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Weaverling, 337 
  S.C. 460, 523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 
  406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), our supreme court articulated the exceptions to this 
  general rule excluding bad character evidence.Â  Evidence of prior bad acts is 
  admissible when it tends to establish (1) motive; (2) intent; (3) absence of 
  mistake; (4) a common scheme or plan embracing the commission of two or more 
  crimes so related to each other that proof of one tends to establish the other; 
  and (5) the identity of the person charged with commission of the present crime.Â  
  Lyle at 416, 118 S.E. at 807; State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 393 
  S.E.2d 364 (1990); State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. 
  App. 2004); see also Anderson v. State, 354 S.C. 431, 581 
  S.E.2d 834 (2003) (explaining that Rule 404(b), SCRE, the modern expression 
  of the Lyle rule, excludes evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts 
  offered to prove character of person in order to show action in conformity therewith; 
  the rule creates an exception when testimony is offered to show motive, identity, 
  existence of common scheme or plan, absence of mistake or accident, or intent).Â  

â€œIn State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001), the 
  Supreme Court articulated the appropriate standard of review on appeal in determining 
  the admissibility of bad act evidence:Â  â€˜In criminal cases, the appellate court 
  sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. CutterÂ¸ 261 S.C. 140, 199 
  S.E.2d 61 (1973).â€™â€Â  State v. Humphries, 346 S.C. 435, 448, 551 S.E.2d 
  286, 293 (Ct. App. 2001) (Anderson, concurring) revâ€™d on other grounds, 
  354 S.C. 87, 579 S.E.2d 613 (2003);Â  see also State v. Tutton, 
  354 S.C. 319, 327, 580 S.E.2d 186, 190 (Ct. App. 2003) (determining whether 
  trial judge properly admitted evidence under common scheme or plan exception 
  to Lyle is a â€œquestion of law.â€).

 A.Â  Motive and Intent

At the conclusion of Robinâ€™s in camera testimony, the 
  trial judge ruled the October incident was admissible under both the motive 
  and intent exceptions of Rule 404(b) and Lyle.Â  In reaching her decision 
  to admit evidence of the October incident, the trial judge stated:

But I do perceive that it is logically relevant and that . . . the State is 
  entitled to give a full snapshot of what happened. I do not think you can isolate outâ€”this is the incident that started the continuum 
  and does show his intent in going there that evening and his motive in going 
  there that evening. Which is . . . according to the Stateâ€™s theory . . . . that she was his property 
  and that he was going there to get his property. . . .

We agree that both 
  motive and intent can be inferred from the prior bad act.Â  Following the October 
  assault, Robin reported Sweatâ€™s conduct and Sweat spend forty-five days in jail.Â  
  He was released eleven days before the December incident occurred.Â  Robin became 
  involved with Blake and refused to resume her relationship with Sweat.Â  Within 
  days, Sweat perpetrated the December 11 attack.Â  Thus, the October incident 
  and Sweatâ€™s time in jail relate to his actions on December 11, 2001.Â  
The State had to prove malice as an element of assault and battery 
  with intent to kill (ABIK).Â  See State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 
  584 S.E.2d 138 (2003) (â€œABIK is an unlawful act of violent nature to the person 
  of another with malice aforethought, either express or implied.â€).Â  â€œGenerally, 
  motive is not an element of a crime that the prosecution must prove to establish 
  the crime charged, but frequently motive is circumstantial evidence . . . of 
  the intent to commit the crime when intent or state of mind is in issue.â€Â  Danny 
  R. Collins, South Carolina Evidence 319 (2d ed. 2000).Â  â€œState of mind 
  is an issue any time malice or willfulness is an element of the crime.â€Â  Id.Â  
  Therefore, the October incident was properly admitted.Â  
In State 
  v. Thomas, 248 S.C. 573, 151 S.E.2d 855 (1966) overruled on other grounds 
  by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (abrogating 
  the doctrine of in favorem vitae), the defendant was convicted of rape.Â  Our 
  supreme court found evidence the defendant had previously stolen the victimâ€™s 
  watch was properly admissible under the motive exception to Lyle.Â  The 
  victim had testified against the defendant for stealing the watch.Â  The defendant 
  allegedly said to the victim on the night of the rape, â€œâ€˜Itâ€™s me and I have 
  come to kill you.Â  I have planned it every single day since you put me on the 
  chaingang for stealing your watch.â€™â€Â  Thomas, 248 S.C. at 576, 151 S.E.2d 
  at 857.Â  In affirming the admission of the prior bad act, the court concluded:Â  


We think that all of the evidence here, which only incidentally tended to prove 
  the commission of other crimes, by appellant is governed by exceptions to the 
  general rule, and that such was, therefore, admissible. . . .Â  The evidence 
  with respect to the prior crime, the theft of [the victimâ€™s] watch, was restricted 
  to the minimum requirements of the case and tended directly and fairly to prove 
  not only the identity of the appellant, but his motive as well.

Id. at 583, 151 S.E.2d 861.
 State v. Plyler, 275 S.C. 291, 270 S.E.2d 126 (1980) dealt, 
  in part, with the motive exception to Lyle in the context of murder.Â  
  The defendant claimed the trial court erred by allowing evidence of prior ill 
  will between he and the defendant.Â  The supreme court disagreed:Â  

The prosecution elicited testimony concerning a verbal altercation between the 
  victim and the appellant three days prior to the killing. In a non-responsive 
  answer, the witness additionally indicated that there had been prior bad blood 
  between the two.Â  Upon objection and motion from defense counsel for a mistrial, 
  the trial judge ordered the remark concerning bad blood stricken from the record 
  and instructed the jury to disregard the comment.Â  The motion for a mistrial 
  was denied.Â  The appellant now asserts these rulings were trial error and entitled 
  him to relief.Â  We do not agree.Â  
  
Evidence of previous difficulties or ill feelings between the accused and 
  the victim and of facts showing the cause of such difficulties or ill will is 
  admissible on the question of motives where there is some connection of cause 
  and effect between the evidence and the crime.Â  40 C.J.S., Homicide, Section 
  228.Â  
  
The challenged evidence tends to show motive on the part of the accused and 
  is not so remote in time as to negate its probative value.

Id. at 296, 270 S.E.2d at 128 (emphasis added).Â  
Thomas and 
  Plyler lend further support to the trial judgeâ€™s decision in this case.Â  
  From the October incident, the jury could have inferred both (1) motiveâ€”that 
  Sweat was driven by anger over Robin causing him to go to jail and terminating 
  their relationship, and that he intended to â€œget his propertyâ€; and (2) intentâ€”that 
  Sweat maliciously sought to inflict harm upon Robin and Blake.Â  Therefore, we 
  find the trial judge did not commit error by allowing the October incident under 
  the motive and intent exceptions of Lyle and Rule 404(b), SCRE.

B.Â  Relevance

Sweat contends that even if the October incident fits under the motive 
  and intent exceptions, it should have been excluded because it was irrelevant.Â  
  We disagree.
For evidence to be admissible, it must be relevant.Â  Rules 401 & 
  402, SCRE; State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 340, 526 S.E.2d 248, 251 (Ct. 
  App. 2000); see also State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 
  S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating bad act must logically relate to the crime 
  with which the defendant has been charged).Â  Evidence which assists the jury 
  in arriving at the truth of an issue is relevant and admissible unless otherwise 
  incompetent.Â  State v. Schmidt, 288 S.C. 301, 303, 342 S.E.2d 401, 403 
  (1986).Â  
â€œâ€˜Relevant evidenceâ€™ means evidence having any tendency to make the existence 
  of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable 
  or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  Evidence 
  is relevant if it tends to establish or make more or less probable some matter 
  in issue upon which it directly or indirectly bears, and it is not required 
  that the inference sought should necessarily follow from the fact proved.Â  State 
  v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 354, 543 S.E.2d 586, 591 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Evidence is admissible if â€œlogically relevantâ€ to establish a material fact 
  or element of the crime; it need not be â€œnecessaryâ€ to the Stateâ€™s case in order 
  to be admitted.Â  State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 393 S.E.2d 364 (1990).Â  
  â€œThe record must support a logical relevance between the prior bad act and the 
  crime for which the defendant is accused.â€Â  State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 
  512, 514 S.E.2d 578, 582 (1999).Â  If the court does not clearly perceive the 
  connection between the extraneous criminal transaction and the crime charged, 
  that is, its logical relevancy, the accused should be given the benefit of the 
  doubt, and the evidence should be rejected.Â  State v. Brooks, 341 S.C. 
  57, 533 S.E.2d 325 (2000).Â  
Determination of relevancy is largely within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  
  State v. Jeffcoat, 279 S.C. 167, 170, 303 S.E.2d 855, 857 (1983); Hamilton 
  at 353, 543 S.E.2d at 591.Â  The trial judge must have wide discretion on innumerable 
  questions of relevancy before her, and her decision should be reversed only 
  for abuse of that discretion.Â  State v. Anderson, 253 S.C. 168, 182, 
  169 S.E.2d 706, 712 (1969). 
The October incident 
  was relevant as it suggested motive and intent and tended to make the Stateâ€™s 
  version of the case more probable.Â  While not strictly necessary to the Stateâ€™s 
  case, it was logically related to why Sweat went to the house that night and 
  to his intentions once there.Â  We find the trial judge did not abuse her discretion 
  by concluding the October incident was relevant to the event that took place 
  on December 11, 2001.Â  

C.Â  Standard of Proof for Prior Bad Acts

If not the subject of a conviction, a prior bad act must first be 
  established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 
  129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Smith, 300 S.C. 216, 387 S.E.2d 
  245 (1989); State v. Mathis, 359 S.C. 450, 597 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
  In State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001), the South Carolina 
  Supreme Court elucidated:Â  

[W]e do not review a trial judge's ruling on the admissibility of other bad 
  acts by determining de novo whether the evidence rises to the 
  level of clear and convincing. If there is any evidence to support the 
  admission of the bad act evidence, the trial judge's ruling will not be disturbed 
  on appeal.

Id. at 6, 545 S.E.2d 829 (emphasis added); accord Pagan, 
  357 S.C. at 143, 591 S.E.2d at 652; State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 155, 
  561 S.E.2d 640, 646 (Ct. App. 2002).
The record contains ample evidence to satisfy the â€œany evidenceâ€ 
  standard articulated in Wilson.Â  The trial judge conducted an extensive 
  in camera review and was satisfied the standard was met.Â  Robin 
  testified the incident occurred.Â  Sweat was arrested for criminal domestic violence 
  and served jail time because of the incident.Â  Additionally, Blake declared 
  at trial that he saw the bruises on Robinâ€™s arm.Â  Thus, evidence exists to support 
  the trial judgeâ€™s finding that the October incident took place.Â  See 
  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 629 (2000) (finding prior bad 
  act established by clear and convincing evidence where witness testified defendant 
  robbed her); cf. State v. Pierce, 326 S.C. 176, 485 S.E.2d 913 
  (1997) (finding trial judge erred in admitting testimony that child abuse victim 
  had previously been treated for injuries where State failed to offer any 
  proof the injuries were inflicted by defendant).Â  We find no error. 

D.Â  Probative Value/Unfair Prejudice

Even though the relevant evidence is clear and convincing and falls 
  within a Lyle exception, it must be excluded if its probative value is 
  substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  
  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 (2001); 
  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Unfair 
  prejudice means â€œan undue tendency to suggest [a] decision on an improper basis, 
  commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one.â€Â  State v. Alexander, 
  303 S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 149 (1991); see also State 
  v. Bright, 323 S.C. 221, 226, 473 S.E.2d 851, 854 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œUnfair 
  prejudice from the introduction of evidence occurs when it has an undue tendency 
  to induce a decision on an improper basis.â€).Â  â€œThe determination of prejudice 
  must be based on the entire record and the result will generally turn on the 
  facts of each case.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 7, 545 S.E.2d 827, 
  830 (2001).Â  
A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value 
  and prejudicial effect of relevant evidence should be reversed only in exceptional 
  circumstances.Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (2003); 
  see also State v. Myers, 359 S.C. 40, 596 S.E.2d 488 (2004) 
  (noting the supreme court reviews rulings balancing whether the probative value 
  of evidence was substantially outweighed by its prejudicial effect pursuant 
  to the abuse of discretion standard and gives great deference to the trial judgeâ€™s 
  decision).Â  â€œIf judicial self-restraint is ever desirable, it is when a Rule 
  403 analysis of a trial court is reviewed by an appellate tribunal.â€Â  State 
  v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 358, 543 S.E.2d 586, 598 (Ct. App. 2001).
As to the October incident, the trial judge ruled:Â  â€œ. . . I do not 
  find that its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair 
  prejudice to the defendant.â€Â  We agree.Â  Testimony of the October incident was 
  highly probative.Â  It tended to show motive and intent, and it completed the 
  Stateâ€™s theory of the case.Â  Sweat testified that: (1) Robin called him multiple 
  times a day; (2) he had filed a complaint against her; (3) she invited him to 
  the house on December 11, 2001 to sign papers giving him temporary custody of 
  their children; (4) Greene tried to slam the door in his face; (5) Blake initiated 
  an attack on him and swung a stick at him; (6) Greene threatened him with a 
  knife, which he took away and swung to fend off Greene and Blake; and (7) he 
  never went inside the house.Â  Consequently, the facts surrounding the December 
  11, 2001 occurrence were vigorously contested.Â  Evidence of the October event 
  was therefore probative in that it gave the jury the necessary background to 
  explain why Sweat may have gone to the house that night and what his intentions 
  may have been.Â  While the prior act of domestic violence had some prejudicial 
  effect on Sweat, we do not believe it was so prejudicial to â€œsuggest a decision 
  on an improper basis, such as an emotional one.â€Â  See State v. Cheesboro, 
  346 S.C. 526, 547, 552 S.E.2d 300, 311 (2001). 
Sweat, citing State v. DuBose, 288 S.C. 226, 341 S.E.2d 785 (1986), 
  argues even if the evidence was otherwise admissible, it lost its probative 
  value by becoming too far removed from the event in question.Â  In Dubose, 
  the defendant was convicted of manufacturing and trafficking marijuana.Â  He 
  was arrested in 1984 after a pilot for SLED observed patches of marijuana growing 
  on the defendantâ€™s fatherâ€™s farm.Â  The State was allowed to admit aerial photographs 
  taken of the DuBose farmland during 1981-1983.Â  The supreme court, finding admission 
  of these photographs was error, held:Â  â€œHere there is a total failure of proof 
  that DuBose grew marijuana in the fields shown in the aerial photographs from 
  1981 to 1983.â€Â  Id. at 230, 341 S.E.2d at 787.Â  
We disagree with Sweat that the October incident was too remote in time from 
  the December crime to have probative value.Â  To the contrary, the incident occurred 
  two months before the December attack, and Sweat was released from jail for 
  the October incident a mere eleven days before the December attack.Â  DuBose, 
  by contrast, dealt with evidence dating back several years.Â  Furthermore, unlike 
  DuBose, the short passage of time in this case does not call into question 
  the efficacy of the evidence admitted.Â  Whereas the DuBose court found 
  â€œa total failure of proofâ€ that DuBose was responsible for the marijuana in 
  the photographs, the trial judge in this case found clear and convincing evidence 
  that the October incident took place.Â Â  
Sweat cites State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 514 S.E.2d 578 (1999) to support 
  his contention the October incident was too remote to have probative value.Â  
  In King, the defendant was found guilty of murdering his father-in-law 
  who reportedly kept up to $1,800 in his wallet.Â  His wallet was not found at 
  the crime scene.Â  The State introduced evidence that the defendant: (1) often 
  needed money; (2) regularly pawned household items; (3) stole cash from his 
  wifeâ€™s purse; (4) forged checks on her bank account; and (5) used her ATM card 
  without permission.Â  Id. at 511, 514 S.E.2d at 582.Â  The supreme court 
  reversed his conviction based on the admission of this evidence of prior bad 
  acts:

The remote thefts were not admissible under any theory.Â  This evidence shows 
  appellantâ€™s bad character and his propensity to commit crimes.Â  These are inadmissible 
  purposes.Â  The temporal connection between these petty thefts and the charged 
  crimes is too attenuated for admissibility under the res gestae 
  theory or under Lyle.Â  Thus the trial judge erred in admitting evidence 
  of the remote thefts.Â  

Id. at 513, 514 S.E.2d at 583.Â  We find King distinguishable 
  from the case at bar.Â  First, the prior bad act in this case is more probative 
  than the thefts in King; it bears a closer temporal and logical connection 
  to the crime charged.Â  In King, the State was allowed to admit evidence 
  of a series of unrelated thefts that began over a year before the murder.Â  In 
  this case, the trial judge disallowed evidence of a string of instances of prior 
  domestic violence.Â  She allowed only the October incident precisely because 
  it was so close in time and so factually related to the attack.Â  See 
  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 135, 536 S.E.2d 679, 682 (2000) (â€œThe temporal 
  attenuation between the making of this statement is of no consequence in assessing 
  its admissibility.Â  The four month lapse is at most a matter bearing on the 
  weight of the evidence, which was for the jury to determine.â€).
Further, the only logical connection between the prior thefts and the murder 
  in King was the inference that defendant often needed money, often stole 
  to get it, and therefore might have murdered his father-in-law to obtain money.Â  
  In other words, its introduction primarily tended to show his propensity to 
  do wrong.Â  Here, the October incident suggests why Sweat perpetrated 
  the crimes on December 11â€”there is a cause and effect relationship between the 
  two events.Â  Thus, while in King the murder did not occur because 
  of the prior thefts, the evidence here tends to show the December attack 
  did occur because of the October incident and its consequences to Sweat.Â  
  Concomitantly, Sweatâ€™s intervening jail time is a critical temporal nexus between 
  the October and December incidents.Â  Therefore, the October incident is appreciably 
  more probative than the prior thefts in King.Â  
Second, the October incident is less damaging than the thefts in King.Â  
  The King court stressed that â€œ[h]ere, all the evidence was circumstantial. 
  . . . the evidence was not overwhelming.Â  The admission of the remote thefts 
  was too prejudicial to be held harmless.â€Â  Id. at 514, 514 S.E.2d at 
  583.Â  By contrast, overwhelming evidence placed Sweat at the house on the night 
  of December 11, 2001.Â  And by Sweatâ€™s own admission, he inflicted the knife 
  injury upon Blake.Â  
Third, our courts have not established a bright-line rule for determining when 
  evidence loses its probative value due to passage of time.Â  Indubitably, we 
  have established no such rule due to the fact-intensive nature inherent in a 
  Rule 403 analysis.Â  The determination of prejudice depends upon the unique circumstances 
  of each case.Â  See Wilson, 345 S.C. at 80, 545 S.E.2d at 7.Â  Accordingly, 
  the trial judge is given broad discretion in making the Rule 403 determination.Â  
  See Myers, 359 S.C. at 48, 596 S.E.2d at 492.Â  Under the facts 
  of this case, we agree that the short passage of time did not diminish the probative 
  value of the October incident.Â  Thus, we find the trial judge did not abuse 
  her broad discretion in concluding the probative value of this evidence outweighed 
  its prejudicial effect.

II.Â  Res Gestae

Â â€œUnder the res gestae theory, evidence of other bad acts may 
  be an integral part of the crime with which the defendant is charged or may 
  be needed to aid the fact finder in understanding the context in which the crime 
  occurred.â€Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004) 
  (citing State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 745 (2001); State 
  v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 514 S.E.2d 578 (1999)); see also State 
  v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding evidence 
  of prior burglary was â€œnecessary and relevant for a full presentation of the 
  case.â€); State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (finding evidence of burglary occurring the same night as the burglary for which 
  defendant was convicted â€œwas necessary for a full presentation of the case without 
  fragmentation.â€).Â  Under this theory, it is important that the temporal proximity 
  of the prior bad act be closely related to the charged crime.Â  Owens, 
  346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 745.Â  
Our supreme court, in State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996), 
  explained the theory of res gestae:Â  

One of the accepted bases for the admissibility of evidence of other crimes 
  arises when such evidence "furnishes part of the context of the crime" 
  or is necessary to a "full presentation" of the case, or is so intimately 
  connected with and explanatory of the crime charged against the defendant and 
  is so much a part of the setting of the case and its "environment" 
  that its proof is appropriate in order "to complete the story of the crime 
  on trial by proving its immediate context or the 'res gestae'" or the "uncharged 
  offense is 'so linked together in point of time and circumstances with the crime 
  charged that one cannot be fully shown without proving the other . . .' [and 
  is thus] part of the res gestae of the crime charged." And where evidence 
  is admissible to provide this "full presentation" of the offense, 
  "[t]here is no reason to fragmentize the event under inquiry" by suppressing 
  parts of the "res gestae." 

Id. at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 370-71 (quoting United States v. Masters, 
  622 F.2d 83, 86 (4th Cir. 1980) (alterations in original)).
We find the October incident was properly admitted to â€œcomplete the story of 
  the crime on trial.â€Â  The prior act of domestic abuse gave Robin the opportunity 
  to escape her relationship with Sweat.Â  As a result, she moved out, and he spent 
  time in jail.Â  Sweat was upset, and eleven days after his release, these crimes 
  occurred.Â  The October abuse, and the events that followed, provided the fact 
  finder with an appropriate context in which to place the December 11 attack.Â  
  See State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 512, 514 S.E.2d 578, 582 (1999) 
  (â€œThe res gestae theory recognizes that evidence of other bad 
  acts may be an integral part of the crime with which the defendant is charged, 
  or may be needed to aid the fact finder in understanding the context in which 
  the crime occurred.â€). 
CONCLUSION
We hold evidence of the October incident was properly admitted to 
  show motive and intent.Â  The evidence tended to make Sweatâ€™s motive and intent 
  more probable, and, therefore, was relevant.Â  The record adequately supports 
  the trial judgeâ€™s finding the incident was proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  
  Furthermore, the incident was highly probative and not so prejudicial to Sweat 
  to suggest a verdict based on an improper basis.Â  Finally, the incident was 
  correctly admitted, pursuant to res gestae, to complete the story 
  of the crime on trial.Â  Accordingly, the convictions and sentences of Sweat 
  are 
 AFFIRMED.Â  
 STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Truluck v. Snyder
description: These combined appeals concern the right to a jury trial in a will contest and the right to have the matter removed from the probate court to the circuit court.
text:
Truluck v. Snyder


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James P. Truluck, Jr., Ethel N. King, Bobbie 
        Jean Truluck, Hazel Ann Simril Childers, Mark Davis Simril, Bryan Scott
Simril, Michael Andrew Simril, J.S. Bourne as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Elizabeth Ashford, and J.S. Bourne Individually, Petitioners,
of whom James P. Truluck, Jr., Ethel N. King, 
        Bobbie Jean Truluck, Hazel Ann Simril Childers, Mark Davis Simril, Bryan 
        Scott Simril and Michael Andrew Simril are Respondents,
and J.S. Bourne as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Elizabeth Ashford, and J.S. Bourne, Individually is Appellant,
v.
Carol S. Snyder as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Mason D. Nesmith, and Carol S. Snyder Individually, Respondent.
James P. Truluck, Jr., Ethel N. King, Bobbie 
        Jean Truluck, Hazel Ann Simril Childers, Mark Davis Simril, Bryan Scott
Simril, Michael Andrew Simril, J.S. Bourne as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Elizabeth Ashford, and J.S. Bourne Individually, Petitioners,
of whom James P. Truluck, Jr., Ethel N. King, 
        Bobbie Jean Truluck, Hazel Ann Simril Childers, Mark Davis Simril, Bryan 
        Scott Simril and Michael Andrew Simril are Respondents,
and J.S. Bourne as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Elizabeth Ashford, and J.S. Bourne, Individually is Appellant,
v.
Carol S. Snyder as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Mason D. Nesmith, and Carol S. Snyder Individually, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3899
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Ronald Stewart Gaynor, of Pawleys Island and William S. 
  Duncan, of Georgetown, for Appellant.
Marian Dawn Nettles, of Lake City and Otis A. Jeffcoat, 
  III, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: 
These combined 
  appeals involve a demand for a jury trial in a will contest.Â  The probate court 
  denied the demand as well as a motion to remove the case to the circuit court.Â  
  The circuit court affirmed.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Mason D. Nesmith died on April 26, 1999.Â  On April 28, 1999, the probate 
  court granted an application from Carol S. Snyder for informal probate of a 
  will that was executed by Nesmith on April 1, 1999.Â  In this will, Nesmith devised 
  all his property to Snyder and Elizabeth Ashford.Â  He also named Snyder as the 
  personal representative of his estate.Â  
On June 9, 1999, James P. Truluck, Jr., commenced a proceeding in the probate 
  court to contest the will on the ground of undue influence and lack of testamentary 
  capacity.Â  On June 15, 1999, an amended summons was filed naming Truluck, Ethel 
  N. King, Bobbie Jean Truluck, Hazel Ann Simril Childers, Mark Davis Simril, 
  Bryan Scott Simril, and Michael Andrew Simril as petitioners and Snyder and 
  Ashford as respondents.Â  
Although she participated in some discovery requests, Ashford did not file 
  any responsive pleadings in the will contest.Â  Ashford died testate on July 
  29, 2000.Â  Her will named J.S. Bourne as the personal representative of her 
  estate as well as her primary beneficiary.Â  
On November 8, 2000, Bourne, individually and as personal representative of 
  Elizabeth Ashfordâ€™s estate, was substituted as a respondent in the contest concerning 
  Nesmithâ€™s will. [1] Â  Bourne answered 
  the petition on December 5, 2000.Â  
On April 12, 2001, Bourne was dismissed by oral order of the probate court 
  as a respondent pursuant to Rule 41, SCRCP, and granted leave to intervene as 
  a petitioner.Â  Although Bourne had submitted a petition under Rule 24(c), SCRCP, 
  alleging numerous causes of action, the probate court permitted him to intervene 
  as a petitioner only on his causes of action for lack of testamentary capacity, 
  undue influence, and termination of appointment. 
  [2] Â  
On April 20, 2001, Bourne filed a summons and petition alleging the three causes 
  of action permitted by the probate court in its oral order.Â  Unlike either the 
  petition Bourne had proffered when he moved to intervene as a petitioner or 
  the petition approved by the probate court, the petition that Bourne filed on 
  behalf of himself and Ashfordâ€™s estate included a demand for a jury trial.Â  
  In her answer, dated May 29, 2001, Snyder objected to the jury trial demand 
  and timely moved to strike the pertinent language in the petition. 
On June 18, 2001, the probate court held a hearing on Snyderâ€™s motion to strike.Â  
  On June 22, 2001, after the hearing on Snyderâ€™s motion to strike and while the 
  matter was still under advisement, Snyder amended her answer to raise for the 
  first time two affirmative defenses, i.e., (1) the statute of limitations under 
  South Carolina Code section 62-3-108, 
  [3]  and (2) lack of standing as to Bourne.Â  On June 27, 2001, Bourne moved 
  under South Carolina Code section 62-1-302 
  [4]  for removal of the proceedings to the circuit court.Â  
The probate court filed a written order on July 12, 2001, granting Snyderâ€™s 
  motion.Â  In the order, the probate court found that all parties had waived the 
  right to a jury trial and that no additional issues of fact or law were created 
  by Bourneâ€™s petition.Â  
On July 19, 2001, Snyder moved for summary judgment on the ground of the statute 
  of limitations.Â  
On November 1, 2001, the probate court issued orders denying (1) Bourneâ€™s motion 
  for reconsideration on the issue of his right to a jury trial, (2) Bourneâ€™s 
  motion to remove the case to the circuit court, and (3) Snyderâ€™s summary judgment 
  motion. Â On October 2, 2002, the circuit court affirmed the probate courtâ€™s 
  decisions regarding Bourneâ€™s rights to a jury trial and removal of the case.Â  
  Bourneâ€™s motion for reconsideration was denied May 12, 2003.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We address first Snyderâ€™s contention that the order issued by the probate 
  court denying removal to the circuit court was not appealable.Â  Snyder contends 
  the order was not a â€œfinal order, sentence, or decree of a probate courtâ€ under 
  South Carolina Code section 62-1-308(a) [5]  and therefore could not be appealed to the circuit court.Â  
  We disagree.Â  Inasmuch as the probate courtâ€™s denial of Bourneâ€™s motion to have 
  the case considered by a jury in the circuit court impacted the mode of trial, 
  it constituted a final order for the purpose of filing an appeal. [6] 
2.Â  The probate court 
  found that all parties, including Bourne, had waived the right to have the case 
  removed to the circuit court.Â  Bourne argues this was error.Â  We agree.
The South Carolina Probate Code provides that â€œactions in which a party has 
  a right to trial by jury and which involve an amount in controversy of at least 
  five thousand dollars in value,â€ â€œmust be removed to the circuit courtâ€ 
  for a trial de novo â€œon motion of a party, or by the court on its own motion, 
  made not later than ten days following the date on which all responsive pleadings 
  must be filed.â€ [7] 
We agree with Bourne that his request for removal was timely.Â  Section 62-1-302 
  requires only that a motion for removal be made â€œnot later than ten days following 
  the date on which all responsive pleadings must be filed.â€ 
  [8] Â  In the present case, on June 22, 2001, the court had accepted without 
  incident Snyderâ€™s amended answer to Bourneâ€™s petition.Â  Because Bourneâ€™s motion 
  for removal was dated June 27, 2001, it fell within the time limit imposed by 
  the South Carolina Probate Code. [9] 
3.Â  We further agree with Bourne that the probate court erred in holding 
  (1) because the pleading that he filed included a jury trial demand, it violated 
  both Rule 24(c), SCRCP, and the oral order granting him leave to intervene; 
  and (2) Bourne was not entitled to a jury trial because he had waived this right.
Pleadings are governed by Part III of the South Carolina Rules of Civil 
  Procedure, which includes Rules 7 through 16.Â  None of these rules include any 
  requirements concerning jury trials or otherwise suggest that a jury trial demand 
  is part of a pleading.Â  The procedure for demanding a jury trial appears in 
  Rule 38, SCRCP, which is included in Part VI, entitled â€œTrials.â€Â  Under Rule 
  38, the only circumstance constituting a waiver of this right is a partyâ€™s failure 
  â€œto serve a demand as required by this rule and to file it as required by Rule 
  5(d).â€ [10] Â  
Rule 38(b) allows such a demand to be â€œendorsed upon a pleading of the party.â€ 
  [11] Â  The rule also allows a jury trial demand to be included in a separate 
  document served up to ten days after the last pleading pertinent to the issue 
  on which a jury trial is warranted. 
  [12] Â  
We agree with Bourne that an â€œendorsement,â€ such as that allowed by Rule 
  38, is not a part of the pleading itself; therefore, including a jury trial 
  demand in his petition did not violate Rule 24(c) or exceed what the probate 
  court allowed when it granted him leave to intervene.Â  Had Bourne demanded a 
  jury trial in a separate document, he would not have â€œalteredâ€ the pleading 
  authorized by the probate court.Â  There is no logical distinction between this 
  method and the use of an endorsement on the face of the pleading to communicate 
  a demand for a jury trial.Â  
The probate court further concluded that all parties had waived their rights 
  to a jury trial in this matter.Â  Specifically, as to Bourne, the probate court 
  noted that Ashford never filed any responsive pleadings or demanded a trial 
  by jury at any time before she died and that the responsive pleading initially 
  filed by Bourne on behalf of himself and Ashfordâ€™s estate failed to include 
  such a demand.Â  We disagree with this reasoning.
The Probate Code further provides that â€œ[t]he right to trial by jury exists 
  in, but is not limited to, formal proceedings in favor of the probate of a will 
  or contesting the probate of a will.â€ 
  [13] Â  Rule 38 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure likewise recognizes 
  the fundamental importance of the right to a jury trial in a civil action. [14] Â  Paragraph (b) of the rule further instructs 
  any party demanding a jury trial on a particular issue to make this demand known 
  â€œby serving upon the other parties a demand therefor in writing at any time 
  after the commencement of the action and not later than 10 days after the service 
  of the last pleading directed to such issueâ€ and provides that a jury trial 
  demand â€œmay be endorsed upon a pleading of the party.â€ 
  [15]   
In this case, Bourne was dismissed from the litigation pursuant to Rule 
  41(a)(1) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  This rule expressly 
  provides that â€œ[u]nless otherwise stated in the notice of dismissal or stipulation, 
  the dismissal is without prejudice . . . .â€ [16] Â  Interpretations of the federal counterpart 
  to this rule, which is essentially the same as the South Carolina version, 
  [17]  have suggested that a dismissal under circumstances such as those 
  presented here has the effect of nullifying the prior pleadings of the party 
  requesting the dismissal. [18] Â  Based on this reasoning, we hold that Bourneâ€™s earlier participation 
  as a defendant in this litigation did not compromise his right to demand a jury 
  trial when he intervened as a petitioner in the case.Â  Because the jury trial 
  demand was contemporaneous with Bourneâ€™s petition to challenge the probate of 
  Nesmithâ€™s will on the grounds of undue influence and lack of testamentary capacity, 
  it was timely under Rule 38. [19] 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Bourne and the estate of Elizabeth Ashford will be referred to collectively 
    as â€œBourne.â€

 
   
     
    [2] Â  See Rule 24(c), SCRCP (requiring that the motion to intervene 
    â€œshall be accompanied by a pleading setting forth the claim or defense for 
    which intervention is soughtâ€).Â  The pleading Bourne submitted under this 
    rule alleged, in addition to assertions of undue influence and lack of testamentary 
    capacity, causes of action for mistake as to the nature of the document, mistake 
    in the document, and fraudulent or reckless inducement. 

 
   
    [3] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-108(3) (1987 and Supp. 2003) (â€œ[A] 
    proceeding to contest an informally probated will and to secure appointment 
    of the person with legal priority for appointment in the event the contest 
    is successful may be commenced within the later of eight months from the informal 
    probate or one year from the decedentâ€™s death.).

 
   
    [4] Â  See id. Â§ 62-1-302(c) (stating circumstances under 
    which probate court matters are removed to the circuit court).

 
   
    [5] Â  See id. Â§ 62-1-308(a) (â€œA person interested in a final 
    order, sentence, or decree of a probate court and considering himself injured 
    by it may appeal to the circuit court in the same county.â€).

 
   
    [6] Â  See Foggie v. CSX Transp., 313 S.C. 98, 103, 431 S.E.2d 
    587, 590 (1993) (â€œIssues regarding mode of trial must be raised in the trial 
    court at the first opportunity, and the order of the trial judge is immediately 
    appealable.â€); Satcher v. Satcher, 351 S.C. 477, 490, 570 S.E.2d 535, 
    542 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œOrders affecting the mode of trial affect substantial 
    rights protected by statute and must, therefore, be immediately appealed.â€).

 
   
    [7] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(c)(5) (1987 and Supp. 2003) (emphasis 
    added).

 
   [8] Â  Id. Â§ 62-1-302(c).

 
   
    [9] Â  See Hiers v. Mullens, 310 S.C. 63, 66, 425 S.E.2d 
    57, 59 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding a removal motion made more than ten days after 
    the date of the original answer became timely upon the granting of the defendantâ€™s 
    motion to amend her answer).Â  

 
   
    [10]  Rule 38(d), SCRCP.

 
   
    [11]  Id. Rule 38(b).

 
   
    [12]  Id.

 
   
    [13]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-306(a) (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [14]  See Rule 38(a), SCRCP (â€œThe right of trial by jury . . . 
    as given by a statute of South Carolina shall be preserved to the parties 
    inviolate.â€).

 
   
    [15]  Id. Rule 38(b).

 
   
    [16]  Id. Rule 41(a)(1). 

 
   
    [17]  See id. Rule 41 historical notes (â€œThis Rule 41 is 
    the same as the Federal Rule, except that it requires service as well as filing 
    the notice of voluntary dismissal by plaintiff if taken before answer or motion 
    to dismiss is served.â€).

 
   
    [18]  See Sandstrom v. ChemLawn Corp., 904 F.2d 83, 86 (1st 
    Cir. 1990) (holding that a corporate defendant was not bound by a representation 
    in a prior dismissed action between the same parties that it would concede 
    personal jurisdiction and stating that â€œ[a]bsent explicit conditions to the 
    contrary . . . a voluntary dismissal under Fed.R.Civ.P. 41(a) wipes the slate 
    clean, making any future lawsuit based on the same claim an entirely new lawsuit 
    unrelated to the earlier (dismissed) actionâ€); James F. Flanagan, South 
    Carolina Civil Procedure 348 (2d ed. 1996) (â€œVoluntary dismissals under 
    Rule 41(a) are not on the merits, unless otherwise stated in the order.â€); 
    Wright & Miller, Federal Practice & Procedure 2d Â§ 2367, at 
    321 (1995) (â€œA voluntary dismissal without prejudice leaves the situation 
    as if the action had never been filed.â€) (emphasis added); 35B C.J.S. 
    Federal Civil Procedure Â§ 775, at 41 (1960) (stating that a dismissal 
    under Rule 41(a)(1), FRCP, unless otherwise stated in the notice of dismissal 
    or stipulation, is without prejudice unless the party requesting dismissal 
    has previously dismissed an action based on the same claim).Â  

 
   
    [19]  Although Snyder unsuccessfully moved for summary judgment on the 
    ground that Bourneâ€™s petition was untimely, the denial of her motion does 
    not prevent her from raising this defense on remand.Â  See Ballenger 
    v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 477, 443 S.E.2d 379, 380 (1994) (â€œThe denial of 
    summary judgment does not establish the law of the case, and the issues raised 
    in the motion may be raised again later in the proceedings by a motion to 
    reconsider the summary judgment motion or by a motion for a directed verdict.â€).

title: State v. Wood
description: In this criminal appeal, the court analyzes whether the circuit judge erred in allowing evidence of an â€œincidentâ€ involving appellant in Greenville County that occurred one to two hours prior to the acts for which he was charged in Anderson County.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John Richard Wood, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3900
Heard November 9, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate 
  Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Special Assistant Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Druanne D. White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this criminal case, John Richard Wood argues the trial 
  court erred by admitting evidence Wood shot and killed a state trooper shortly 
  before committing the crimes involved in this appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Wood was indicted for criminal conspiracy, failure to stop when signaled by 
  a law enforcement vehicle, resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, armed robbery, 
  two counts of possession of a firearm or knife during commission of or attempt 
  to commit a violent crime, four counts of assault with intent to kill, and three 
  counts of assault and battery with intent to kill.
Immediately prior to the beginning of trial and outside the presence of the 
  jury, the State moved for permission to introduce evidence at trial that Wood 
  fatally shot a state trooper.Â  The shooting occurred one to two hours before 
  Wood committed the acts for which he was charged in the instant case.Â  The evidence 
  consisted of the testimony of Terry and Debra Wheeler and a 911 telephone call.Â  
  The Wheelers witnessed a traffic stop, heard shots, and then saw a red moped 
  weaving in and out of traffic.Â  They followed the moped and saw Wood abandon 
  the moped and get into a Jeep.Â  The Wheelers followed the Jeep long enough to 
  view the license plate number and made a 911 call with information about Wood 
  and the Jeep.Â  Based in part on the Wheelersâ€™ information, police officers attempted 
  to apprehend Wood.Â  Wood failed to stop when signaled by a law enforcement vehicle.Â  
  A high-speed chase ensued during which Wood shot at police officers.
Wood objected to the admission of the evidence on the ground it was irrelevant 
  under Rule 401, SCRE, and, even if relevant, unduly prejudicial under Rule 403, 
  SCRE.Â  The State argued the evidence was admissible as part of the res gestae 
  and to show motive, existence of common scheme or plan, identity, absence of 
  mistake or accident, and intent under Rule 404(b), SCRE and State v. Lyle, 
  125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).
The trial judge found: â€œItâ€™s my judgment that the evidence from Greenville 
  which the State seeks to admit is probably admissible as part of the res gestae 
  and also under 404(b) as to the issue of intent.â€Â  The judge further ruled:

However, based on the arguments that have been presented, Iâ€™m going to approach 
  this matter cautiously and limit the Stateâ€™s use of the so-called Greenville 
  evidence, at least initially.Â  The State certainly should not be foreclosed 
  from explaining to the jury some limited basis of what precipitated the stop 
  or attempted stop in Anderson County.
At this time I will permit the Stateâ€™s witnesses to testify to observing, perhaps 
  hearing an incident in Greenville involving an individual on a motorcycle 
  or moped, however it is described, and that as a result an individual in the 
  vehicle was followed, eventually to the rear of the Greenville Gymnastics Center, 
  where the individual was picked up by a female in a jeep.Â  Testimony would then 
  permit the actual following of the jeep and reporting the tag number of the 
  jeep to 911.
Anderson law enforcement would then be permitted to explain the fact that officers 
  were alerted to the fact and looking for a jeep with a specific tag number which 
  was registered to an individual, who can be identified, to an Anderson address 
  as a result of an incident in Greenville.
At least initially, I want to proceed on the basis that there will not be a 
  reference to the shooting death of a state trooper in Greenville.Â  And I fully 
  recognize in restricting the State in this regard, that events may develop during 
  the course of the trial.Â  For example, if the issue of identity becomes a bonafide 
  issue, there may be issues of defenses which are raised.Â  There may be requests 
  for lesser-included offenses.Â  And the list goes on.Â  Any of which may well 
  require a broadening of the admissibility of the Greenville evidence.
But at least initially, Iâ€™m going to restrict the State to the parameters I 
  have outlined.Â  If thereâ€™s any need for clarification of that, Iâ€™ll be glad 
  to respond.

(Emphasis added).
In response to the judgeâ€™s ruling, the Solicitor stated: â€œYour Honor, so in 
  other words, we will not be playing the 911 tape where they say, we heard shots.Â  
  Weâ€™re just going to say an incident.Â  Is that right?Â  Iâ€™ve got, I think, 
  all my witnesses in here.Â  I just want to clarify it for everybody before we 
  begin the testimony.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  The judge declared: â€œYes, thatâ€™s correct.â€Â  
  Reference to the murder of the state trooper was prohibited.Â  The shooting was 
  referred to as an â€œincidentâ€ throughout the trial.
The jury found Wood guilty of criminal conspiracy, failure to stop when signaled 
  by a law enforcement vehicle, resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, armed robbery, 
  two counts of possession of a firearm or knife during commission of or attempt 
  to commit a violent crime, five counts of assault with intent to kill, one count 
  of assault and battery with intent to kill, and one count of assault and battery 
  of a high and aggravated nature.Â  He received a sentence of 138 years imprisonment.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the 
  appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State v. Wilson, 345 
  S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 
  852 (Ct. App. 2003). This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings 
  unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 
  527 S.E.2d 105 (2000).Â  This same standard of review applies to preliminary 
  factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal 
  cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. 
  Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 600 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The appellate court 
  does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of 
  the evidence, but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported 
  by any evidence.Â  Mattison, 352 S.C. at 583, 575 S.E.2d at 855.
If there is any evidence 
  to support the admission of bad act evidence, the trial courtâ€™s ruling will 
  not be disturbed on appeal.Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 
  62 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. 
  App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wood argues the trial court â€œerred by refusing to exclude evidence 
  about a Greenville â€˜incidentâ€™ since it was not necessary to the juryâ€™s consideration 
  of the Anderson County charges.Â  Even if the Greenville incident was relevant, 
  its probative value was substantially outweighed by its prejudicial effect under 
  Rule 403, SCRE, and it should have been excluded on that basis.â€Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Issue Preservation
Initially, we address whether this issue is preserved for review.Â  
  Wood made a motion in limine to suppress evidence relating to 
  the murder of the state trooper, but failed to make an objection when the evidence 
  was actually presented.
In most cases, making a motion in limine to exclude evidence 
  at the beginning of trial does not preserve an issue for review because a motion 
  in limine is not a final determination.Â  State v. Forrester, 
  343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001); State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 
  S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Thus, the moving party must make a contemporaneous 
  objection when the evidence is introduced.Â  Id.; see also State 
  v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 193 n.3, 498 S.E.2d 642, 644 n.3 (1998) (â€œWe 
  have consistently held a ruling in limine is not final, and unless 
  an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling 
  procured, the issue is not preserved for review.â€) (citation omitted); State 
  v. Floyd, 295 S.C. 518, 521, 369 S.E.2d 842, 843 (1988) (â€œWe caution Bench 
  and Bar that these pre-trial motions are granted to prevent prejudicial matter 
  from being revealed to the jury, but do not constitute final rulings on the 
  admissibility of evidence.â€).
â€œHowever, where a judge makes a ruling on the admission of evidence on the 
  record immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question, the 
  aggrieved party does not need to renew the objection.â€Â  Forrester, 
  343 S.C. at 642, 541 S.E.2d at 840.Â  This court expounded:

Because no evidence was presented between the ruling and [the] testimony, there 
  was no basis for the trial court to change its ruling.Â  Thus, . . . [the] motion 
  was not a motion in limine.Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling in this 
  instance was in no way preliminary, but to the contrary, was a final ruling.Â  
  Accordingly, [the defendant] was not required to renew her objection to the 
  admission of the testimony in order to preserve the issue for appeal.

State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268-69, 460 S.E.2d 409, 410-11 
  (Ct. App. 1995) (footnote omitted); see also State v. Burton, 
  326 S.C. 605, 486 S.E.2d 762 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting the general rule that a 
  courtâ€™s ruling on in limine motion is not a final decision, but 
  applying State v. Mueller and holding that where objection is made during 
  trial and there are no intervening witnesses before the disputed testimony, 
  the decision is final and the objection need not be renewed).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In the case sub judice, the State presented the Wheelersâ€™ 
  testimony at the beginning of trial, immediately after the judge ruled on the 
  issue.Â  Therefore, the motion was not a motion in limine but a 
  final ruling.Â  Consequently, the issue may be reviewed on appeal because Wood 
  was not required to make an objection when the evidence was admitted.Â  See 
  King, 349 S.C. at 149, 561 S.E.2d at 643.
II.Â  Res Gestae
Evidence of 
  bad acts or other crimes may be admitted under the res gestae theory:

One of the accepted bases for the admissibility of evidence 
  of other crimes arises when such evidence â€œfurnishes part of the context of 
  the crimeâ€ or is necessary to a â€œfull presentationâ€ of the case, or is so intimately 
  connected with and explanatory of the crime charged against the defendant and 
  is so much a part of the setting of the case and its â€œenvironmentâ€ that its 
  proof is appropriate in order â€œto complete the story of the crime on trial by 
  proving its immediate context or the â€˜res gestaeâ€™â€ or the â€œuncharged offense 
  is â€˜so linked together in point of time and circumstances with the crime charged 
  that one cannot be fully shown without proving the other . . .â€™ [and is thus] 
  part of the res gestae of the crime charged.â€Â  And where evidence is admissible 
  to provide this â€œfull presentationâ€ of the offense, â€œ[t]here is no reason to 
  fragmentize the event under inquiryâ€ by suppressing parts of the â€œres gestae.â€

State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 122, 470 S.E.2d 366, 
  370-71 (1996) (quoting United States v. Masters, 622 F.2d 83, 86 (4th 
  Cir. 1980)).Â  The res gestae theory recognizes that evidence of other bad acts 
  may be an integral part of the crime with which the defendant is charged or 
  may be needed to aid the fact finder in understanding the context in which the 
  crime occurred.Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 745 (2001); 
  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004); State 
  v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Under this theory, 
  it is important that the temporal proximity of the prior bad act be closely 
  related to the charged crime.Â  State v. Hough, 325 S.C. 88, 480 S.E.2d 
  77 (1997).Â  Even if the evidence is relevant under this theory, prior to admission 
  the trial judge should determine whether its probative value clearly outweighs 
  any unfair prejudice.Â  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Bolden, 303 S.C. 41, 
  398 S.E.2d 494 (1990).
The evidence was properly admitted under the res gestae theory.Â  See 
  Adams, 322 S.C. at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 370-71.Â  Admission of the testimony 
  was necessary and relevant to a full presentation of the evidence in this case.Â  
  The â€œincidentâ€ provided the context and motivation for the crimes at issue.Â  
  The testimony regarding the â€œincidentâ€ was relevant to show the complete, whole, 
  unfragmented story regarding Woodâ€™s crimes.Â  See State v. Simmons, 
  352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The Wheelersâ€™ testimony elucidates 
  both the reason police pursued the Jeep and the reason Wood shot at, harmed, 
  and threatened the officers who attempted to apprehend him.Â  Furthermore, the 
  crimes were temporally related.Â  The shooting took place only two hours before 
  the occurrence at issue.Â  The two crimes comprise part of the same episode.Â  
  The crimes are so concatenated as to be inextricably intertwined.Â  See 
  Adams, 322 S.C. at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 371 (â€œThe use of the cocaine here 
  was inextricably intertwined with the robbery and murder. Under these circumstances, 
  such evidence was properly admitted as part of the res gestae 
  of the crime.â€).Â  Indubitably, the murder of a state trooper was part of the 
  res gestae of the second crimes because it explains why Wood evaded capture 
  at all costs.Â  Moreover, the probative value of the evidence outweighed its 
  prejudicial effect.Â  See Owens, 346 S.C. at 653, 552 S.E.2d at 
  753.
Because we dispose of this issue under a res gestae analysis, we 
  do NOT reach the Lyle/Rule 404(b) argument.
CONCLUSION
The trial judge engaged in a cathartic evidentiary ruling by NOT referring 
  to a â€œmurder of a highway patrolman,â€ but in a pristine and salutary etymological 
  endeavor, utilizing the term â€œincident.â€Â  The testimony describing the â€œincidentâ€ 
  is admissible under the res gestae theory.Â  Accordingly, the convictions and 
  sentences of Wood are
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.
