title: Brown v. Brown
description: In this domestic relations case, the court analyzes three issues:  (1) custody of children; (2) efficacy of preferences of custody of the minor children; and (3) whether the custody award granted de facto custody to the paternal grandparents.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Diane Q. Brown, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        George C. Brown, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
  Â James F. Fraley, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3901
  Heard November 9, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Thomas M. Neal, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        James C. Cothran, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this family court action, Diane Q. Brown (Mother) 
  appeals the family court order awarding custody of the couplesâ€™ three children 
  to George C. Brown (Father).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Father and Mother were married on December 16, 1991 and have three children, 
  Melissa Rene, born December 17, 1991, and twins, Nicholas George and Natalie 
  Rae, born June 10, 1995.Â  The parties separated on October 30, 2000, and Mother 
  initiated divorce proceedings on the ground of adultery.Â  Father did not contest 
  the divorce.Â  The parties reached an agreement settling all property and financial 
  matters.Â  The only contested issues before the family court were custody of 
  the minor children, attorneyâ€™s fees, and detective fees.Â  On appeal, the only 
  contested issue is custody of the minor children.Â  The family court awarded 
  custody of the three minor children to Father, who, by the time of trial, had 
  moved in with his parents.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 â€œIn appeals from the family court, the court of appeals has jurisdiction to 
  find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  
  Emery v. Smith, Op. No. 3870 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed Sep. 27, 2004) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 38 at 56) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 
  414 S.E.2d 157 (1992)); Upchurch v. Upchurch, 359 S.C. 254, 257-58, 597 
  S.E.2d 819, 821 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Although this Court may find facts in accordance 
  with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, we are not required 
  to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was 
  in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight 
  to their testimony.Â  See Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 471 S.E.2d 
  154 (1996); Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); 
  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 526 S.E.2d 241 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In 
  particular, an appellate court â€œshould be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation 
  of the evidence on child custody for that of the trial court.â€Â  Woodall 
  at 10, 471 S.E.2d at 157.Â Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant 
  of her burden to convince this Court the family court committed error.Â  Skinner 
  v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
ISSUES

   
    I.
    
    Did the family court err in awarding custody of the minor children to 
      Father?
    
  
   
    II. 
    
    Did the family court err by failing to adequately consider the preferences 
      of the minor children?
    
  
  
    III.   
    
    Did the family court award de facto custody to the paternal grandparents?
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Custody of the Minor Children
Mother first argues the family court erred in awarding custody of the minor 
  children to Father.Â  We disagree.Â  
The paramount and controlling factor in every custody dispute is the best interests 
  of the children.Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 
  430 (Ct. App. 2000); Paparella v. Paparella, 340 S.C. 186, 189, 531 S.E.2d 
  297, 299 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Custody decisions are left largely to the discretion 
  of the trial court.Â  Shirley at 330, 536 S.E.2d at 430.Â  
In Shirley, we articulated the South Carolina rule governing custody 
  cases:

  In all child custody controversies, the controlling considerations are the 
    childâ€™s welfare and best interests.Â  In reaching a determination as to custody, 
    the family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all 
    areas of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, 
    familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  Additionally, the court must 
    assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness, and attitude as they impact the child.Â  
  

342 S.C. at 330, 536 S.E.2d at 430 (citations omitted); see 
  also Pirayesh v. Pirayesh, 359 S.C. 284, 296, 596 S.E.2d 505, 
  512 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œWhen determining to whom custody shall be awarded, the 
  court should consider all the circumstances of the particular case and all relevant 
  factors must be taken into consideration.â€);Â  Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 
  16, 22, 553 S.E.2d 251, 254Â  (Ct. App. 2001) (providing the totality of circumstances 
  peculiar to each case constitutes the only scale upon which the ultimate decision 
  of child custody can be weighed). 
 â€œThe relative fitness of parents is an important issue in custody 
  litigation. . . . Fitness decisions normally turn on either of two considerations; 
  whether either parent has been the primary caretaker, or whether either parent 
  has engaged in conduct which would affect the welfare of the child.â€Â  Roy T. 
  Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina 433 (3rd ed. 2001).Â  â€œAlthough 
  there is no rule of law requiring custody be awarded to the primary caretaker, 
  there is an assumption that custody will be awarded to the primary caretaker.â€Â  
  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 527, 599 S.E.2d 114, 120 (2004) (citation 
  omitted).Â  

  In South Carolina, in custody matters, the father and mother are in parity 
    as to entitlement to the custody of a child.Â  When analyzing the right to 
    custody as between a father and mother, equanimity is mandated.Â  We place 
    our approbation upon the rule that in South Carolina, there is no preference 
    given to the father or mother in regard to the custody of the child.Â  The 
    parents stand in perfect equipoise as the custody analysis begins.

Kisling v. Allison, 343 S.C. 674, 678, 541 S.E.2d 273, 
  275 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Additionally, child custody is not granted to a party 
  as reward or withheld as punishment.Â  Davenport v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 
  524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975); Clear v. Clear, 331 S.C. 186, 191, 
  500 S.E.2d 790, 792 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
Morality of a parent is a proper factor for consideration in determining 
  custody of children.Â  Davenport at 527, 220 S.E.2d at 230.Â  However, 
  the effect of a parentâ€™s morality is limited in its force to what relevancy 
  it has, either directly or indirectly, to the welfare of the child.Â  Id.Â  

Recognizing this was a â€œclose custody case,â€ the family court noted 
  that â€œboth parties love the children and the children clearly love both parents, 
  and have a close relationship with both.â€Â  The court order states that â€œboth 
  parties were the primary caretakers of the children[.]â€Â  The court did not find 
  Mother unfit, but concluded custody with Father was in the childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  

Specifically, the family court found the children have had excessive 
  tardies at school and held Mother to be the significant factor causing the childrenâ€™s 
  tardies.Â  This finding is supported by the testimony of Marlene Cordoso, a school 
  employee, who testified that most of the childrenâ€™s tardiness occurred when 
  Mother brought the children to school.Â  She further averred Mother was late 
  on occasion when it was her responsibility to pick up the children from the 
  after-school care program.Â  Moreover, Ms. Cordoso stated Mother failed to pick 
  up a sick child from school after agreeing to do so.Â  
Other personnel at the school testified Mother sometimes would 
  bring the children to school without their lunches.Â  This did not occur when 
  Father brought their lunches.Â  The school employees further averred the children 
  were better groomed and properly clothed in winter months when in the care of 
  Father as opposed to Mother. 
Nancy Hogsed, a babysitter for the children, corroborated the 
  testimony of Ms. Cordoso.Â  According to Ms. Hogsed, Mother frequently was late 
  and would fail to pick up the children at the requisite time.Â  Additionally, 
  Mother was often late to or absent from the childrenâ€™s birthday parties, award 
  functions, and sporting events.Â  Mother lost her job at the hospital for excessive 
  tardiness and absenteeism.Â Â  
Furthermore, several witnesses offered testimony of Motherâ€™s 
  poor temperament.Â  The witnesses stated Mother loses her temper with her daughter 
  Melissa and cursed at the child.Â  Mitzi Kirsch, a realtor who listed the marital 
  residence, testified to a â€œscreaming rampageâ€ and verbal abuse inflicted on 
  her by Mother while Ms. Kirsch was attempting to sell the marital residence.Â  
  The relationship became so difficult that Ms. Kirsch withdrew the listing of 
  the home.Â  
Although Father admittedly engaged in an adulterous relationship, 
  he professed the amoret had ended and he was currently attending church.Â  The 
  amalgamation of witness testimony reveals Father: (1) was active in raising 
  the children; (2) often cooked meals; (3) helped with school work; (4) took 
  the children to church; and (5) attended the childrenâ€™s recreational events.Â  
  Consequently, ample evidence exists to support the trial judgeâ€™s conclusion, 
  â€œHusband has the preferable temperament for dealing with the children.â€
To support her position, Mother proffers the improvement the 
  children made in school while they were in her care.Â  She contends that since 
  the partiesâ€™ separation, the children have been late less and have improved 
  their grades, and, therefore, the family court erred by awarding custody to 
  Father.Â  However, we find the family court properly weighed the factors and 
  exercised discretion in awarding custody with Father.Â  The family court balanced 
  the adulterous indiscretions of Father against the shortcomings of Mother in 
  deciding to award custody to Father.Â  There is substantial evidence in the record 
  to support the award of custody to Father, including: (1) Motherâ€™s inability 
  consistently to have the children to school on time; (2) her inattentiveness 
  to the childrenâ€™s lives; and (3) her poor temperament around the children.Â  

The family court considered how the custody decision would impact 
  the childrenâ€™s lives and assessed each partiesâ€™ attributes.Â  It determined the 
  well-being of the children was best served by an award of custody to Father.Â  
  We find the family court properly analyzed this custody situation pursuant to 
  the statutes and case law of this state and did not abuse its discretion in 
  awarding custody to Father. 
II.Â  Childrenâ€™s Preferences
Mother contends the family court erred in failing to consider the 
  preferences of the minor children.Â  We disagree.Â  
 â€œIn determining the best interests of the child, the court must 
  consider the childâ€™s reasonable preference for custody.Â  The court shall place 
  weight upon the preference based upon the childâ€™s age, experience, maturity, 
  judgment, and ability to express a preference.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1515 
  (Supp. 2003); see also Moorhead v. Scott, 259 S.C. 580, 
  585, 193 S.E.2d 510, 513 (1972) (holding the wishes of a child of any age may 
  be considered under all the circumstances, but the weight given to those wishes 
  must be dominated by what is best for the welfare of the children).Â  The significance 
  to be attached to the wishes of children in a custody dispute depends upon the 
  age of the children and the attendant circumstances.Â  See Smith v. 
  Smith, 261 S.C. 81, 85, 198 S.E.2d 271, 274 (1973).Â  The childâ€™s preference 
  will be given little weight where the wishes of the child are influenced by 
  the permissive attitude of the preferred parent.Â  Id. at 86, 198 S.E.2d 
  at 274.Â  
The trial judge is not required to take testimony from the children 
  where (1) counsel fails to request that the judge take the testimony and (2) 
  the childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem testifies as to the childrenâ€™s preferences.Â  
  See Perry v. Perry, 315 S.C. 373, 375, 433 S.E.2d 911, 912 (Ct. 
  App. 1993); see also Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 505 
  S.E.2d 344 (Ct. App. 1998) (finding the courtâ€™s decision not to interview an 
  eleven-year-old child was not an abuse of discretion).Â  
The twins were approximately six years old at the time of trial, 
  and Melissa was approximately ten.Â  Although the guardian ad litem recommended 
  custody be awarded to Father, he asseverated: â€œ[A]ll three children stated they 
  had a preference to live with their mother.â€Â  The guardian explained:

  The reasoning for Nicholas and Natalie is justâ€”I donâ€™t think they are really 
    mature enough to really tell me why they wanted to live with her.Â  Melissa, 
    I think, is more connected, based on my conversations with her, is more connected.Â  
    She wants to stay in the neighborhood with the children she has grown up with 
    all these years.Â  But, of course, thatâ€™s not going to happen.Â  

Guinan v. Guinan, 254 S.C. 554, 176 S.E.2d 173 (1970), the 
  leading South Carolina case on childrenâ€™s preferences, dealt with the custody 
  dispute over a sixteen-year-old boy.Â  Our supreme court reversed the family 
  courtâ€™s award of custody to the mother, holding: 

  Ordinarily, the wishes of a child of this boyâ€™s age, intelligence and experience, 
    although probably not controlling, Ex parte Reynolds, 73 S.C. 296, 
    53 S.E. 490 (1906), are entitled to great weight in awarding his custody as 
    between estranged parents.Â  Annot., 4 A.L.R.3d 1396, 1434 (1965).Â  The court 
    made no finding of fact tending to offset this important factor in awarding 
    custody, and the record before us is bare of any evidence tending to do so.Â  
    Absent any evidence tending to establish that the best interest of the boy 
    would be served by awarding his custody to the mother, the court erred in 
    failing to allow him to live with the parent of his choice.Â  

Id. at 557-58, 176 S.E.2d at 174.Â  
Moorhead v. Scott, 259 S.C. 580, 193 S.E.2d 510 (1972), involved 
  a change of custody action by a father attempting to obtain custody of his children, 
  ages eight, eleven, and twelve.Â  Id. at 582, 193 S.E.2d at 512.Â  The 
  family court awarded a change of custody to the father based on its finding 
  of a substantial change of conditions and the childrenâ€™s preference to live 
  with their father.Â  Id. at 584, 193 S.E.2d at 512.Â  In reversing, the 
  supreme court noted the difference in weight to be given a childâ€™s preference 
  based upon their age and elucidated that the childrenâ€™s best interestsâ€”not the 
  childrenâ€™s preferenceâ€”is the cardinal determination in custody decisions:

  Our Court has given little significance to the wishes of a six year old child.Â  
    Poliakolff v. Poliakoff, 221 S.C. 391, 70 S.E.2d 625 (1952).Â  On the 
    other hand, our Court has given great weight to the wishes of a child sixteen 
    years of age.Â  Guinan v. Guinan, 254 S.C. 554, 176 S.E.2d 173 (1970).Â  
    It is clear that the wishes of a child of any age may be considered under 
    all the circumstances, but the weight given to those wishes must be dominated 
    by what is best for the welfare of the children.Â  

Id. at 585, 193 S.E.2d at 513.
In summation, South Carolina law requires the family court to consider 
  a childâ€™s reasonable preference for custody.Â  However, the weight given to the 
  childâ€™s preference depends upon the childâ€™s age, experience, maturity, judgment, 
  and ability to express a preference.Â  And a determination of the best interests 
  of the child is paramount to the childâ€™s preference.Â  
Although the six-year-old twins expressed a preference for Mother, 
  we find Poliakolff and Morehead counsel that minimal weight should 
  be given the preference of such young children.Â  Ten-year-old Melissaâ€™s wishes 
  should be given more weight because she is older.Â  However, even the weight 
  given the preference of a ten-year-old does not rise to the level of â€œgreat 
  weightâ€ that should be given the desires of a sixteen-year-old.Â  See 
  Bolding v. Bolding, 278 S.C. 129, 293 S.E.2d 699 (1982) (reversing change 
  of custody of eleven-year-old because â€œFather failed in his burden of establishing 
  a change of condition sufficient to warrant a transfer of custody, as the only 
  change alleged or proved involved the wishes of the eleven-year-old child.â€); 
  see also Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina 
  454 (3rd ed. 2001) (â€œJudging from the handful of South Carolina cases on childrenâ€™s 
  preferences, it appears that somewhere between 12 and 14 may well be the ages 
  at which the wishes of the child should be given serious consideration.â€); Patel 
  v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 599 S.E.2d 114 (2004) (upholding award of custody 
  of thirteen-year-old daughter to the mother where daughter expressed â€œdefinite 
  desireâ€ to live with mother).
Moreover, the preference of any child is merely a factor in 
  the analysisâ€”it is not determinative.Â  The family court, cognizant of the childrenâ€™s 
  wishes, considered the factors in this custody decision and reasonably concluded 
  it was in their best interests to be with Father.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  

III.Â  De Facto Custody
Mother argues the custody award to Father was actually a de 
  facto custody award to the childrenâ€™s paternal grandparents.Â  She claims the 
  grant of custody was error because (1) the grandparents were not parties to 
  the action, and (2) even if the grandparents had been parties to the action, 
  Mother would have to have been adjudged unfit under Moore v. Moore, 300 
  S.C. 75, 386 S.E.2d 456 (1989) in order for custody to go to the grandparents.Â  
  We find this argument without merit.Â  
Â The family court considered the work schedules of both parties 
  in its analysis and found:

  Although husbandâ€™s third shift job and his living with his parents would, 
    normally be a negative factor against his receiving custody, the Court believes 
    that this negative factor is not significant.Â  The children have a close relationship 
    with their paternal grandparents.Â  The paternal grandparents have often times 
    assisted the parents in caring for the children . . . .Â  This living arrangement 
    will actually assist the husband in caring for the children since the grandparents 
    will be home with the children while he is working third shift.

This Court expressly rejects the principle entitled â€œde factoâ€ 
  custody.Â  Factually, â€œde factoâ€ custody, even if recognized, is not presented 
  or proven in this case.Â  Apodictically, custody was awarded to Father, not the 
  grandparents.Â  The family court merely factored the paternal grandparents into 
  the custody analysis.Â  Mother cites no law supporting her theory of de facto 
  custody, and we refuse to erect a rule that would punish a parent solely because 
  he or she chooses to live with his or her parents.Â  
Further, we find Moore inapposite as that case addressed 
  the rebuttable presumption that â€œit is in the best interest of any child to 
  be in the custody of its biological parent.â€Â  300 S.C. at 79, 386 S.E.2d at 
  458 (citing Kay v. Rowland, 285 S.C. 516, 331 S.E.2d 781 (1985); Cook 
  v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 345 S.E.2d 612 (1978)).Â  The case at bar deals with 
  a custody dispute between the two parents, not between a parent and a third 
  party.Â  Concomitantly, the court did not need to find Mother unfit to award 
  custody to Father.Â  We find granting custody to the Father, partially because 
  of the assistance available from the paternal grandparents, was not tantamount 
  to de facto custody and did not constitute an abuse of discretion.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the decision of the family court awarding custody to 
  Father is hereby
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Cole v. Raut
description: In this medical negligence case, the court submitted the case to the jury on only one cause of action and only one defense.  The jury returned a general verdict for the defense.  The court affirmed under the two issue rule, finding sufficient evidence to support the negligence cause of action submitted to the jury.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Marty K. Cole and Tracy S. Cole, as co-administrators of the Estate 
          of Kyle Austin Cole, and Tracy S. and Marty K. Cole, individually, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Pratibha P. Raut, M.D., and Dr. Raut & Associates, P.A., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chester County
  Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3902
  Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Charles L. Henshaw, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Robert H. Hood, Hugh W. Buyck, Roy P. Maybank and Deborah Sheffield, 
          all of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this medical negligence 
  action, Marty and Tracy Cole appeal a general defense verdict for Dr. Pratibha 
  P. Raut and her medical practice.Â  The Coles argue the circuit court erred in 
  charging the jury on the defense of assumption of risk.Â  We affirm pursuant 
  to the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Coles brought this action individually and on behalf of their son, Kyle, 
  who was born on February 22, 1997.Â  The Coles alleged medical negligence against 
  Dr. Raut and her medical practice.Â  The complaint essentially asserted that 
  Dr. Raut failed to deliver Kyle in a timely manner by Cesarean section (C-section) 
  birth, and failed to timely respond to warning signs that Kyle was suffering 
  from the effects of oxygen distress prior to birth.Â  Dr. Raut and her practice 
  denied negligence, and asserted various defenses, including contributory negligence.Â  

Dr. Raut and her practice sought to amend their pleadings at trial to include 
  assumption of risk as a separate, affirmative defense.Â  Initially, the court 
  ruled that the â€œcomparative fault affirmative defense covered assumption of 
  the risk.â€Â  When Dr. Raut and her practice renewed their motion, the court elected 
  to reserve its ruling on the motion until the close of evidence.Â  After all 
  evidence was presented, the court struck the comparative negligence defense 
  raised by Dr. Raut and her practice.Â  However, over the Colesâ€™ objection, the 
  court elected to charge the jury on the affirmative defense of assumption of 
  risk. [1] 
At trial, both parties provided expert testimony regarding the various issues 
  stemming from the care rendered by Dr. Raut in the delivery process, including 
  Dr. Rautâ€™s timing in ordering a C-section. [2] Â  Predictably, the Coles presented expert testimony 
  that Dr. Raut deviated from the standard of care which resulted in injury, and 
  Dr. Raut presented expert testimony that she did not deviate from the applicable 
  standard of care while providing prenatal care to Mrs. Cole or in the delivery 
  of her child.Â  A jury issue was therefore presented on the malpractice - negligence 
  claim.
The court instructed the jury that the Coles were entitled to prevail if the 
  jury found Dr. Raut was negligent â€œin at least one or more of the ways alleged 
  â€¦ [and that] the defendantsâ€™ negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s 
  injuries.â€Â  When later charging the jury on the assumption of risk affirmative 
  defense, the court stated:

  I charge you, if you find that the plaintiff freely and voluntarily exposed 
    herself to a known danger and understood and appreciated the danger, then 
    in such circumstance your verdict would be for the defendant.Â  However, I 
    charge you, on the other hand, if you find that the plaintiffâ€™s injuries and 
    negligence were the result of the defendantâ€™s negligence, then in such circumstance 
    your verdict would be for the plaintiff.

The jury returned a general defense verdict.Â  Judgment was 
  entered for Dr. Raut and her medical practice.Â  The Coles appeal.
DISCUSSION
The Coles argue the circuit court erred in instructing the jury on the assumption 
  of risk defense, contending the defense is inapplicable to the facts of the 
  case.Â  We do not reach this issue, however, because the jury returned a general 
  verdict for the defense, and that verdict is independently supported by the 
  unchallenged submission of the negligence claim to the jury. 
  [3] Â  This principle is generally referred to as the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule.Â  
  The rule is based on the principle that reversal is inappropriate where no error 
  is found as to one of the issues that may independently support the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  
  See Anderson v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 
  317 S.C. 280, 282, 454 S.E.2d 353, 355 (Ct.App. 1995) (â€œIf a verdict is susceptible 
  of two constructions, one of which will uphold it and the other which will defeat 
  it, the one which will uphold it is preferredâ€).Â  Moreover, a general verdict 
  is presumptively valid.Â  See Gold Kist, Inc. v. Citizens & Southern 
  Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 286 S.C. 272, 282, 333 S.E.2d 67, 73 (Ct.App. 
  1985) (â€œThe appellate courts of this State exercise every reasonable presumption 
  in favor of the validity of a general verdictâ€).
Â Because the present case involved both an issue 
  of negligenceâ€”properly submitted to the juryâ€”and the challenged defense of assumption 
  of risk, we are bound to affirm the defense verdict if the verdict may be sustained 
  on the negligence claim.Â  See Id. (â€œ[W]here a jury returns a general 
  verdict in a case involving two or more issues or defenses and its verdict is 
  supported as to at least one issue or defense, the verdict will not be reversedâ€).Â  
  The Coles concede the negligence claim involved disputed issues of fact and 
  was properly submitted to the jury.Â  The general defense verdict may therefore 
  be sustained on the negligence claim.Â  See Anderson, 317 S.C. 
  at 282, 454 S.E.2d at 355 (Applying the â€œtwo-issueâ€ rule where case submitted 
  to jury on only one cause of action, negligence, and only one defense, contributory 
  negligence).
CONCLUSION
Since the general defense verdict may be sustained 
  on the negligence cause of action, the judgment of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.


 
   [1]  Â We recognize that in 
    South Carolina the doctrine of assumption of risk was largely subsumed by 
    the law of comparative negligence in Davenport v. Cotton Hope Plantation, 
    333 S.C. 71, 508 S.E.2d 565 (1998).Â  However, the cause of action in this 
    present case arose in February 1997, prior to Davenport.

 
   [2]  Â Mrs. Cole was admitted 
    to the hospital on February 21, 1997.Â  The labor period was prolonged, and 
    the record contains a detailed history of the labor process.Â  We need not 
    discuss this factual background in light of our disposition of this appeal.

 
   [3]  Â While Dr. Raut objected to the general verdict 
    form, the Coles did not.

title: Montgonery v. CSX Transportation, Inc.
description: This is a FELA case.  The primary issue is whether there was any negligence on the part of CSX Railroad in regard to an injury suffered and sustained by Montgomery on a railroad track line.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Harry Montgomery, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        CSX Transportation, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
  James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3903
  Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

REVERSED and REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Mark A. Stephens and Robert A. McKenzie, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Mark C. Wilby, of Augusta, Georgia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â  Harry Montgomery, a railroad employee with 
  CSX Transportation, Inc. (CSX), was injured as he attempted to tighten a bolt 
  on a railroad track.Â  Montgomery filed this action against CSX Transportation, 
  Inc. under the Federal Employersâ€™ Liability Act.Â  The circuit court granted 
  summary judgment.Â  We reverse and remand for trial.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
CSX Transportation, Inc. (CSX) owns and operates two mainline tracks north 
  of Charleston, South Carolina: the â€œA-lineâ€ and the â€œS-line.â€Â  The A-line runs 
  from Charleston to Dillon, South Carolina to Rocky Mount, North Carolina to 
  Richmond, Virginia and beyond.Â  The S-line runs from Charleston to Andrews, 
  South Carolina then cuts inland to Hamlet, North Carolina, then to Raleigh, 
  North Carolina and then cuts eastward and reconnects with the A-line north of 
  Rocky Mount.
Other than the physical places that the rails run, 
  there are several significant differences between the A-line and S-line.Â  First, 
  the A-line is made of â€œwelded rail,â€ which is continuous quarter-mile rail sections 
  welded together.Â  Thus, there are no track bolts or nuts on the A-line needed 
  to hold the rail together.Â  Contrastively, the S-line is made up of â€œjointed 
  rail.â€Â  â€œJointed railâ€ is made from thirty-nine foot rail sections held together 
  by â€œrail joints,â€ which are iron plates placed on either side of the ends of 
  the rail where they abut.Â  The plates are attached to the rails by six large 
  track bolts and nuts which hold the rail sections together.
Second, the A-line is much more active than the S-line in terms of the amount 
  of traffic run by CSX on the rail.Â  The A-line is a â€œClass 4 Trackâ€ â€“ a high 
  speed passenger track through which most of the freight is run.Â  On the other 
  hand, the S-line is a â€œClass 
  3 Trackâ€ that is mostly used for local freight.Â  Between sixteen and seventeen 
  trains run daily on the A-line.Â  Approximately three trains run daily on the 
  S-line.
Third, at the time of the events which form the basis of this suit, the A-line 
  was in much better condition than the S-line. Â Harry Montgomery, the plaintiff 
  in this action and a CSX employee since 1977, described the difference between 
  the two tracks:

  [The S-line] was tore up and run down for many years and you had to be there 
    to see it.Â  It wasâ€”it was a bad railroad track.Â  It was a bad piece of track.Â  
    It was rough, it was rugged, there was a lot of work.Â  I mean a whole lot 
    more work to have been done on that piece of railroad track than it was on 
    the A Line.

Because of the S-lineâ€™s poor condition, CSX placed 
  a lot of â€œslow ordersâ€ on the S-line, which meant that the freight that needed 
  to be run was often â€œbacked-up.â€Â  In fact, CSXâ€™s employees were told that the 
  Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) was going to shut down the S-line because 
  the track was in such bad shape. Â Fourth, the employees working on the A-line 
  were given more equipment and much superior equipment than that given to Montgomery, 
  the only track maintenance employee on the S-line.
Montgomery began working for CSX in 1977.Â  In 1994, he was promoted to foreman.Â  
  At the time of Montgomeryâ€™s injury in 1999, James F. Reed was Montgomeryâ€™s Roadmaster 
  in charge of both the A-line and the S-line.Â  Darrell Crook was CSXâ€™s Assistant 
  Division Engineer.Â  There were two track inspectors working for Reed: Montgomery 
  and Ussery.Â  A track inspectorâ€™s job is to inspect the railroad tracks, look 
  for anything that is unsafe, and try to make it safe or take it out of service.Â  
  Montgomery summarized a track inspectorâ€™s duties:

  [T]ighten[ed] track bolts, replaced broken joints, replaced broken joint 
    bars, replaced anything thatâ€™sâ€”that might be broken or defective in a switch 
    or onâ€”on, not necessarily in a switch, but preferably in aâ€”well, more important 
    in a switch or on just railroad tracks to assure proper rock, railroad we 
    call a balance, but itâ€™s railroad rocks, so that you would understand, make 
    sure that on a given day if there is a lot of rocks, ample rocks, enough rocks 
    on a givenâ€”anything to make sure that signs, railroad signs, that theyâ€™re 
    supposed to be in place are in place, report anything that we see thatâ€™s out 
    of the ordinary that wouldâ€”that would allow a piece of track to be unsafe.

Although Montgomery had twenty years of experience and Ussery had only worked 
  for CSX for two years, Reed and Crook took Montgomery off the A-line and gave 
  supervision of that line to Ussery.Â  Montgomery was made the inspector of the 
  S-line.Â  Ussery was then labeled the â€œSeniorâ€ Track Inspector.Â  These changes 
  occurred approximately one to two months before Montgomeryâ€™s accident.Â  Because 
  Montgomery felt his job would be in danger if he complained, he did not refuse 
  to work on the S-line.
Montgomery was responsible for the â€œAndrews Subdivisionâ€ of the S-line, a stretch 
  of track forty-five to fifty miles long.Â  Crook professed that at the time he 
  assigned Montgomery to the Andrews Subdivision of the S-line, he knew that it 
  â€œhad a lot of bolts out, [it] had broken bars over there, [it] had a good many 
  weak ties and had some surface conditions.â€Â  In actuality, the condition of 
  the track was much worse.Â  Few of the bolts that held the jointed rails together 
  were secure.Â  Some were loose, while others were missing.Â  In fact, some joint 
  bars needed to be totally replaced and/or lifted up.
Although Montgomery was technically a â€œforemanâ€ 
  at the time of his injury, he had no employees working under his supervision 
  on the S-line.Â  Not only was Montgomery the only person assigned to inspect 
  the S-line, but he was also the only person to make the repairs and maintenance 
  on the S-line.Â  Montgomery was required to inspect and repair and/or replace 
  every bolt on every joint bar on the S-line.Â  There are approximately 130 joints 
  per mile per rail on the S-line, meaning that there were 3,120 bolts and nuts 
  that needed to be checked per mile.Â  Montgomery was required to be certain that 
  more than 70,000 bolts were tightened and/or replaced in addition to all the 
  other problems with the S-line.
Before Montgomery began work on this project, Crook advised Montgomery that 
  he knew the S-line â€œwas in bad shape.â€Â  Because the S-line was in a state of 
  disrepair, Crook promised Montgomery that CSX would provide him with a â€œbolt-tightening 
  machineâ€ to do the assignment.Â  A â€œbolt-tightening machineâ€ is a hydraulic, 
  eight horsepower machine that mechanically tightens and loosens track nuts.Â  
  Crook gave Montgomery a bolt-tightening machine, albeit a very old one.Â  However, 
  Montgomery was provided no other power equipment or welding equipment to repair 
  the S-line.Â  On the other hand, even though the A-line has no bolts to tighten 
  (because it was welded rail) and was not in disrepair, Ussery was given a new 
  truck with which to maintain the A-line.Â  The truck was equipped with a newer 
  bolt-tightening machine, a MAT-weld unitâ€”a detachable hydraulic and gas-powered 
  unit that allowed the user to operate power tools while working on the line, 
  including, but not limited to, power wrenches, power saws, power drills, welding 
  equipment, and a welding torch.
On Montgomeryâ€™s first day of work on the S-line, the old bolt machine given 
  to him by Crook failed and became inoperable.Â  It was neither repaired nor replaced 
  by CSX.Â  The other bolt-tightening machine issued to Ussery, the only remaining 
  machine that CSX allocated to Crookâ€™s department, which covered 1400 miles of 
  track, was not made available to Montgomery even though Ussery had no real need 
  for it.Â  Because CSX would not give Montgomery another machine or even Usseryâ€™s 
  machine, Montgomeryâ€™s only alternative was to replace and tighten the bolts 
  by hand with a three to four foot long manual â€œtrack wrench.â€
To use the track wrench, Montgomery had to stand on the ground facing the rail 
  with the head of the wrench pointing down and fastened on the nut.Â  The nut 
  is on the opposite side of the rail from the bolt head.Â  The head of the bolt 
  is oblong and fits into an oblong hole on the inside of the joint bar so it 
  will not move if the nut is tightened or loosened on the other side.Â  Montgomery 
  would then push the handle of the wrench from right to left to remove the nut 
  or left to right to tighten the nut.
Every day for the entire day, Montgomery tightened and replaced bolts by hand 
  with the manual track wrench.Â  Montgomery stated that he â€œwas supposed to go 
  on as far as, you know, my work time would allow me to [every day].â€Â  Although 
  Montgomery had been working over a month on the S-lineâ€™s Andrews Subdivision 
  at the time he was injured, he had only been able to repair a few of the forty-five 
  miles of his assignment before he was hurt.
Montgomery was injured on July 13, 1999, between 11:30 a.m. and 12:00 p.m., 
  approximately three-and-a-half hours after he began working that day.Â  He was 
  trying to tighten a loose nut with the track wrench when the nut stiffened up 
  or froze on the bolt.Â  When Montgomery applied more pressure, the frozen nut 
  suddenly gave way, the end of the wrench came off the nut, he was thrown between 
  the rails by his momentum, and he landed hard on the track on his right knee, 
  side, and elbow.Â  Montgomery explained:

  Okay.Â  When Iâ€”when I started to tighten thisâ€”this bolt, after I seen that 
    that boltâ€”that particular bolt was loose, I got my wrench and Iâ€”Iâ€”I positioned 
    myself and I, you know, went about trying to tighten it.Â  So I give it a few 
    turns and at one point theâ€”the wrench, the bolt actually froze, so I went 
    about giving it someâ€”and Iâ€”as I looked, the bolt was notâ€”it was not tightening.Â  
    So when I get toâ€”when I went and put my wrench back on there and I tried to 
    tighten it some more, the bolt had froze, which allowed me to apply just a 
    little more pressure than normal, and then all of a sudden the whole thing 
    gave which sent meâ€”threw me across the rail, sent me across the rail.

Montgomery had neck surgery and knee surgery as 
  a result of the accident.
At the time Montgomery was injured, which was the mid-point in his shift, he 
  had already tightened or replaced over 200 bolts that day.Â  He was not charged 
  with violation of any rule by CSX.Â  Yet, the attorney for CSX criticized Montgomery 
  for trying to free up and tighten the tough bolt.Â  Montgomery realistically 
  had no option but to try to do so:
 
  Q:Â  Do you have any procedures or instructions for what to do in the event 
    that a bolt sticks like that one did, any rules or regulations?
    A:Â  Well, youâ€™ve gotâ€”youâ€™ve gotâ€”you have several options, because if youâ€”ifâ€”if 
    given I had thatâ€”thatâ€”that torch that I was telling you about, you can cut 
    it off and donâ€™t even have to use a wrench or if a welder was in the area, 
    you canâ€”you can ask him to cut it off, which is the same as cutting it off.
    Q:Â  And then just put a new one on there?
    A:Â  Thatâ€™s right.
    Q:Â  Okay.Â  And why did you not just stop and get somebody to come and do that 
    for y[ou]?
    A:Â  Oh, well, no, itâ€™s not like that, Miss.Â  Itâ€™s not that every time you 
    run into a joint bar you call a welder to tighten it.Â  Thatâ€™sâ€”thatâ€™sâ€”thatâ€™s 
    part of your job.Â  I mean, thatâ€™sâ€”and you donâ€™t cryâ€”you donâ€™t cry or scream 
    help every time you run into a minor problem.
  
According to Montgomery, even if he had called, 
  no one would have come to cut one single bolt:
 
  Q:Â  She asked could you have called for help.Â  Could you have gotten any 
    help?
    A:Â  It is very doubtful that I would have gotten any.Â  I could have called.
   
    Ms. McLeod:Â  Why is it doubtful?
      The Witness:Â  Because of the amount of people that worksâ€”that was working 
      at the time in Bennett Yard, a shortage.
    

Montgomery filed a personal injury action against CSX under the Federal Employersâ€™ 
  Liability Act (FELA), asserting his injuries were caused â€œin whole or in partâ€ 
  by the negligence of CSX.Â  Montgomery alleged that he was assigned an unreasonable 
  task, maintenance of the entire S-line, and the recurring tightening of bolts 
  required by this assignment caused his injury.Â  Alternatively, or in combination 
  with the unreasonable task theory, Montgomery averred he was provided insufficient 
  equipment for the task assigned.Â  In his complaint, Montgomery specifically 
  claimed that CSX was negligent â€œin its engines, cars, appliances, machinery, 
  roadbed, track, work assignments and methods, works or other equipmentâ€ and 
  in its failure â€œto exercise reasonable care to furnish and maintain reasonably 
  safe and suitable equipment and work methods and [to provide] a reasonably safe 
  place in which to perform his work.â€
CSX maintained that it follows job analysis and physical qualifications in 
  assigning certain jobs.Â  Indeed, Reed stated that a track worker like Montgomery 
  would only normally be required to tighten two dozen bolts in a normal day of 
  work and that if a worker has to tighten as many as 100 bolts in a day that 
  he should be given a bolt tightening machine to properly perform his assignment:
 
  Q:Â  If he hadâ€”ifâ€”if you knew that a man would have to tighten as many as 
    a hundred bolts in a day, would you give him a machine to do it?
    A:Â  Yes, if we had somebody doing that.
  
Reed inconsistently claimed that it is appropriate 
  to require an employee to tighten 100 to 150 bolts a day with a track wrench.Â  
  He did not express any opinion about whether 200 bolts was appropriate.Â  Yet, 
  Montgomery had already done 200 in less than half of the dayâ€™s work.
In support of the theories asserted by Montgomery, 
  he presented affidavits from two experts that show the assignment given to Montgomery 
  and the tools provided to Montgomery were not reasonably safe.Â  First, Montgomery 
  produced an affidavit from Don H. Bowden, Sr., a railroad safety consultant.Â  
  Bowden has testified concerning common and reasonable work assignments and safety 
  practices in the railroad industry.Â  He explicated that repairing the Andrews 
  Subdivision should not have been done by one worker alone:

  Under common industry practice, this job should not be done by one man alone.Â  
    Mr. Montgomery was assigned to the monumental task of repairing the track 
    by himself.Â  While it is not uncommon for one man to be assigned a task in 
    inspecting a track, it is unreasonably hazardous to require one man to not 
    only inspect the track, but also perform the actual track maintenance himself.Â  
    A prudent and reasonable railroad would assign a gang of men to do this type 
    of job.Â  To do otherwise, in my opinion, subjects the employee to an unsafe 
    workplace in the railroad industry because an accident is bound to happen.

Bowden declared the track wrench was an unsafe and 
  unsuitable tool for this assignment:

  The unreasonable hazards to which Mr. Montgomery was exposed by working this 
    track by himself were greatly exacerbated and increased by CSX requiring him 
    to replace and/or tighten the track bolts with a manual track wrench.Â  While 
    it is not uncommon for workers to use manual track wrenches to tighten sporadic 
    loose bolts on a stretch of track, this particular track was in such a state 
    of disrepair that the use of a track wrench was not only impracticable, it 
    unreasonably increased the likelihood of injury to Mr. Montgomery.Â  To use 
    an analogy, a swing-blade works fine to knock-down sporadic weeds on a private 
    lawn; however, one would not require a man to use a swing-blade to clear several 
    years of growth on a 100 acre plat of land.Â  In addition to the sheer volume 
    of bolts that Mr. Montgomery needed to replace and/or tighten, the condition 
    of the bolts and the track also made the manual track wrench an unsuitable 
    tool for this job.Â  This track had been neglected by CSX for a long period 
    of time.Â  As such, CSX should have known that the bolts were very likely to 
    be â€œrusted-on,â€ making them very difficult to remove and/or tighten.Â  Requiring 
    Mr. Montgomery to work with a manual wrench in these conditions unreasonably 
    multiplied his risk of injury.Â  Mr. Montgomeryâ€™s description of the accident 
    shows these hazards were present because he was required to use a tremendous 
    amount of leverage on the wrench to break through the rust.Â  For all of these 
    reasons, a prudent and reasonable railroad would not have supplied just a 
    track wrench to Mr. Montgomery to do this job.Â  A prudent and reasonable railroad 
    would have provided him with another bolt tightening machine when the first 
    one became inoperable or would have fixed the one assigned to him.

Second, Montgomery submitted the affidavit of Dr. 
  Tyler A. Kress, Ph.D., a biomechanical engineer.Â  In his affidavit, Dr. Kress 
  discussed a 1986 study undertaken by the Association of American Railroads, 
  which indicated that 11.1% of all tool-related injuries resulted from the use 
  of track wrenches.Â  Dr. Kress opined the type of work that Montgomery was performing 
  daily and the tools he was given to perform that work created unreasonably dangerous 
  biomechanical risks to his body:
 
  It is my opinion that (1) the type of work that Mr. Montgomery was performing 
    daily and (2) the tools he was given to perform that work created unreasonably 
    dangerous biomechanical risk factors to his body.Â  It is my further opinion 
    that these risk factors are consistent with his fall and the injuries he sustained 
    as a result of his fall.
  Apparently, Mr. Montgomery was ordered to perform the repetitive motion of

  [11] Â  It is undisputed that the track wrench Montgomery was using when 
  he fell was not defective and was similar to other track wrenches he had used 
  for the past twenty years.Â  
The focus of this controversy comes down to whether 
  CSX should have provided a bolt-tightening machine in view of expert testimony 
  suggesting that a manual track wrench, although not defective, was unreasonably 
  dangerous for Montgomeryâ€™s assignment. [12] 
Bowden provided a statement acknowledging that, 
  although a manual track tool was safe and suitable for sporadic tightening and 
  untightening of bolts, the Andrews subdivision â€œwas in such a state of disrepair 
  that the use of a track wrench was not only impracticable, it unreasonably increased 
  the likelihood of injury to Mr. Montgomery.â€Â  Bowden further noted that, as 
  the S-line â€œhad been neglected by CSX for a long period of time,â€ â€œCSX should 
  have known that the bolts were very likely to be â€˜rusted on,â€™ making them very 
  difficult to remove and/or tighten.â€ Â Similarly, Tyler A. Kress, an industrial 
  engineer, stated in an affidavit that â€œwhen an employee is forced to use a manual 
  track wrench all day long on rusted and poorly tended nuts and bolts, the risk 
  of injury increases with each repetitive use.â€ 
I would hold the trial court correctly concluded 
  that the expert opinions offered in response to CSXâ€™s summary judgment motion 
  do not give rise to an inference that a manual track wrench was not reasonably 
  safe for the work that was assigned to Montgomery.Â  There was no admissible 
  evidence supporting a finding that Montgomery was subject to any pressure with 
  respect to the amount of work he had to complete in any given time period.Â  
  Furthermore, the record is devoid of any suggestion that Montgomery was suffering 
  from fatigue or other ill effects of repetitive motion. [13] 
Finally, citing Blair v. Baltimore & Ohio 
  Railroad Co., [14]  Montgomery argues he presented 
  sufficient evidence of negligence on the part of CSX through the combined effect 
  of its failure to provide him with the necessary help and its refusal to give 
  him proper equipment.Â  I disagree.
In Blair, the Supreme Court, in reinstating 
  an award under FELA, held there was sufficient evidence of the railroad defendantâ€™s 
  negligence to have the issue determined by a jury.Â  In so holding, the Supreme 
  Court stated as follows:

  The negligence of the employer may be determined by viewing its conduct as 
    a whole.Â  And especially is this true in a case such as this, where the several 
    elements from which negligence might be inferred are so closely interwoven 
    as to form a single pattern, and where each imparts character to the others. 
    [15] 

Further reading of the opinion, however, indicates 
  that the cumulative impact of the â€œseveral elements from which negligence might 
  be inferredâ€ was not the deciding factor in the decision.Â  Rather, it is evident 
  from the text immediately following what is quoted above that the Supreme Court 
  had already accepted the premise that the railroad employer was negligent in 
  several respects, any one of which would have been actionable in its own right, 
  and the relationship between all of these undisputed manifestations of negligence 
  only enhanced an already meritorious action:

  The nature of the duty which the petitioner was commanded to undertake, the 
    dangers of moving a greased, 1000 pound steel tube, 30 feet in length, on 
    a 5 foot truck, the area over which that truck was compelled to be moved, 
    the suitableness of the tools used in an extraordinary manner to accomplish 
    a novel purpose, the number of men assigned to assist him, their experience 
    in such work and their ability to perform the duties and the manner in which 
    they performed those dutiesâ€”all of these raised questions appropriate for 
    a jury to appraise in considering whether or not the injury was the result 
    of negligence as alleged in the complaint.Â  We cannot say as a matter 
    of law that the railroad complied with its duties in a reasonably careful 
    manner under the circumstances here, nor that the conduct which the jury might 
    have found to be negligent did not contribute to petitionerâ€™s injury â€œin whole 
    or in part.â€Â  Consequently, we think the jury, and not the court should finally 
    determine these issues. [16] 

In contrast, none of the specifications of negligence 
  alleged in the present case had sufficient evidentiary support to withstand 
  CSXâ€™s summary judgment motion.Â  Blair therefore is easily distinguishable 
  from the present case.
I would affirm the grant of summary judgment to CSX.


 
   [1] Â  Norton v. Norfolk S. Ry., 350 S.C. 473, 
    476, 567 S.E.2d 851, 853 (2002).

 
   
    [2] Â  Rogers v. Mo. Pac. R.R., 352 U.S. 500, 506 (1957).

 
   
    [3] Â  Claar v. Burlington N. R.R. Co., 29 F.3d 499, 503 (9th 
    Cir. 1994).

 
   
    [4] Â  Norton, 350 S.C. at 480 n.5, 567 S.E.2d at 855 n.5 (quoting 
    Hernandez v. Trawler Miss Vertie Mae, Inc., 187 F.3d 432, 436-37 (4th 
    Cir. 1999)).

 
   
    [5] Â  See Frazier v. Norfolk & W. Ry. Co., 996 F.2d 
    922, 923 (7th Cir. 1993) (concerning a plaintiff who was injured 
    while unloading 11,600-pound double-axle wheel assemblies from a trailer); 
    S. Ry. Co. v. Welch, 247 F.2d 340, 341 (6th Cir. 1957) (noting 
    â€œcircumstances of particular difficultyâ€ warranting assigning additional personnel 
    to assist in a particular task); McKennon v. CSX Transp., 897 F. Supp. 
    1024, 1027 (M.D. Tenn. 1995) (holding in a summary judgment case that â€œthe 
    fact that Plaintiffâ€™s job would have been easier if there had been more workers 
    does not constitute negligence on the part of Defendant, nor does it create 
    an unreasonably unsafe work environmentâ€).

 
  
  [6] Â  Montgomery testified 
    in his deposition as follows:Â  â€œI was supposed to go on as far as, you know, 
    my work time would allow me to and you know, get off.â€

 
   
    [7] Â  See Lujan v. Natâ€™l Wildlife Fedâ€™n, 497 U.S. 871, 888 
    (1990) (â€œThe object of [Rule 56] is not to replace conclusory allegations 
    of the complaint or answer with conclusory allegations of an affidavit.â€); 
    Lavender v. Kurn, 327 U.S. 645 (1956) (stating speculation and conjecture 
    are not a substitute for probative facts); Zarecki v. Natâ€™l R.R. Passenger 
    Corp., 914 F. Supp. 1566, 1574 (N.D. Ill. 1996) (â€œAn affidavit that does 
    not set forth the facts and reasoning used in making a conclusion amounts 
    to nothing more than a denial of the adverse partyâ€™s pleading.â€); E.T. 
    Barwick Indus. v. Walter Heller & Co., 692 F. Supp. 1331, 1347 (N.D. 
    Ga. 1987) (â€œTheoretical speculations, unsupported assumptions, and conclusory 
    allegations advanced by an expert . . . are [not] entitled to any weight when 
    raised in opposition to a motion for summary judgment.â€) (citations omitted), 
    affâ€™d, 891 F.2d 906 (11th Cir. 1989).

 
   
    [8] Â  671 So. 2d 888 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1996).

 
   
    [9] Â  Montgomery notes in his brief that one of the supervisors testified 
    that a track worker with only manual equipment would be expected to tighten 
    only 24 bolts during a normal workday. 

 
   
    [10]  See Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 175, 561 S.E.2d 654, 
    657 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding hearsay evidence presented in response to summary 
    judgment motion did not create a genuine issue of material fact because â€œ[o]ur 
    appellate courts have interpreted Rule 56(e) to mean materials used to support 
    or refute a motion for summary judgment must be admissible in evidenceâ€).

 
   
    [11]  Chicago & N.W. Ry. v. Bower, 241 U.S. 470, 473-74 (1916).

 
   
    [12]  See McKennon, 897 F. Supp. at 1027 (â€œUnder FELA, the 
    proper inquiry is whether the method prescribed by the employer was reasonably 
    safe, not whether the employer could have employed a safer alternative method 
    for performing the task.â€).

 
   
    [13]  See Mayhew v. Bell S.S. Co., 917 F.2d 961, 963 (6th 
    Cir. 1990) (stating that although â€œrelaxed standards applied in FELA and Jones 
    Act suitsâ€ do not require a medical expert â€œto articulate to a â€˜reasonable 
    degree of medical certainty,â€™ . . . a medical expert must be able to articulate 
    that it is likely that the defendantâ€™s negligence, or more than possible that 
    the defendantâ€™s negligence, had a causal relationship with the injury and 
    disability for which the plaintiff seeks damagesâ€); Moody v. Me. Cent. 
    R.R. Co., 823 F.2d 693, 695 (1st Cir. 1987) (â€œ[A]lthough a 
    plaintiff need not make a showing that the employerâ€™s negligence was the sole 
    cause, there must be a sufficient showing (i.e., more than a possibility) 
    that a causal relation existed.â€); Collier v. Varco-Pruden Bldgs., 
    911 F. Supp. 189, 192 (D.S.C. 1995) (finding an expertâ€™s affidavit â€œamount[ed] 
    to nothing more than his speculation as to what â€˜most likelyâ€™ happened, and 
    has no support in the recordâ€).

 
   [14] 323 U.S. 600 (1945).

 
   [15]  Id. at 604 (citations omitted).

 
   
    [16]  Id. at 604-05 (emphasis added).

title: State v. Landis
description: In this criminal appeal, the appellant contends the circuit court erred in failing to grant a directed verdict because of a failure of the State to comply with the provisions of S.C. Code Ann. Section 56-5-2953 requiring videotaping from the activation of blue lights through arrest.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Harley L. Landis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3904
Heard November 9, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  6, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this criminal action, 
  Harley L. Landis (Landis) appeals his conviction for driving under the influence 
  (DUI).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On November 27, 2000, South Carolina 
  Highway Patrol Trooper David Davis (Trooper Davis) observed a vehicle driven 
  by Landis headed northbound on Interstate 85.Â  Landis was weaving and straddling 
  the center lane.Â  A State Transport Police Officer had taken a position immediately 
  behind Landisâ€™ vehicle.Â  The State Transport Police Officer initiated blue lights 
  and pulled Landis over to the side of the interstate.Â  Trooper Davis then pulled 
  behind the Transport Police Officer.Â  After the Transport Officer removed Landis 
  from his car, Trooper Davis performed the field sobriety test, determined Landis 
  was impaired, and placed him under arrest for DUI.Â  There was no videotape of 
  the incident site because Trooper Davisâ€™ videotape machine was inoperable at 
  the time of Landisâ€™ arrest.Â Â  
Landis was convicted by a magistrateâ€™s 
  court jury and fined $637.Â  On appeal, the circuit court affirmed the conviction 
  and sentence of Landis.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal appeals from magistrate or municipal 
  court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but 
  instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception.â€Â  
  State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 
  2001); accord Rogers v. State, 358 S.C. 266, 594 S.E.2d 278 (2004) 
  (quoting City of Landrum v. Sarratt, 352 S.C. 139, 141, 572 S.E.2d 476, 
  477 (Ct. App. 2002)).Â  In criminal cases, the court of appeals sits to review 
  errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless 
  clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); 
  State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 199 S.E.2d 61 (1973); State v. Bowie, 
  360 S.C. 210, 600 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Landis contends the circuit court erred in affirming 
  his conviction because the State failed to comply with the mandatory provisions 
  of section 56-5-2953 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2001) requiring videotaping 
  at the incident site.Â  Landis presents two arguments supporting his position.Â  
  First, he argues the circuit court erred in finding that Trooper Davis constituted 
  the arresting officer as contemplated by section 56-5-2953.Â  Second, Landis 
  alleges the circuit court erred in finding that the affidavit requirement of 
  section 56-5-2953(B) was satisfied by the State.Â  We disagree and affirm.
The cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the legislative intent whenever possible.Â  State 
  v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing State 
  v. Baucom, 340 S.C. 339, 531 S.E.2d 922 (2000)).Â  All rules of statutory 
  construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail 
  if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must 
  be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  State 
  v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1999) cert. denied 
  as improvidently granted, State v. Hudson, 346 S.C. 139, 551 S.E.2d 
  253 (2001).Â  The determination of legislative intent is a matter of law.Â  Hudson, 
  336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577.Â Â Â  
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained 
  primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  Morgan at 366, 547 
  S.E.2d at 206.Â  Words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without 
  resorting to subtle or forced construction which limits or expands the statuteâ€™s 
  operation.Â  Id.Â  When faced with an undefined statutory term, the court 
  must interpret the term in accord with its usual and customary meaning.Â  Id.Â  
  This Court must apply clear and unambiguous terms of a statute according to 
  their literal meaning.Â  State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 403 S.E.2d 660 
  (1991).Â  We should consider, not merely the language of the particular clause 
  being construed, but the word and its meaning in conjunction with the purpose 
  of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  Whitner v. State, 328 
  S.C. 1, 492 S.E.2d 777 (1997).Â Â  The terms must be construed in context and 
  their meaning determined by looking at the other terms used in the statue.Â  
  Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577.Â Â Â  
When a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, 
  and conveys clear and definite meaning, there is no occasion for employing rules 
  of statutory interpretation and a court has no right to look for or impose another 
  meaning.Â  City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 486 S.E.2d 492 (Ct. 
  App. 1997).Â  The statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and 
  fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.Â  
  Id.Â  Any ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, 
  equitable, and beneficial operation of the law.Â  Id.; City of Sumter 
  Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 
  894 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
I.Â  Arresting Officer
Landis asserts the State Transport Police Officerâ€”not Trooper 
  Davisâ€”was the arresting officer at the incident site.Â  Consequently, Landis 
  contends that any effort by the State to comply with the statutory requirements 
  of section 56-5-2953 must be met by the State Transport Officer as the arresting 
  officer.Â  The circuit court found Trooper Davis, not the State Transport Officer, 
  was the arresting officer pursuant to section 56-5-2953.Â  We agree.Â  
Section 56-7-2953 provides, in pertinent part:

(A)Â  A person who violates Section 56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, 
  or 56-5-2945 must have his conduct at the incident site and the breath test 
  site videotaped.
Â (1)Â  The videotaping at the incident site must:
  
(a)Â  begin not later than the activation of the officerâ€™s 
  blue lights and conclude after the arrest of the person for a violation of Section 
  56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, or a probable cause determination that the person violated 
  Section 56-5-2945 . . . .
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . 

(B)Â  . . . .Â  Failure by the arresting officer 
  to produce the videotapes required by this section is not alone a ground 
  for dismissal of any charge made pursuant to Section 56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, 
  or 56-5-2945 if the arresting officer submits a sworn affidavit . . . 
  . 

S.C. Code Ann. (Supp. 2001) (emphasis added).
The statute does not define â€œarresting officer.â€Â  
  Consequently, we must interpret this phrase in accord with its usual and customary 
  meaning.Â  See City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 486 S.E.2d 
  492 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating when legislature elects not to define a term in 
  a statute, courts will interpret term in accord with its usual and customary 
  meaning).Â Â  
Pellucidly, the record supports the finding that Trooper 
  Davis was the â€œarresting officerâ€ as that phrase is ordinarily understood.Â  
  Trooper Davis personally observed Landisâ€™ driving prior to the traffic stop.Â  
  He arrived at the scene simultaneously with the State Transport Officer.Â  Trooper 
  Davis pulled in directly behind the Transport Officer and approached just after 
  Landis had been removed from his vehicle.Â  Moreover, Trooper Davis conducted 
  the field sobriety test, determined Landis was impaired, and placed him under 
  arrest for DUI.Â  
In State v. Garvin, 341 S.C. 122, 533 S.E.2d 591 (Ct. 
  App. 2000), we noted:Â  

The term â€œarrestâ€ has a technical meaning, applicable in 
  legal proceedings.Â  It implies that a person is thereby restrained of his liberty 
  by some officer or agent of the law, armed with lawful process, authorizing 
  and requiring the arrest to be made.Â  It is intended to serve, and does serve, 
  the end of bringing the person arrested personally within the custody and control 
  of the law, for the purpose specified in, or contemplated by, the process.Â  


Id. at 126-27, 533 S.E.2d at 593 (quoting State 
  v. Leak, 11 N.C.App. 344, 181 S.E.2d 224 (1971)).Â  Trooper Davis â€œrestrained 
  [Landis] of his libertyâ€ and brought him â€œwithin the custody and control of 
  the law.â€Â  Therefore, we hold that the State Transport Officer merely assisted 
  in facilitating the traffic stop.Â  Trooper Davis was the arresting officer responsible 
  for meeting the statutory videotaping requirements of section 56-5-2953(A).Â  

II.Â  Videotaping 
  Requirements
Landis argues the State failed to comply with the videotape 
  requirements of the incident scene contained in section 56-5-2953(A) of the 
  South Carolina Code (Supp. 2001).Â  Specifically, Landis contends the circuit 
  court erred in affirming his conviction because the affidavit prepared by Trooper 
  Davis was not entered into evidence at trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 56-5-2953(A) provides that a person charged with 
  driving under the influence shall have â€œhis conduct at the incident site and 
  the breath test site videotaped.â€Â  Videotaping at the incident site must begin 
  not later than the activation of the officerâ€™s blue lights and conclude after 
  the arrest of the person.Â  S.C. Code Ann. section 56-5-2953(A)(1)(a) (Supp. 
  2001).Â  While Trooper Davis was unable to videotape the arrest due to the inoperable 
  condition of his videotape equipment, section 56-5-2953(B) clearly envisions 
  instances where videotape might not be available at the incident site and provides:

Nothing in this section may be construed as prohibiting 
  the introduction of other evidence in the trial of a violation of Section 56-5-2930, 
  56-5-2933, or 56-5-2945. Failure by the arresting officer to produce the 
  videotapes required by this section is not alone a ground for dismissal of any 
  charge made pursuant to Section 56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, or 56-5-2945 if 
  the arresting officer submits a sworn affidavit certifying that the videotape 
  equipment at the time of the arrest, probable cause determination, or breath 
  test device was in an inoperable condition, stating reasonable efforts have 
  been made to maintain the equipment in an operable condition, and certifying 
  that there was no other operable breath test facility available in the county 
  or, in the alternative, submits a sworn affidavit certifying that it was physically 
  impossible to produce the videotape because the person needed emergency medical 
  treatment, or exigent circumstances existed. Further, in circumstances including, 
  but not limited to, road blocks, traffic accident investigations, and citizensâ€™ 
  arrests, where an arrest has been made and the videotaping equipment has not 
  been activated by blue lights, the failure by the arresting officer to produce 
  the videotapes required by this section is not alone a ground for dismissal. 
  However, as soon as videotaping is practicable in these circumstances, videotaping 
  must begin and conform with the provisions of this section. Nothing in this 
  section prohibits the court from considering any other valid reason for the 
  failure to produce the videotape based upon the totality of the circumstances; 
  nor do the provisions of this section prohibit the person from offering evidence 
  relating to the arresting law enforcement officer's failure to produce the videotape.

S.C. Code Ann. section 56-5-2953(B) (Supp. 2001) (emphasis 
  added).Â  
In accordance with section 56-5-2953(B), Trooper 
  Davis prepared a sworn affidavit certifying that his videotape equipment was 
  inoperable at the time of the arrest despite reasonable efforts to repair the 
  equipment.Â  Trooper Davis testified at trial to the existence of the affidavit:

Q:Â  Was your car equipped with video at this time?
A:Â  It was, but it was inoperable at the time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q:Â  And pursuant to section [56-5-2953] did you sign 
  an affidavit for failure to produce videotape indicating that your videotaping 
  machine was inoperable?
A:Â  Yes, I did.

Moreover, Landisâ€™ counsel was provided a copy of Trooper 
  Davisâ€™ affidavit. 

Counsel for Landis:Â  I havenâ€™t seen any Affidavit.Â  
  Iâ€™m assuming you will be admitting it.
State:Â  I thought you were given a copy.
Counsel:Â  I donâ€™t think so.
State:Â  That was done today.
Counsel:Â  Oh, Okay.
     . . . .Â 
Counsel:Â  Thatâ€™s fine.Â  I just needed to see it.Â 

Indeed, Landis used the affidavit during cross-examination 
  of Trooper Davis.Â  And during the motion hearing, Landisâ€™ counsel requested 
  to enter the affidavit into evidence but decided to wait until trial to admit 
  the document.Â  

   Counsel for Landis:Â  Can we put the Affidavit 
  in as an exhibit?
 The Court:Â  Sure.        
  State:Â  If counsel wants to put the Affidavit into 
  evidence in his trial, then (inaudible)
  Counsel:Â  I think weâ€™re entitled to introduce that 
  at this time for the record on our motion.Â  It is not something thatâ€”
   State:Â  You want to introduce it for purposes 
  in the motion?
  Counsel:Â  Well, we need it for purposes of the motion, 
  but I guess we canâ€”weâ€™ll do it at trial.Â  Weâ€™ll hang on to it and just go ahead 
  and admit it during the trial itself.

In further refutation of Landisâ€™ argument, the 
  record discloses that not only was Landisâ€™ counsel in possession of Trooper 
  Davisâ€™ affidavit, but the court accepted counselâ€™s request to place the affidavit 
  into evidence.Â  Landisâ€™ counsel then decided not to enter the affidavit after 
  the court had given him permission to do so.Â  Although the statute does not 
  specify to whom the arresting officer should submit the affidavit, we hold that 
  whether the affidavit has been submitted is not an issue when it has undisputedly 
  been prepared and is in defense counselâ€™s possession at trial.Â  
Based on the cited testimony and Trooper Davisâ€™ affidavit, 
  we hold the statutory requirements of section 56-5-2953(B) were satisfied. 
CONCLUSION
Therefore, the order of the circuit court is hereby
AFFIRMED.
 STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.
