title: Paul Davis Systems v. Deepwater
description: Paul Davis Systems, Inc. sought to foreclose on a mechanic's lien against Deepwater of Hilton Head.  The trial judge directed Deepwater's property be sold to satisfy the mechanic's lien, but subsequently granted Deepwater's motion for relief from judgment and dismissed Deepwater as a party.  We reverse, finding the trial judge erred in (1) granting Deepwater relief from judgment under Rule 60(b) because Deepwater's failure to interpose its contract defense in its answer does not amount to "mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect" warranting relief under Rule 60(b), and (2) ruling on defenses readily available to Deepwater prior to trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Paul Davis Systems, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Deepwater of Hilton Head, LLC, Columbia Construction Services Company, 
        Inc., and Andrew Batten, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 3905
Heard September 16, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  6, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Sean Michael Bolchoz and James O. Hale, both of Hilton Head 
  Island, for Appellant.
Edward E. Bullard and John R.C. Bowen, both of Hilton Head Island; and Robert 
  C. Calamari and William Jerad Rissler, both of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Paul Davis Systems, 
  Inc. (â€œDavisâ€) sought to foreclose on a mechanicâ€™s lien against Deepwater of 
  Hilton Head (â€œDeepwaterâ€).Â  The trial judge directed Deepwaterâ€™s property be 
  sold to satisfy the mechanicâ€™s lien, but subsequently granted Deepwaterâ€™s motion 
  for relief from judgment and dismissed Deepwater as a party.Â  Davis asserts 
  the trial court erred in (1) granting Deepwaterâ€™s motion for relief from judgment 
  and (2) ruling upon defenses offered through a post-trial motion.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Pursuant to a work authorization order 
  entered into on April 6, 1999, Davis agreed to perform certain subcontracting 
  services for Columbia Construction Services (â€œColumbiaâ€), a general contractor, 
  to make improvements to real property owned by Deepwater.Â  Though Deepwater 
  owned the property being renovated, Columbia had been retained as the projectâ€™s 
  general contractor by C.A. Muer Corporation (â€œMuerâ€).Â  Muer was leasing the 
  property from Deepwater for use as a seafood restaurant.Â Â  
At some point during the project, a dispute 
  arose between Davis and Columbia regarding payment for labor. Davis served a 
  notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien on Deepwater on September 28, 1999, 
  followed by service of a summons and complaint on October 4, 1999.Â  Davisâ€™s 
  complaint asserted a cause of action against Columbia for breach of contract 
  in which Davis sought damages of $37,721.00, and a separate claim for foreclosure 
  of a mechanicâ€™s lien against Deepwaterâ€™s real property.Â  Neither the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien nor the complaint was served on Muer or named Muer as a party.Â  However, 
  Deepwater provided a copy of the complaint to Muer and directed Muer to release 
  Deepwaterâ€™s property from the lien.Â  
In order to release the property from 
  the lien, Columbia, at Muerâ€™s request, posted a mechanicâ€™s lien bond dated October 
  28, 1999 in the amount of one and one-third times the amount claimed by Davis.Â  
  Deepwater received a copy of a letter from Columbiaâ€™s attorney, Ann Marscher, 
  to Davisâ€™s attorney referencing attached unsigned copies of a discharge of mechanicâ€™s 
  lien, cancellation of lis pendens, and a stipulation of dismissal 
  [1]  between Columbia and Davis and a copy of the bond to discharge the 
  construction lien filed with the Beaufort County Register of Deeds. 
Although Columbia answered Davisâ€™s complaint 
  by filing a general denial, Deepwater failed to respond to the complaint.Â  As 
  a consequence, Davis moved for an order of default against Deepwater and for 
  release of the bond.Â  Deepwater responded through attorney Marscher by filing 
  an answer and opposing Davisâ€™s default motion.Â  Although default had not been 
  entered against Deepwater at this point, Deepwater styled this motion as a motion 
  to set aside default based on Rule 55 and 60(b), arguing mistake, inadvertence, 
  or excusable neglect on the part of attorney Marscher. Marscher stated in her 
  affidavit that Deepwater failed to file an answer based on the mistaken belief 
  that Deepwater had been discharged upon the filing of the bond and based on 
  the mistaken impression that Davisâ€™s counsel would consent to the dismissal 
  of Deepwater. Â By order entered April 3, 2000, the trial court denied 
  Davisâ€™s motion for default and allowed Deepwater to answer as previously filed. 
  Â A subsequent answer to Davisâ€™s second amended complaint filed on behalf 
  of all defendants, including Deepwater, added as a defense that Deepwaterâ€™s 
  property had been discharged from the suit by the posting of the surety bond.Â  

The matter proceeded to a bench trial, and the judge entered an order awarding 
  Davis a total of $54,168.89 on the breach of contract claim.Â  Because the courtâ€™s 
  order made no mention of the mechanicâ€™s lien, Davis filed a motion to amend, 
  asking the court to authorize foreclosure on the lien against Deepwaterâ€™s property.Â  
  The trial judge granted the motion through an order invalidating the surety 
  bond, finding that Deepwater failed to comply with the conditions of South Carolina 
  Code section 29-5-110 (Supp. 2003) for the discharge of a lien from real property 
  by the posting of a bond because the surety that executed the bond was not licensed 
  to do business in South Carolina.Â  The order also directed Deepwaterâ€™s property 
  be sold to satisfy Davisâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
On May 30, 2002, with the scheduled foreclosure 
  sale of its property mere days away, Deepwater filed an emergency motion asking 
  for relief from the judgment pursuant to Rule 60, SCRCP. [2] Â  Deepwater argued that it should be relieved 
  from the order entitling Davis to foreclose on the lien against its property 
  based on mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect pursuant to Rule 
  60(b)(1).Â  Deepwater asserted that it neither received nor was served with any 
  papers to put it on notice that an action was pending against it and never engaged 
  counsel because it reasonably relied on the copy of the letter from Marscher 
  to Davisâ€™s attorney referencing the discharge of mechanicâ€™s lien, cancellation 
  of lis pendens, stipulation of dismissal, and surety bond.Â  Deepwater further 
  argued it was denied an opportunity to represent its interests during the bench 
  trial because it reasonably believed it had been dismissed from the suit by 
  the surety bond filed by Columbia.Â  Deepwater also introduced its lease with 
  Muer and argued that because it was Muer rather than Deepwater that entered 
  into the construction contract with Columbia, Davisâ€™s lien should encumber Muerâ€™s 
  leasehold interest rather than the real property owned by Deepwater. 
By order entered February 5, 2003, the 
  trial judge concluded the lack of a contractual relationship between Deepwater 
  and Davis precluded Davis from encumbering Deepwaterâ€™s real property with a 
  valid mechanicâ€™s lien. Â Â Having so concluded, the court dismissed Deepwater 
  from the suit and released its property from Davisâ€™s lien.Â  The court set aside 
  the previous award of attorneyâ€™s fees in Davisâ€™s favor based on the assertion 
  of the lien and permitted Deepwater to apply for costs and attorneyâ€™s fees incurred 
  in defending against Davisâ€™s lien.Â  Davis appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Davis contends the trial judge erred in 
  granting Deepwater relief based on excusable neglect and in considering and 
  ruling upon defenses available to Deepwater prior to trial but asserted only 
  by post-trial motion.Â  Deepwater alleges it was entitled to relief from the 
  judgment under Rule 60(b)(1) because although its interests were represented 
  by attorney Marscher, it was not aware that it was represented, never engaged 
  counsel, and reasonably believed it had been discharged from the lien.Â Â  We 
  disagree with Deepwater and reverse the decision of the trial judge.
Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP, allows 
  a party to seek relief from a final judgment or order on the grounds of â€œmistake, 
  inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.â€Â  Relief under this section lies 
  within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be reversed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Thompson v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 
  116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 902-03 (1989).Â  â€œSuch an abuse arises when the judge 
  issuing the order was controlled by an error of law or when the order, based 
  upon factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id. at 119, 
  382 S.E.2d at 903.Â  It is incumbent upon the party seeking relief pursuant to 
  Rule 60(b)(1) to show the applicability of one of the qualifying grounds.Â  See 
  Williams v. Ray, 232 S.C. 373, 381, 102 S.E.2d 368, 371 (1958) (referencing 
  the statutory relief from judgment for mistake, inadvertence, surprise or excusable 
  neglect available prior to the adoption of the South Carolina Rules of Civil 
  Procedure).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
As an initial matter, we find 
  Deepwaterâ€™s belief that it had been discharged from the lien based on Marscherâ€™s 
  letter to Davisâ€™s attorney was unreasonable and does not amount to â€œmistake, 
  inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect,â€ warranting relief under Rule 
  60(b), SCRCP.Â Â  As we have long held, â€œa party has a duty to monitor the progress 
  of his case.â€Â  Hill v. Dotts, 345 S.C. 304, 310, 547 S.E.2d 894, 897 
  (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Goodson v. Am. Bankers Ins. Co., 295 S.C. 400, 
  403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (Ct. App. 1988)).Â  We note that Deepwater was not the 
  intended recipient of the letter, and the copies of the discharge of mechanics 
  lien, cancellation of lis pendens, and stipulation of dismissal to which the 
  letter referred had not been executed and were unsigned.Â  In addition, the bond 
  to discharge the construction lien referenced in the letter was later determined 
  to be invalid because it did not comply with the statutory prerequisites.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-110 (Supp. 2003).
Moreover, we agree with 
  Davis that the trial judge erred in ruling on Deepwaterâ€™s defenses asserted 
  in the Rule 60(b) motion, which were available to Deepwater prior to trial.Â  
  See Greenville Income Partners v. Holman, 308 S.C. 105, 107, 417 
  S.E.2d 107, 108 (Ct. App. 1992) (stating that the failure of an attorney to 
  interpose available defenses does not amount to the kind of mistake, surprise, 
  inadvertence, and excusable neglect contemplated by Rule 60(b)); see 
  also Mitchell Supply Co. v. Gaffney, 297 S.C. 160, 163-64, 375 
  S.E.2d 321, 323 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œ[T]he neglect of the attorney is the neglect 
  of the client, and . . . no mistake, inadvertence or neglect attributable to 
  an attorney can be successfully used as a ground for relief unless it would 
  have been excusable if attributable to the client.â€).Â  But see 
  Graham v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442, 452, 248 S.E.2d 594, 599 (1978) 
  (stating that this general rule is not applied where there has been a willful 
  and unilateral abandonment of the client by counsel).
Deepwater attempts to circumvent the tenet 
  that Rule 60(b) relief is not available based on the failure of an attorney 
  to assert available defenses by explaining that it was unaware that Marscher 
  filed a motion and answer on its behalf.Â  However, whether Deepwater knew that 
  its interests were represented by Marscher is of little import considering Deepwaterâ€™s 
  unreasonable belief that it had been discharged from the case and its failure 
  to monitor the progress of the case.Â  See Goodson, 295 S.C. at 
  403, 368 S.E.2d at 689.Â  This is not a case of willful and unilateral abandonment 
  of the client by counsel in which we could refuse to apply the general rule 
  that the neglect of an attorney is the neglect of a client.Â  Cf. Graham, 
  272 S.C. at 452, 248 S.E.2d at 599 (finding the attorneyâ€™s withdrawal from the 
  case at a crucial stage without reasonable notice to the client to be an action 
  of willful abandonment and thus not attributable to the client).Â  Rather, there 
  is ample evidence that Marscher represented Deepwaterâ€™s interests throughout 
  the litigation, including filing a motion opposing default and an answer on 
  behalf of Deepwater. Â Â 
We find Marscherâ€™s failure to 
  interpose Deepwaterâ€™s contract defense at the time she answered on behalf of 
  Deepwater does not amount to â€œmistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable 
  neglectâ€ warranting relief under Rule 60(b).Â  Further, we find Marscherâ€™s failure 
  attributable to Deepwater.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial judge erred in granting 
  Deepwater relief from judgment under Rule 60(b) and ruling on defenses readily 
  available to Deepwater prior to trial.
REVERSED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Copies of the discharge of mechanicâ€™s lien, cancellation 
    of lis pendens, and stipulation of dismissal do not appear in the record on 
    appeal. 

 
   
    [2]  Deepwaterâ€™s motion was captioned â€œNotice of Emergency Motion and 
    Emergency Motion for Stay and for Alternate Forms of Relief Pursuant to SCRCP 
    Rules 17, 19, 21, 59, 60, 62, 67 and Memorandum in Support of Motion.â€Â Â  The 
    motion ruled upon by the trial judge and relevant to this appeal is Deepwaterâ€™s 
    Rule 60(b) motion for relief from final judgment.Â

title: State v. James
description: Appellant appeals his convictions for possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine and possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine within proximity of a school.  He contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict given the State failed to produce substantial circumstantial evidence of the intent element.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Christopher L. James, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Edgefield County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3906
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed December 20, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Appellate 
  Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry 
  Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant 
  Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald 
  V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â Â Â Â  Christopher James appeals his convictions for possession 
  with intent to distribute crack cocaine and possession with intent to distribute 
  crack cocaine within proximity of a school.Â  He contends the trial court erred 
  in denying his motion for a directed verdict given the State failed to produce 
  substantial circumstantial evidence of the intent element.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On April 15, 2000, Corporal Tony Taylor, employed with the 
  Johnston Police Department, was patrolling the town when he observed James holding 
  an open container of beer.Â  Because James was in violation of the townâ€™s open 
  container ordinance, Taylor stopped his vehicle and approached James.Â  Taylor 
  then instructed James to put his hands on the patrol car so that he could conduct 
  a pat down for weapons.Â  During the pat down, Taylor felt something in Jamesâ€™s 
  left front pocket.Â  When questioned about the object, Taylor responded, â€œOh, 
  thatâ€™s my rag.â€Â  As James pulled the rag out of his pocket, Taylor observed 
  two small â€œzip-lockâ€ bags fall to the ground.Â  According to Taylor, one 
  bag was empty and the other bag contained what he believed to be eight to ten 
  rocks of crack cocaine.Â  A struggle ensued when both James and Taylor 
  reached for the bags.Â  James then broke free and absconded with the bag containing 
  the substance.Â  Unable to apprehend James at that time, Taylor returned to the 
  scene and retrieved the empty bag.Â  Drug analysis of the bag revealed that it 
  contained crack cocaine; however, there was no weight assigned to the substance 
  because it was essentially residue.Â  The second bag was never recovered.Â Â Â  

An Edgefield County grand jury indicted James for resisting arrest, possession 
  with intent to distribute crack cocaine, and possession with intent to distribute 
  crack cocaine within proximity of a school.
At trial, Taylor recounted the incident for the jury.Â  He also testified extensively 
  as to why James was charged with possession with intent to distribute as opposed 
  to simple possession of crack cocaine.Â  For several reasons, Taylor believed 
  James intended to sell the crack cocaine rather than use it for his personal 
  consumption.Â  Taylor testified that dealers normally carry a large number of 
  crack cocaine rocks in a single bag.Â  He also stated that a dealer usually sells 
  an entire bag of crack cocaine before selling from other bags.Â  In contrast, 
  Taylor claimed that a crack cocaine addict normally carries only one rock of 
  crack cocaine.Â  Additionally, he testified an addict has a distinct, unhealthy 
  physical appearance.Â  Because James appeared in good health, had an empty bag 
  containing crack cocaine residue, and a bag full of what appeared to be crack 
  cocaine rocks, Taylor concluded that James intended to sell the crack cocaine.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   

James did not testify at trial.Â  Two witnesses testified on Jamesâ€™s behalf.Â  
  Naomi Coppinger, the mother of Jamesâ€™s children, testified that James was employed 
  and supported his family.Â  Shelby Still, an acquaintance of James, testified 
  she witnessed from her doorway the incident involving James and Taylor.Â  
  Although Still corroborated most of Taylorâ€™s account of the incident, she 
  testified that she did not see any bags of drugs fall out of Jamesâ€™s pocket 
  when he pulled out the rag.Â  She also characterized the area as â€œdrug-infested,â€ 
  and acknowledged that bags containing drugs may have been on the ground.Â Â  
  
The jury convicted James of resisting arrest, possession with intent to distribute 
  crack cocaine, and possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine within 
  proximity of a school.Â  The trial court sentenced James to time served for the 
  resisting arrest charge and ten years imprisonment for each of the drug charges.Â  
  The sentences were to be served concurrently.Â  James appeals.
DISCUSSION
James argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for 
  a directed verdict as to the drug charges.Â  He contends the State failed to 
  produce substantial circumstantial evidence that he possessed crack cocaine 
  with intent to distribute.Â  In conjunction with this contention, James asserts 
  the courtâ€™s failure to direct a verdict violated his Fourteenth Amendment right 
  to due process because the evidence was not sufficient to convince a rational 
  trier of fact that he was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
At trial, James moved for a directed verdict after the State 
  rested and at the close of the evidence.Â  In each of these motions, James 
  argued there was insufficient evidence to support the elements of the possession 
  with intent to distribute charges.Â  The court denied these motions.Â  Although 
  the court acknowledged there was no evidence as to the weight of the crack cocaine, 
  it found the State had presented circumstantial evidence to support the charges.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   

In ruling on a motion for directed verdict in a criminal case, 
  a trial court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  
  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 321, 555 S.E.2d 402, 404 (2001).Â  The 
  trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not 
  its weight.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002).Â  
  â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce 
  evidence of the offense charged.â€Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 
  544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  Furthermore, the court should not refuse to grant 
  the directed verdict motion when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that 
  the accused is guilty.Â  State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 409, 535 S.E.2d 
  126, 127 (2000).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this court must 
  view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable 
  to the State.Â  State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 
  (1999).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence 
  reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case 
  was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 
  349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).
Section 44-53-375(B) of the South Carolina Code â€œcreates a 
  permissive inference that possession of more than one gram of crack cocaine 
  constitutes possession with intent to distribute.Â  However, a conviction of 
  possession with intent to distribute does not hinge upon the amount involved.Â  
  Furthermore, the statute does not mandate a reverse inference or presumption 
  for amounts less than one gram.â€Â  State v. Robinson, 344 S.C. 220, 223, 
  543 S.E.2d 249, 250 (Ct. App. 2001) (citations omitted); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(B) 
  (2002).Â  Possession of any amount of controlled substance coupled with sufficient 
  indicia of intent to distribute will support a conviction for possession with 
  intent to distribute.Â  Matthews v. State, 300 S.C. 238, 239, 387 S.E.2d 
  258, 259 (1990).
As a threshold matter, the State asserts James did not properly 
  preserve this issue for appellate review.Â  Specifically, the State contends 
  James did not explicitly argue the State failed to produce â€œsubstantial circumstantial 
  evidence that he possessed cocaine with intent to distribute.â€
We agree with the Stateâ€™s assertion with respect to Jamesâ€™s 
  Fourteenth Amendment argument.Â  At trial, James moved to exclude the crack cocaine 
  evidence on the ground the weapons pat down and subsequent seizure of the drugs 
  violated his Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.Â  In a separate and subsequent 
  argument, James moved for a directed verdict without referencing the Fourteenth 
  Amendment.Â  Even if Jamesâ€™s post-verdict motion could be construed to encompass 
  a Fourteenth Amendment challenge regarding the sufficiency of the evidence, 
  such an argument was untimely and did not preserve the argument for our review.Â  
  See Humbert v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 338, 548 S.E.2d 
  862, 865, 866 (2001) (stating issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial 
  court will not be considered on appeal); State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 
  113, 485 S.E.2d 360, 363 (1997) (recognizing party may not argue one ground 
  at trial and another on appeal); State v. Kennerly, 331 S.C. 442, 455, 
  503 S.E.2d 214, 221 (Ct. App. 1998), affâ€™d, 337 S.C. 617, 524 S.E.2d 
  837 (1999) (â€œ[I]ssues not raised to the trial court in support of the directed 
  verdict motion are not preserved for appellate review.â€).
Despite the failure to preserve the Fourteenth Amendment issue, 
  we find James properly raised the sufficiency of the evidence argument to the 
  trial court.Â  Although James did not use the term â€œsubstantial circumstantial 
  evidenceâ€ in his motion for a directed verdict, he argued there was insufficient 
  evidence to support the elements of the charge of possession with intent to 
  distribute.Â  Moreover, it is apparent from the trial courtâ€™s ruling that this 
  ground was the basis for the motion.Â  Significantly, the court informed the 
  parties that it would instruct the jury â€œthat they have to find the intent to 
  distribute has been proven by the State beyond a reasonable doubt, and there 
  would be a lesser included offense of possession of crack cocaine.â€Â  Thus, 
  we find the argument is properly before this court.Â  Cf. State v. 
  Russell, 345 S.C. 128, 132, 546 S.E.2d 202, 204 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding 
  argument that defendant was entitled to a directed verdict on the ground the 
  State failed to establish the corpus deliciti of DUI was preserved 
  even though the defendant did not use the exact words where the ground for the 
  motion was apparent from a review of the record).
We now analyze the merits of Jamesâ€™s appeal.Â  Clearly, the 
  evidence was sufficient to prove James possessed crack cocaine.Â  The State contends 
  it proved the intent to distribute element based on Officer Taylorâ€™s testimony.Â  
  James was observed in an area known for â€œhigh crimeâ€ and â€œhigh-narcotics trafficking.â€Â  
  He had in his possession one â€œzip-lockâ€ bag bulging with what appeared to be 
  eight to ten crack cocaine rocks and one empty â€œzip-lockâ€ bag that tested positive 
  for crack cocaine residue.Â  Officer Taylor testified dealers normally carry 
  a large number of crack cocaine rocks and sell from one â€œzip-lockâ€ bag before 
  selling from other bags.Â  In contrast, a crack cocaine addict usually carries 
  only one rock of crack.Â  Furthermore, unlike an addict, James appeared healthy.Â  
  Based on these characteristics, Officer Taylor believed James intended to sell 
  the crack cocaine because he fit the profile of a drug dealer as opposed to 
  a drug user or addict.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, 
  as we are required to do, we find this evidence was insufficient to submit to 
  the jury the possession with intent to distribute charges.Â  In doing so, we 
  must distinguish the instant case from two recent decisions of this court, Cherry 
  and Robinson, which at least facially appear to be dispositive.Â  State 
  v. Cherry, 348 S.C. 281, 559 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2001) (en banc), 
  affâ€™d in result, Op. No. 25902 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Nov. 29, 2004) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 46 at 24), and State v. Robinson, 344 S.C. 220, 543 S.E.2d 
  249 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
In Cherry, the defendant was a passenger in a vehicle 
  stopped for a traffic violation.Â  When an officer searched Cherry for weapons, 
  he discovered a small bag containing approximately eight rocks of crack cocaine 
  in his watch pocket.Â  He also seized $322 in cash from Cherry.Â  Cherry was convicted 
  of possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine.Â  As one of the issues 
  raised on appeal, Cherry challenged the trial courtâ€™s failure to grant his motion 
  for a directed verdict.Â  Because there was no evidence that he intended to distribute 
  the crack cocaine, Cherry asserted the charge should not have been submitted 
  to the jury.Â  This court, in a divided en banc decision, affirmed 
  Cherryâ€™s conviction.Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the 
  State without weighing it, the majority opinion found the following evidence 
  justified the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny Cherryâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict:Â  (1) Cherry was arrested in high crime area known for violence and 
  drug activity; (2) Cherry had in his possession a small bag containing eight 
  rocks of crack cocaine; (3) he had no drug paraphernalia with him indicating 
  the crack cocaine was for his personal consumption; (4) he had $322 in cash, 
  in mostly twenty dollar bills; and (5) a single rock of crack cocaine typically 
  sold for twenty dollars.Â  Cherry, 348 S.C. at 285, 559 S.E.2d at 299.
In Robinson, law enforcement observed Robinson enter 
  a business that was the focal point of a six-month drug investigation.Â  When 
  Robinson left the establishment, an officer approached him.Â  Robinson charged 
  the officer and threw his hand up in the air.Â  The officer saw a black plastic 
  bag fly from Robinsonâ€™s hand.Â  The bag contained seven rocks of crack cocaine 
  with an assigned weight of 0.9 grams.Â  As a result, Robinson was charged with 
  possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine and a related proximity charge.Â  
  Because the amount of crack cocaine was less than the statutory amount triggering 
  the permissible inference of intent to distribute, the State relied solely on 
  expert testimony from officers regarding the distinction between a drug dealer 
  and a user of crack cocaine.Â  The officers testified that a user would normally 
  not have more than one or two rocks in his possession.Â  Additionally, one officer 
  testified that he would expect that a dealer would have crack cocaine packaged 
  as it was by Robinson.Â  Based on this testimony, we found there was sufficient 
  evidence of Robinsonâ€™s intent to distribute to withstand a motion for a directed 
  verdict.Â  Robinson, 344 S.C. at 224, 543 S.E.2d at 250.
Analyzing the facts of this case, we conclude the indicia of 
  intent relied upon by the State is considerably weaker than that presented in 
  either Cherry or Robinson and, thus, insufficient to support the 
  charged offenses.Â  Although James was observed in a â€œhigh-narcotics traffickingâ€ 
  area, he was initially detained for an open container violation in an area near 
  his home.Â  In contrast to Robinson, there was no testimony that James 
  was engaged in a drug transaction or that he was under surveillance for dealing 
  drugs.Â  There was, however, testimony that James was employed and supported 
  his family.Â  Furthermore, unlike the defendant in Cherry, James did not 
  have large amounts of cash, but instead, only had $37 on his person.Â  As to 
  the amount of crack cocaine possessed by James, the evidence was speculative.Â  
  The â€œbulgingâ€ bag of crack cocaine, which the State primarily relied on to establish 
  the intent element, was never recovered for evidentiary testing as in Robinson 
  and Cherry.Â  Officer Taylor also was not entirely clear as to how many 
  rocks, of what he believed to be crack cocaine, were contained in the bag.Â  
  He admitted that he only saw the bag briefly on the ground before the struggle 
  ensued with James.Â  Finally, Jamesâ€™s healthy appearance was not conclusive as 
  to whether he was a drug dealer.Â  Instead, it could also have raised the inference 
  that he was not a long-term user of crack cocaine.Â  Based on the foregoing, 
  we find the entirely circumstantial evidence in this case was not substantial 
  and merely raised a suspicion that James intended to distribute crack cocaine.Â  
  Therefore, we hold the trial judge erred in failing to direct a verdict on the 
  possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine charge as well as the related 
  proximity charge.Â  
Accordingly, Jamesâ€™s convictions and sentences are
REVERSED. [1] 
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â Â  We recognize that our supreme court has recently 
    ruled that when a conviction is reversed due to insufficient evidence, an 
    appellate court may remand the case for sentencing on the lesser-included 
    offense.Â Â  We, however, choose not to do so in this case given the State has 
    not made such a request.Â  Moreover, although the trial court indicated it 
    would charge the jury on the lesser-included offense of possession of crack 
    cocaine, the courtâ€™s charge to the jury was not included as part of the record 
    on appeal.Â  Thus, it is unclear whether the jury considered the lesser-included 
    offense.Â  See State v. Brown, 360 S.C. 581, 597-98, 602 S.E.2d 
    392, 401 (2004) (holding that when a conviction is reversed due to insufficient 
    evidence, an appellate court will consider remanding a case for sentencing 
    on a lesser-included offense only when:Â  (1) the evidence adduced at trial 
    fails to support one or more elements of the crime of which appellant was 
    convicted; (2) the jury was explicitly instructed it could find the defendant 
    guilty of the lesser-included offense and was properly instructed on the elements 
    of that offense; (3) the record on appeal contains sufficient evidence supporting 
    each element of the lesser-included offense; (4) the State seeks a sentencing 
    remand on appeal; (5) the defendant will not be unduly or unfairly prejudiced; 
    and (6) the Court is convinced justice will be served by such a result after 
    carefully considering the record as well as the interests and concerns of 
    the both the defendant and the victim of the crime).

title: Pack v. Associated Marine Institutes
description: The court affirms the trial court's grant of summary judgment, agreeing the individual employees of RMI did not act in a grossly negligent manner, neither AMI nor RMI acted with deliberate indifference causing the death of Tracy Pack, and none of the theories advanced to justify a federal civil rights claim have merit.
text:
Pack v. Associated Marine


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Rose M. Pack and Joseph B. Pack, III as Co-Personal Representatives of 
        the Estate of Tracy B. Pack, deceased, Appellants,
v.
Associated Marine Institutes, Inc.; Rimini Marine Institute, Inc.; The 
        South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice; Tyrone Smalls; Barney
Gadson; 
        Rodney Morrow; Thaddeus Chestnut; and John Zeigler, Defendants,
of whom Associated Marine Institutes, Inc.; Rimini Marine Institute, 
        Inc.; Tyrone Smalls; Barney Gadson; Rodney Morrow; Thaddeus Chestnut; 
        and John Zeigler are the, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

 

Opinion No. 3907
Heard September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William H. Johnson, of Manning, for Appellants.
Thomas C. Salane, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J:Â  Rose M. Pack and Joseph 
  B. Pack, III, as co-personal representatives of the Estate of Tracy B. Pack 
  (the Estate), appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order granting partial summary judgment 
  to Associated Marine Institutes, Inc. (AMI), Rimini Marine Institute, Inc. (RMI), 
  and four Rimini employees.Â  We affirm.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In August 1999, juveniles Jon Smart and 
  Stephen Hutto were in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Juvenile 
  Justice (DJJ).Â  They boarded at RMI, a residential rehabilitation facility for 
  juveniles in the custody of DJJ. [1] 
Prior to Smartâ€™s placement at RMI, DJJ screened 
  him under its eligibility guidelines, classified him as a non-violent offender, 
  and determined he was fit for placement at RMI although Smartâ€™s DJJ record indicated 
  he had a history of substance abuse that included becoming intoxicated from 
  inhaling paint and gasoline fumes, a practice commonly called â€œhuffing.â€Â  Barney 
  Gadson, RMIâ€™s Director of Operations, testified he had reviewed Smartâ€™s DJJ 
  records, and was aware that Smart had a problem with becoming violent after 
  huffing.Â  Gadson and Smartâ€™s team leader, Robert McCray, tested Smart to determine 
  if his purported huffing addiction was true by making gasoline accessible to 
  him. Â After Smart attempted to steal the gas, he received counseling and RMI 
  employees took precautions to restrict his access to fuel kept on campus.Â  On 
  August 11, 1999, Smart huffed gas he stole from a generator while on work furlough.Â  
  When his counselor, Thaddeus Chestnut, confronted him about the odor of gasoline 
  on his person, Smart denied huffing and claimed he smelled of gas from working 
  on the generator.Â  
The following day, Tracy Pack obtained permission 
  from RMI to have Smart and Hutto leave the RMI campus to work at his chicken 
  houses.Â  Pack was a former employee of RMI who allowed juveniles from the Rimini 
  facility to work off-campus with him at his familyâ€™s nearby poultry farm and 
  boat landing. Â Once there, Smart became intoxicated by huffing gasoline 
  he had secretly funneled from Packâ€™s truck.Â  Smart subsequently bludgeoned Pack 
  to death.Â  Smart and Hutto then stole Packâ€™s truck and went on a crime spree 
  before police apprehended them.Â  
The Estate brought survival and wrongful 
  death actions against AMI and RMI, arguing AMI failed to properly monitor RMI.Â  
  It further alleged that RMI was negligent in its supervision of Smart and Hutto, 
  and should have discovered and warned Pack of the boysâ€™ violent propensities.Â  

AMI and RMI made a motion for partial summary 
  judgment, arguing they were entitled to statutory limitations on liability under 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-56-180 (Supp. 2003), because both corporations qualified 
  as charitable organizations.Â  The circuit court agreed, and partially granted 
  their motions.Â  
The Estate then filed a complaint in United 
  States District Court alleging DJJ, AMI, and RMI violated Tracy Packâ€™s civil 
  rights pursuant to 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  It also amended its complaints in state 
  court, adding nine RMI employees and DJJ as defendants.Â  
The parties later agreed to voluntarily 
  dismiss the federal action without prejudice.Â  Consequently, the Estate reasserted 
  its federal civil rights claims against all defendants in state court.Â  Following 
  discovery, the Estate voluntarily dismissed all claims against four of the employees. 
  [2] Â  The circuit court also granted DJJâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  
  The remaining defendants, including AMI, RMI and four RMI employees, each filed 
  motions for summary judgment on all causes of action.Â  
The circuit court denied summary judgment 
  to AMI and RMI on the Estateâ€™s wrongful death and survival claims.Â  However, 
  it granted summary judgment in favor of individual RMI employees on both negligence 
  claims, finding they were entitled to qualified immunity pursuant to S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 33-56-180.Â  The court also granted all defendants summary judgment on 
  the Estateâ€™s federal civil rights cause of action, finding â€œthat even if an 
  unconstitutional â€˜custom or practiceâ€™ can be shown by the [Estate] in this case, 
  the â€˜deliberate indifferenceâ€™ standard cannot be met.â€Â  To support its conclusion, 
  the court relied on White v. Chambliss, 112 F.3d 731, 737 (4th Cir. 1997), 
  which held â€œ[a] claim of deliberate indifference, unlike one of negligence, 
  implies at a minimum that the defendants were plainly placed on notice of a 
  danger and chose to ignore the danger notwithstanding the notice.â€Â  
The Estate filed a motion to amend the judgment, 
  requesting the trial court rule on its claim that application of the â€œstate 
  created dangerâ€ doctrine supported a finding RMI violated 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  
  The circuit court denied the motion, finding the evidence failed to prove RMI 
  created the danger that led to Tracy Packâ€™s death.Â  It also stated â€œ[e]ven if 
  the Court determined that Tracy Pack has a substantive due process right to 
  be protected by the defendants, the absence of deliberate indifference prevents 
  Â§ 1983 from being an available remedy.â€ Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When we review an order granting summary judgment, the court of appeals
applies the same standard that governs the circuit courts pursuant to Rule 56,
SCRCP.  Summary judgment is proper
when there are no genuine issues of material fact and the moving party is
entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Lanham
v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 361-62, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333
(2002).  In making our determination whether any triable issues of
fact exist, we will view the evidence and all reasonable inferences from it in
the light most favorable to the non-moving party. 
Id. 


DISCUSSION 


I.      
Claims Against Individual RMI Employees
  The Estate contends the circuit court erred 
  by granting summary judgment in favor of individual RMI employees on its wrongful 
  death and survival claims, arguing evidence in the record created numerous genuine 
  issues of material fact whether four of the employees acted in a grossly negligent 
  manner.Â  We disagree.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-56-180(A) (Supp. 2003) 
  states, in relevant part: 

An action against the charitable organization pursuant to this 
  section constitutes a complete bar to any recovery by the claimant, by reason 
  of the same subject matter, against the employee of the charitable organization 
  whose act or omission gave rise to the claim unless it is alleged and proved 
  in the action that the employee acted in a reckless, wilful, or grossly negligent 
  manner[.]

Here, the circuit courtâ€™s unappealed finding 
  that AMI and RMI qualified as charitable organizations is the law of the case.Â  
  In re:Â  Morrison, 321 S.C. 370, 371, 468 S.E.2d 651, 653 (1996) (stating 
  an unappealed ruling is the law of the case).Â  Moreover, the Estate does not 
  allege on appeal that RMI employees were either reckless or willful.Â  Thus, 
  pursuant to section 33-56-180(A), the Estate is statutorily barred from recovering 
  against an individual RMI employee on its wrongful death and survival claims 
  unless it can show the employee acted in a grossly negligent manner. 
Section 33-56-180 does not define what it 
  means to act in a grossly negligent manner.Â  However, our supreme court has 
  defined gross negligence in the context of liability by a government entity 
  to mean 

the intentional conscious failure to do something which it is 
  incumbent upon one to do or the doing of a thing intentionally that one ought 
  not to do.Â  It is the failure to exercise slight care.Â  Gross negligence has 
  also been defined as a relative term, and means the absence of care that is 
  necessary under the circumstances.

Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 
  341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003) (internal citations omitted). 
  [3] Â  â€œAdditionally, while gross negligence ordinarily is a mixed question 
  of law and fact when the evidence supports but one reasonable inference, the 
  question becomes a matter of law for the court.â€Â  Etheredge v. Richland Sch. 
  Dist. One, 341 S.C. 307, 310, 534 S.E.2d 275, 277 (2000).Â  
The Estate makes numerous allegations of 
  gross negligence against individual RMI employees arguing evidence contained 
  in the record creates genuine issues of material fact sufficient to overcome 
  summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
The trial court granted summary judgment 
  after determining RMI employees acted with at least slight care in carrying 
  out their duties.Â  On appeal, the Estateâ€™s argument is essentially that the 
  employees were grossly negligent because they failed to do more to address Smartâ€™s 
  behavior problems or prevent Smart and Hutto from participating in off-campus 
  work furloughs on Packâ€™s farm.Â  The fact that more might have been done does 
  not negate a finding that RMI employees exercised at least slight care.Â  See 
  Etheredge, 341 S.C. at 311-12, 534 S.E.2d at 277-78 (holding that where 
  defendant had no knowledge of animosity between students, and principal and 
  security monitored hallways, the fact that school district might have done more 
  did not negate the fact it exercised slight care for purposes of determining 
  whether gross negligence exception to Tort Claims Act was applicable).
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the Estate, we agree with the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that individual RMI 
  employees exercised at least slight care in their supervision and control of 
  Smart and Hutto.Â  As such, we conclude there are no genuine issues of material 
  fact that would prevent the award of summary judgment.Â 


  II.Â Â Â Â Â  Federal Civil Rights Claims Against AMI and RMI 
The Estate contends that AMI and RMI displayed 
  deliberate indifference for Packâ€™s safety, and thus the circuit court erred 
  in granting summary judgment on its 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 claims.Â  We disagree.
An unappealled ruling of the circuit court 
  determined that AMI and RMI qualify as state actors.Â  Therefore, both corporations 
  may be liable for violating Tracy Packâ€™s civil rights if the Estate can show 
  each had knowledge of an unconstitutional custom or practice, and failed, as 
  a matter of specific intent or deliberate indifference, to correct or stop it.Â  
  See Spell v. McDaniel, 824 F.2d 1380, 1391 (4th Cir 1987) (holding 
  a municipality is at fault for allowing a widespread unconstitutional practice 
  or custom to continue if (1) responsible policymakers have actual or constructive 
  knowledge of its existence, and (2) it fails thereafter, as a matter of specific 
  intent or deliberate indifference, to correct or stop the practice).Â  
To support its Â§ 1983 claims against the 
  corporations, the Estate reasserts essentially the same allegations it relied 
  on as evidence of individual employeesâ€™ gross negligence. [4] Â  We note that even had the Estate proven individual 
  RMI employees acted in a grossly negligent manner, they cannot predicate their 
  1983 claim on the employeesâ€™ behavior alone.Â  See Monell v. Depâ€™t 
  of Soc. Servs., 436 U.S. 658, 692-94 (1978) (holding a state actor cannot 
  be held liable under Section 1983 on a respondeat superior theory).Â  Unless 
  the Estate can show AMI and RMI acted with deliberate indifference in monitoring 
  Smart and permitting the work furloughs to continue and the practices made Packâ€™s 
  murder â€œalmost bound to happen,â€ its constitutional claim fails as a matter 
  of law.Â  See Spell, 824 F.2d at 1390 (holding a plaintiff must 
  prove the failure to correct or stop the offending practice must make the specific 
  violation â€œalmost bound to happen, sooner or laterâ€ rather than merely â€œlikely 
  to happen in the long runâ€ to sustain a section 1983 claim); see also 
  Jensen v. Conrad, 570 F.Supp. 114, 122 (D.S.C. 1983) (â€œIn defining the 
  concept of deliberate indifference, it is important to recognize that although 
  it is closely associated with gross negligence, there is a significant distinction. 
  In essence, gross negligence is the breach of reasonable standards of conduct 
  posing obvious dangers to others while deliberate indifference involves a knowing 
  lack of regard or concern for the safety of others.â€) (internal citation omitted).Â  

RMI accepted Smart only after DJJ screened 
  him under its eligibility guidelines, classified him as a non-violent offender, 
  and determined he was fit for placement.Â  RMIâ€™s staff monitored Smartâ€™s huffing 
  addiction and took appropriate steps to counsel him and restrict his access 
  to gasoline on campus.Â  Prior to the murder, Smart and Hutto had participated 
  in work furloughs without incident and had regularly worked with Tracy Pack 
  at the poultry farm.Â  Although he later admitted to stealing gas and huffing 
  while at the farm and boat landing, Smart acknowledged he did so secretly and 
  lied to his counselors when questioned about the odor of gas on his person.Â  
  On the day of his murder, Tracy Pack himself specifically requested Smart and 
  Hutto for work furlough on his farm.Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most 
  favorable to the Estate, we cannot say AMI and RMI knowingly disregarded Tracy 
  Packâ€™s safety or that their decision to continue the practice of work furloughs 
  made Packâ€™s murder almost bound to happen.Â  Absent a showing of such deliberate 
  indifference, the Estateâ€™s section 1983 claims fail.
The Estate also raises section 1983 claims 
  against RMI based on an alleged failure to train employees to follow an internal 
  guideline governing the supervision of juveniles.Â  Assuming the Estateâ€™s allegations 
  of a failure to train are true, it still must show AMI and RMI acted with deliberate 
  indifference to survive section 1983 scrutiny.Â  Since we have determined the 
  Estate failed to make such a showing, we find this argument unpersuasive.Â  
Finally, the Estate contends a theory of 
  liability referred to as the â€œstate created dangerâ€ doctrine supports 1983 liability 
  arguing AMI and RMI created the danger that led to Packâ€™s death by not taking 
  affirmative action to end off-campus work furloughs.Â  The Estate urges us to 
  adopt a four-part test created by the United States Court of Appeals for the 
  Third Circuit, which is used to prove a due process violation under the doctrine.Â  
  See Kneipp v. Tedder, 95 F.3d 1199 (3d Cir. 1996) (establishing 
  a four-part test for proving a section 1983 claim under the â€œstate created dangerâ€ 
  doctrine).Â  We decline to do so.Â  
Our state supreme court has not adopted 
  the four-part Kneipp test nor, insofar as we can tell, has it ever recognized 
  or even discussed the â€œstate created dangerâ€ doctrine in relation to a section 
  1983 action.Â  We prefer, instead, to be guided by the analysis employed by the 
  Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals in a case similar to Kneipp and to the 
  one at bar.Â  In addressing the issue of whether a plaintiff may claim liability 
  under 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 based on an affirmative duty theory, the court, in Pinder 
  v. Johnson, 54 F.3d 1169, 1174 (4th Cir. 1995) recognized:

the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment does not require 
  governmental actors to affirmatively protect life, liberty, or property against 
  intrusion by private third parties.Â  Instead, the Due Process Clause works only 
  as a negative prohibition on state action.Â  â€˜Its purpose was to protect the 
  people from the State, not to ensure that the State protected them from each 
  other.â€™

To support its conclusion, the court quoted 
  DeShaney v. Winnebago County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 489 U.S. 189, 196-97 
  (1989), wherein the Supreme Court of the United States held:

[i]f the Due Process Clause does not require the State to provide 
  its citizens with particular protective services, it follows that the State 
  cannot be held liable under the Clause for injuries that could have been averted 
  had it chosen to provide them.Â  As a general matter, then, we conclude that 
  a Stateâ€™s failure to protect an individual against private violence simply does 
  not constitute a violation of the Due Process Clause.


  The affirmative duty of protection rejected by the United States Supreme Court 
  in DeShaney and the Fourth Circuit in Pinder is precisely the 
  duty the Estate relies on in this case.Â  The Estate argues RMI and AMI could 
  have, and thus should have, acted to prevent Smart and Huttoâ€™s crimes.Â  However, 
  DeShaney makes clear that no affirmative duty exists in these circumstances. 

CONCLUSION
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the 
  Estate, we find RMI employees exercised at least slight care in the performance 
  of their duties and are entitled to qualified immunity from liability pursuant 
  to S.C. Code Ann. section 33-56-180 (Supp. 2003).Â  Because the Estate failed 
  to prove AMI and RMI acted with deliberate indifference in maintaining the practice 
  of off-campus work furloughs, training their employees, and addressing Smartâ€™s 
  huffing addiction, its federal civil rights claims predicated on those allegations 
  must fail.Â  Finally, we conclude AMI and RMIâ€™s alleged failure to protect Pack 
  against the violent acts of Smart and Hutto does not constitute a violation 
  of the Due Process Clause.Â  Therefore the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment 
  is
AFFIRMED. 
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    RMI operates the facility pursuant to a contract between its parent, AMI, 
    and DJJ.Â  RMI was responsible for the day-to-day operation of the facility.Â  
    AMI is a charitable corporation organized under the laws of Florida specializing 
    in the operation of residential and day programs for troubled youth.Â  

 
   [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    A fifth employee, Thaddeus Chestnut, was named as a defendant and was served 
    by publication.Â  We find no evidence in the record that Chestnut filed an 
    answer or motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order granting summary 
    judgment to â€œRMI Employeesâ€ does not refer to any specific individual.Â  Therefore, 
    Chestnutâ€™s status in this case is unclear to this court.

 
   [3] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    The Estate argues each sentence of the Jinks standard is an independent 
    definition of gross negligence.Â  It also asserts this courtâ€™s definition of 
    gross negligence as â€œa conscious failure to exercise due careâ€ in Jackson 
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrs., 301 S.C. 125, 390 S.E.2d 467 (Ct. App. 1989) 
    constitutes a fourth meaning to permit a finding of gross negligence even 
    when there is evidence a defendant exercised slight care.Â  We disagree and 
    read the definition in Jinks as a single, comprehensive standard for 
    proving gross negligence requiring a determination whether a defendant exercised 
    at least slight care.Â  

 
   [4]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â  The contention is (1) the practice of permitting off-campus work furloughs 
    without adequate supervision, (2) failure to train and instruct employees 
    on the internal policy requiring supervision, and (3) failing to respond to 
    knowledge of Smartâ€™s huffing addiction and his behavioral history, all directly 
    resulted in the unconstitutional deprivation of Tracy Packâ€™s right to life. 
    Â

title: Elliott v. SCDOT
description: The court determines a pay raise already in effect when an admittedly compensable accident occurred is, in this case, an exceptional reason for deviating from the normal method of calculating the average weekly wage.
text:
Elliott v. SCDOT


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Katherine Elliott, Appellant,
v.
S.C. Department of Transportation and State Accident Fund,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3908
Heard September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Malcolm M. Crosland, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant. 
Samuel Thompson Brunson, of Florence, for Respondents.Â  
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Katherine Elliott appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming 
  the workersâ€™ compensation commissionâ€™s decision to calculate her average weekly 
  wage without including her earned salary increase.Â  We reverse and remand. [1] 
FACTS
Elliott was employed by the South Carolina Department of Transportation as 
  a Trade Specialist II, earning an annual salary of $19,253.Â  After she obtained 
  her commercial driverâ€™s license, she earned a five percent salary increase that 
  was effective September 17, 2000.Â  On September 28, 2000, Elliott was injured 
  in a work-related activity.Â  
Elliott filed for workersâ€™ compensation benefits, arguing her five percent 
  pay increase constituted an â€œexceptional reasonâ€ for departing from the standard 
  method used to calculate the compensation rate.Â  The standard calculation is 
  based upon a claimantâ€™s fifty-two weeks of earnings immediately preceding the 
  date of injury. Â The single commissioner utilized the standard method to establish 
  Elliottâ€™s rate of compensation, excluding her wage increase.Â  The majority of 
  the full commission affirmed.Â  However, in a dissenting opinion, one of the 
  commissioners concluded Elliottâ€™s salary increase was extraordinary, and fairness 
  required its inclusion in calculating her average weekly wage to more appropriately 
  reflect her future earning capacity.Â  The circuit court affirmed the decision 
  of the majority of the full commission.Â  
DISCUSSION
Elliott contends the circuit court erred as a matter of law 
  by affirming the decision of the full commission, arguing her five percent salary 
  increase qualifies as an â€œexceptional reasonâ€ to recalculate her average weekly 
  wage to most nearly approximate the amount she would have been earning but for 
  her injury.Â  We agree.
The Administrative Procedures Act governs our review of the decisions of the 
  South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 
  276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  We will not weigh the evidence 
  or substitute our judgment for that of the full commission on questions of fact. 
  Â However, we may reverse or modify the commissionâ€™s decision when a claimantâ€™s 
  substantial rights are prejudiced because of an error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).
Although the parties agreed to stipulated facts before the full commission, 
  there is nothing in the record to suggest they stipulated whether Elliottâ€™s 
  pay increase qualified as an â€œexceptional reasonâ€ to depart from the standard 
  wage calculation employed by the single commissioner.Â  We also recognize the 
  full commission acting as fact-finder found Elliottâ€™s average weekly wage did 
  not include her pay increase.Â  However, their finding is not dispositive.Â  The 
  determination of whether Elliottâ€™s raise constitutes an â€œexceptional reasonâ€ 
  for purposes of applying the standard wage calculation method provided by the 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is a question of law.Â  
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-40 (Supp. 2003) provides in relevant part:

â€œAverage weekly wagesâ€ 
  means the earnings of the injured employee in the employment in which he was 
  working at the time of the injury during the period of fifty-two weeks immediately 
  preceding the date of injury, . . . 
When for exceptional 
  reasons the foregoing would be unfair, either to the employer or employee, such 
  other method of computing average weekly wages may be resorted to as will most 
  nearly approximate the amount which the injured employee would be earning were 
  it not for the injury. 

The Workerâ€™s Compensation Act is remedial legislation enacted to protect the 
  worker.Â  Therefore, the statute is given a broad construction in order to accomplish 
  that end.Â  Booth v. Midland Trane Heating & Air Conditioning, 289 
  S.C. 251, 254, 379 S.E.2d 730, 731 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œThe statute provides an 
  elasticity or flexibility with a view toward always achieving the ultimate objective 
  of reflecting fairly a claimantâ€™s probable future earning loss.â€Â  Sellers 
  v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 191, 564 S.E.2d 694, 698 (Ct. 
  App. 2002).Â  Moreover, it is well established that the objective of wage calculation 
  is to arrive at a fair approximation of the claimantâ€™s probable future earning 
  capacity.Â  Disability reaches into the future, not the past; loss as a result 
  of the injury must be thought of in terms of its impact on probable future earnings.Â  
  Bennett v. Gary Smith Builders, 271 S.C. 94, 98-99, 245 S.E.2d 129, 131 
  (1978).
Elliott earned her pay increase by voluntarily pursuing special 
  certification and licensing.Â  The additional pay was a merit-based reward given 
  in recognition of her efforts to obtain a commercial driverâ€™s license, and was 
  not merely a standard cost-of-living increase or step increase based on longevity 
  of service.Â  In addition, the raise was not speculative, but was an established, 
  guaranteed amount already in place at the time of the accident.Â  While the increase 
  in pay is small, the amount of the raise is not the factor that determines whether 
  it is an exceptional reason for recalculating the average weekly wage.Â  The 
  inclusion of the increase in salary will, in the words of the statute, â€œmost 
  nearly approximate the amount which the injured employee would be earning were 
  it not for the injury.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-40 (Supp. 2003).Â  
We therefore conclude Elliottâ€™s earned pay increase qualifies 
  as an â€œexceptional reasonâ€ to recalculate her average weekly wage.Â  Accordingly, 
  we reverse the decision of the circuit court and remand this case to the full 
  commission with directions to recalculate Elliottâ€™s average weekly wage including 
  the five percent pay raise.
REVERSED and REMANDED. Â 
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: City of Florence v. Jordan
description: In this appeal, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s finding that an individual charged with DUI was not adequately informed in writing of his implied consent rights before submitting to a breath analysis test.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
City of Florence, Appellant,
v.
George Washington Jordan, III, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3909
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Kimberly Veronica Barr, of Florence, for Appellant.
David Michael Ballenger, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this appeal, we must decide whether an individual 
  charged with DUI was adequately informed in writing of his implied consent rights 
  before submitting to a breath analysis test.Â  The municipal court found the 
  accused was not sufficiently informed and excluded the test results because 
  the law enforcement officer purportedly failed to properly execute a preprinted 
  rights advisement form.Â  The circuit court affirmed this ruling.Â  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
George Washington Jordan, III, was arrested by Florence 
  City Police in June 1999 for driving under the influence.Â  Jordan was taken 
  to police headquarters where he was offered a breath test. A law enforcement 
  officer presented Jordan with a preprinted â€œAdvisement of Implied Consent Rightsâ€ 
  form issued by SLED.Â  This form sets forth three separate advisements: a â€œDUI 
  Advisement,â€ a â€œFelony DUI Advisement,â€ and a â€œZero Tolerance Advisement.â€ The 
  law enforcement officer executing the form must check the box next to the appropriate 
  advisement.Â  In this case, the officer checked the box for the standard â€œDUI 
  Advisement.â€Â  This advisement reads, in its entirety:

Subject Advised/Informed in Writing: You are under arrest 
  for Driving Under the Influence, Section 56-5-2930, South Carolina Code of Laws 
  1976, as amended.Â  The arresting officer has directed that [breath, blood, 
  urine (CIRCLE ONE)] samples be taken for alcohol and/or drug testing.Â  The 
  samples will be taken and tested according to Section 56-5-2950 and South Carolina 
  Law Enforcement Division procedures.Â  You do not have to take the tests or give 
  the samples.Â  If you are 21 years old or older and you refuse to submit to the 
  tests or give the samples, your privilege to drive in South Carolina must be 
  suspended or denied for at least ninety days and your refusal may be used against 
  you in court.Â  If you are 21 years old or older and take the tests or give the 
  samples and have an alcohol concentration of fifteen one-hundredths of one percent 
  or more, your privilege to drive in South Carolina must be suspended for at 
  least thirty days.Â  Pursuant to Section 56-1-286, if you are under 21 years 
  old and refuse to submit to the tests or give the samples, your privilege to 
  drive in South Carolina must be suspended or denied for at least six months 
  for breath/blood refusals [ninety days for urine refusals] and your refusal 
  may be used against you in court.Â  Pursuant to Section 56-1-286, if you are 
  under 21 years old and take the tests or give the samples and have an alcohol 
  concentration of two one-hundredths of one percent or more, your privilege to 
  drive in South Carolina must be suspended for at least three months.Â  You have 
  the right to have a qualified person of your own choosing conduct additional 
  independent tests at your expense and the officer must provide you affirmative 
  assistance upon request.Â  You have the right to request an administrative hearing 
  within ten days of the issuance of the notice of suspension.Â  You must enroll 
  in an Alcohol and Drug Safety Action Program within ten days of the issuance 
  of the notice of suspension.

(emphasis in original).Â  The officer advising Jordan of his implied consent 
  rights failed to indicate on the advisement form the type of test to be administered 
  by circling or otherwise designating whether a â€œbreath,â€ â€œblood,â€ or â€œurineâ€ 
  sample would be requested from Jordan.Â  Jordan was given a copy of the advisement 
  form, and he consented to a breath test.Â  Evidence from the suppression hearing 
  revealed that Jordan was informed a breath test would be offered.
In pre-trial proceedings, 
  Jordan moved to exclude the results of the test, arguing the officerâ€™s failure 
  to circle the word â€œbreathâ€ resulted in an incomplete advisement under South 
  Carolina Code section 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2003), which requires the accused be 
  advised in writing of his implied consent rights prior to the administration 
  of a breath test.Â  The trial judge agreed and granted the motion to suppress.Â  
  On appeal, the circuit court affirmed.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit or exclude evidence is within his discretion 
  and will not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion occurs. Elledge 
  v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 
  792 (2002).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the judgeâ€™s decision is controlled 
  by an error of law or is without evidentiary support. State v. Wilson, 
  345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The City of Florence argues the failure to circle the word 
  â€œbreathâ€ on the SLED form did not constitute an incomplete advisement of Jordanâ€™s 
  implied consent rights under South Carolina Code section 56-5-2950.Â  We agree.
Section 56-5-2950 mandates that all persons arrested for DUI must be advised 
  of their implied consent rights in writing before any breath test or other type 
  of test is conducted.Â  The statute explicitly sets forth the essential content 
  of the advisement as follows:

No tests may be administered or samples obtained unless 
  the person has been informed in writing that:
(1) he does not have to take the test or give the samples, 
  but that his privilege to drive must be suspended or denied for at least ninety 
  days if he refuses to submit to the tests and that his refusal may be used against 
  him in court;
(2) his privilege to drive must be suspended for at least 
  thirty days if he takes the tests or gives the samples and has an alcohol concentration 
  of fifteen one-hundredths of one percent or more;
(3) he has the right to have a qualified person of his own 
  choosing conduct additional independent tests at his expense;
(4) he has the right to request an administrative hearing 
  within thirty days of the issuance of the notice of suspension; and
(5) if he does not request an administrative hearing or 
  if his suspension is upheld at the administrative hearing, he must enroll in 
  an Alcohol and Drug Safety Action Program.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a).Â  The statute further provides SLED â€œmust administer 
  the provisions of this subsection and must make regulations necessary to carry 
  out its provisions.â€Â  Id.Â  
In determining whether Jordan was adequately advised in writing of his implied 
  consent rights under section 56-5-2950, we are guided by the express legislative 
  intent as discerned from the plain language of the statute. See State 
  v. Scott, 351 S.C. 584, 588, 571 S.E.2d 700, 702 (2002); State v. Morgan, 
  352 S.C. 359, 365-66, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  Reading section 
  56-5-2950, it is beyond dispute that each of the implied consent rights enumerated 
  in the statute was explicitly addressed in the SLED advisement form presented 
  to Jordan.Â  Nowhere among the rights listed in section 56-5-2950 does it provide 
  the accused a right to be explicitly advised in writing what specific type of 
  test is being requestedâ€”be it blood, breath, urine, or any other test.Â  Nor, 
  under the language of the statute, does the accused have to be advised in writing 
  that only one particular test is being requested to the express exclusion of 
  any other test.Â  Indeed, the implied consent rights provided under section 56-5-2950(a) 
  inform the accused that he may refuse any test and refuse to give any 
  samples.Â  
The supposed violation 
  in the present case, therefore, is not connected to the implied consent rights 
  set forth in section 56-5-2950(a) as contended by Jordan.Â  The violation, if 
  indeed one exists, stems solely from a failure to comply with SLED procedures.Â  
  The question remaining before us, therefore, is whether or under what circumstances 
  DUI test results should be found inadmissible due to a failure by law enforcement 
  to adhere to any of the various technical or procedural requirements prescribed 
  by the statute or promulgated by SLED through its statutory authority.
The leading case 
  on this point is State v. Huntley, 349 S.C. 1, 562 S.E.2d 472 (2002).Â  
  In Huntley, a defendant charged with DUI sought to suppress his breath 
  test results on the grounds the breathalyzer operator did not strictly comply 
  with the statutory guidelines governing the administration of breath tests.Â  
  Specifically, the defendant claimed the operator used a 0.10 simulator test 
  solution rather than the prescribed 0.08 solution.Â  Id. at 4, 562 S.E.2d 
  at 473.Â  In ruling that suppression of the test results was not warranted, the 
  supreme court focused on whether the failure to comply with the statute affected 
  the reliability of the evidence.Â  The court explicitly found the operatorâ€™s 
  error did not impact the accuracy and reliability of the resultsâ€”concluding 
  â€œ[t]here is no question the breathalyzer machine was operating properly and 
  its results were reliable.â€ Id. at 6, 562 S.E.2d at 474. 
Shortly after the Huntley decision, the Legislature amended section 
  56-5-2950 to provide additional guidance to our trial courts on when to exclude 
  test results due to the failure to comply with the statuteâ€™s mandates or SLED 
  regulations.Â  Subsection (e) was added to the statute in 2003, which provides: 


The failure to follow any of these policies, procedures, 
  and regulations [promulgated by SLED], or the provisions of this section, shall 
  result in the exclusion from evidence any tests results, if the trial judge 
  or hearing officer finds that such failure materially affected the accuracy 
  or reliability of the tests results or the fairness of the testing 
  procedure. [1] 

Â§ 56-5-2950(e) (emphasis added).Â  
As does Huntley, subsection (e) makes clear that the decision to admit 
  or exclude test results under section 56-5-2950 should not turn solely on whether 
  the prescribed procedures were followed with the most exacting compliance. Instead, 
  the question should be whether the violation thwarted the clear policy objectives 
  underlying the statuteâ€”that is, to ensure suspects are informed of their rights 
  to refuse any test and, if consent is obtained, to ensure the tests are conducted 
  in an accurate, reliable, and fair manner.Â  
In this case, neglecting to circle the word â€œbreathâ€ on 
  the SLED form has no bearing on the accuracy or reliability of the breath test 
  results, and Jordan does not contend otherwise; nor does the failure in any 
  way impact upon the fairness of the testing procedure.Â  The purpose of the SLED 
  form is not to serve as the exclusive source of information regarding the arrest 
  and testing procedures provided to a person accused or suspected of driving 
  under the influence.Â  Rather, it is designed to serve the limitedâ€”but critically 
  importantâ€”function of advising the accused in writing of his right to refuse 
  any test and inform him of the possible consequences arising from his decision 
  to refuse or proceed with any test.Â  The failure to satisfy the specific technical 
  requirement at issue in this caseâ€”a requirement that is beyond the scope of 
  the statutory mandate of section 56-5-2950(a)â€”cannot, therefore, render the 
  advisement in the present case incomplete. 
In reaching this conclusion, 
  we do not intend to excuse the law enforcement officerâ€™s failure to execute 
  the Implied Consent Rights Advisement form with the care and attention the seriousness 
  of the occasion demanded.Â  Nor do we intend to diminish the critical role of 
  SLED in prescribing the necessary procedures to ensure the rights of all criminal 
  suspects are protected and the will of the Legislature is followed.Â  Our decision 
  today is limited to determining whether Jordan was adequately informed in writing 
  of his implied consent rights under section 56-5-2950.Â  On that narrow question 
  we must answer in the affirmative.
CONCLUSION
Because the failure to 
  circle the word â€œbreathâ€ on the SLED form did not render the implied consent 
  rights advisement incomplete or violate the implied consent statute, we find 
  the trial court improperly suppressed evidence of Jordanâ€™s breath test results.Â  
  Accordingly, the judgment of the circuit court is reversed, and the matter is 
  remanded to the Florence Municipal Court for trial.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.

 
  [1] Â Subsection (e) was added to section 56-5-2950 
    by the 2003 amendment to the statute. See Act No. 61, 2003 S.C. Acts 
    689. Though this amendment occurred after the trial of this case, subsection 
    (e) is remedial in nature and, as such, is applied retroactively. See 
    South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue v. Rosemary Coin Machs., Inc., 339 
    S.C. 25, 28, 528 S.E.2d 416, 418 (2000) (noting that â€œstatutes that are remedial 
    or procedural in nature are generally held to operate retrospectivelyâ€).Â
