title: State v. Guillebeaux
description: Guillebeaux appeals from his convictions for distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine near a school.  He argues the trial judge erred in failing to grant his new trial motion where there was evidence that a juror knew one of the State's chief witnesses.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Alvis Alphonso Guillebeaux, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3910
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor William Townes Jones, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.: Â Alvis Alphonso Guillebeaux appeals his convictions for 
  distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine near a school, 
  arguing the trial judge should have granted his motion for a new trial because 
  a juror concealed a social relationship with a witness.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In a controlled buy organized by the Abbeville County Sheriffâ€™s 
  Office, confidential informant Brent Smith purchased crack cocaine from an unknown 
  black male later identified as Guillebeaux.Â  Guillebeaux was indicted on charges 
  of distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine near a school 
  or playground. 
Smith was the Stateâ€™s chief witness at trial.Â  During jury 
  selection, the judge identified Guillebeaux and other potential witnesses, including 
  Smith. The judge asked the panel members whether they had â€œany type of personal, 
  business or social relationship either with the defendant, Mr. Guillebeaux or 
  any of the potential witnesses.â€Â  None of the members of the jury panel responded.Â  
  The panel was also asked, among other things, if any of them â€œfor whatever reason 
  could not give both the state and the defendant a fair and impartial trial.â€Â  
  No one responded.Â  Both Guillebeaux and the State exhausted their peremptory 
  strikes, and Juror Catherine Gray (â€œJurorâ€) was seated without challenge.Â  Guillebeaux 
  was convicted as charged and sentenced to a total term of twenty-two years imprisonment.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

After Guillebeauxâ€™s trial, Jessie Johnson, Jurorâ€™s brother, 
  approached Guillebeauxâ€™s counsel claiming Juror had a social relationship with 
  Smith.Â  At a post-trial hearing, Johnson testified that he and Smith used to 
  smoke crack together.Â  Johnson stated that Jurorâ€™s father and Smithâ€™s father 
  were friends, Juror went to high school with Smith, Juror knew Smith from frequenting 
  Smithâ€™s familyâ€™s filling station, and Juror would speak to Smith when she came 
  to visit Johnson.Â  
Juror testified at the hearing that she knew who Smith was 
  but had not had any conversations with him beyond saying â€œhiâ€ in passing on 
  the street.Â  She denied attending high school with him but acknowledged that 
  she went to high school with Smithâ€™s brother.Â  She stated she was aware of what 
  kind of car Smith drove because he worked at his brotherâ€™s filling station, 
  which is across the street from her hairdresser.Â  
Guillebeaux moved for a new trial based on Jurorâ€™s failure 
  to disclose the alleged social relationship.Â  Guillebeaux argued Jurorâ€™s failure 
  to inform them that she knew Smith prevented Guillebeaux from determining whether 
  he would exercise a peremptory strike against her.Â  The trial judge found Juror 
  had not misled the court and the motion was denied.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Guillebeaux argues the trial judge abused his discretion 
  in denying the motion for a new trial because Jurorâ€™s failure to disclose the 
  social relationship with Smith precluded Guillebeaux from exercising his peremptory 
  strikes against her. [1] Â  We disagree.
The denial of a motion for a new trial will be disturbed on appeal only upon 
  a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Covington, 343 S.C. 157, 
  163, 539 S.E.2d 67, 69 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œWhere a new trial motion is based 
  upon allegations that a juror gave misleading and incomplete answers on voir 
  dire, the trial courtâ€™s denial of that motion will be affirmed absent a prejudicial 
  abuse of discretion.â€Â  Id. at 163, 539 S.E.2d at 69-70; State v. Kelly, 
  331 S.C. 132, 145, 502 S.E.2d 99, 106 (1998). 
When allegations arise concerning a jurorâ€™s failure to reveal 
  information in response to voir dire questions, courts look to whether the concealment 
  was intentional and consider the nature of the information concealed.Â  State 
  v. Woods, 345 S.C. 583, 587-88, 550 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001).Â  A new trial 
  is warranted if the court finds: (1) the juror intentionally concealed the information; 
  and (2) â€œthe concealed information would have supported a challenge for cause 
  or would have been a material factor in the use of the partyâ€™s peremptory challenges.â€Â  
  Id.Â  However, a determination that a juror did not intentionally conceal 
  the information ends the courtâ€™s inquiry.Â  State v. Sparkman, 358 S.C. 
  491, 497, 596 S.E.2d 375, 377-78 (2004).Â  
Determining whether a jurorâ€™s failure to respond to a voir 
  dire question amounts to intentional concealment is a â€œfact intensive determination 
  that must be made on a case-by-case basis.â€Â  Sparkman, 358 S.C. at 496, 
  596 S.E.2d at 377.Â  Intentional concealment occurs â€œwhen the question presented 
  to the jury on voir dire is reasonably comprehensible to the average juror and 
  the subject of the inquiry is of such significance that the jurorâ€™s failure 
  to respond is unreasonable.â€Â  Id.Â  Concealment is considered unintentional 
  where the voir dire question posed is ambiguous or incomprehensible to the average 
  juror or where â€œthe subject of the inquiry is insignificant or so far removed 
  in time that the jurorâ€™s failure to respond is reasonable under the circumstances.â€Â  
  Id.Â  Although it may be inferred that a juror is not impartial if she 
  fails to disclose a relationship without justification, such an inference may 
  not be drawn where there is information to the contrary or the failure to disclose 
  is innocent.Â  State v. Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 448, 567 S.E.2d 244, 247 
  (2002). 
This court has recently addressed the failure of a juror 
  to reveal a relationship with a witness.Â  State v. Galbreath, 359 S.C. 
  398, 597 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In Galbreath, potential jurors 
  were asked during voir dire if they were close personal friends or business 
  associates with any of the witnesses.Â  A seated juror did not respond to this 
  question, despite information that the juror knew the victimâ€™s mother and that 
  the jurorâ€™s brother-in-law rented land from someone in the victimâ€™s extended 
  family.Â  This court found no intentional concealment where the juror accurately 
  answered the specific question posed and the alleged relationships did not amount 
  to close personal friends or business associates.Â  Galbreath, 359 S.C. 
  at 403-04, 597 S.E.2d at 847-48; see Sparkman, 358 S.C. at 498-97, 
  596 S.E.2d at 376-77 (finding no intentional concealment where the judge asked 
  on voir dire whether anyone had been the victim of a â€œserious crimeâ€ and seated 
  juror did not immediately recall that he had been a crime victim forty years 
  earlier and was not sure if the crime amounted to a â€œseriousâ€ one).
Although the trial judge asked a more general question regarding 
  relationships in the present case, we find Juror did not intentionally conceal 
  information.Â  Juror was not asked during voir dire if she knew any of the witnesses, 
  she was asked if she had any type of social relationship with Smith.Â  Jurorâ€™s 
  knowledge of who Smith was and the rare exchange of greetings with him in her 
  community did not constitute a â€œsocial relationship.â€Â  Juror answered the questions 
  posed to her during voir dire honestly, her failure to reveal her knowledge 
  of Smith was a reasonable response to the question posed, and her failure to 
  respond did not amount to intentional concealment.Â  Further, Juror indicated 
  during voir dire that she knew of no reason she could not be impartial to both 
  the defense and the State and there is no evidence to the contrary.Â  As we find 
  no intentional concealment on Jurorâ€™s part, we need not further determine whether 
  the information would have been a material factor in the exercise of Guillebeauxâ€™s 
  peremptory strikes.Â  Sparkman, 358 S.C. at 497, 596 S.E.2d at 377-78.Â  
  Based on this evidence, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion 
  in denying the motion for a new trial.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Because the Juror did not intentionally conceal information 
  in response to voir dire questions, the trial judge did not abuse his discretion 
  in denying Guillebeauxâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  Accordingly, his convictions 
  are 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  As the State points out, Guillebeauxâ€™s issue on 
    appeal refers to a motion for mistrial instead of a motion for a new trial.Â  
    A motion for a mistrial is substantively different from a motion for a new 
    trial.Â  State v. Johnson, 248 S.C. 153, 160, 149 S.E.2d 348, 351 (1966) 
    (â€œIt thus appears that a mistrial and a new trial are not the same thing in 
    name or effect.â€).Â  However, the substance of the appellate argument focuses 
    on the failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial in this situation.Â  
    Because Guillebeauxâ€™s motion for a new trial was properly preserved at the 
    trial level and the substance of his appellate argument focuses on the trial 
    judgeâ€™s failure to grant a new trial, we will treat the references to â€œmistrialâ€ 
    in his appellate brief as a scrivenerâ€™s error and address his appeal with 
    reference to a new trial.Â

title: Stoddard v. Riddle
description: In this appeal, the court reviews a determination by the family court that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction to modify an alimony agreement between former spouses.
text:
Stoddard v. Riddle, 12618


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Daniel Miles Stoddard, Appellant,
v.
Selena Joanna Riddle, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3911Â Â Â 
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 20, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Laura Anne Filler, of Chesnee, for Appellant.
Oscar W. Bannister, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Daniel Stoddard (Husband) appeals a family court order 
  determining it did not have subject matter jurisdiction to modify a property 
  settlement agreement between him and his former wife, Selena Riddle (Wife).Â  
  We affirm. [1]   
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Following an eight-year marriage, Husband and Wife were divorced 
  in 1980.Â  The divorce decree incorporated a property settlement agreement, which, 
  by the agreementâ€™s own terms, was not merged into the courtâ€™s final order.Â  
  In regard to alimony, the agreement stated the following:

Husband shall pay directly to the Wife the sum of Two Hundred 
  Twenty-Five and no/100 ($225.00) Dollars per month . . . the payment of such 
  amounts herein provided shall not in any manner be modified by the Court, and 
  shall not terminate until her death or remarriage.Â Â Â  

Since 1983, Wife has cohabitated with another man.Â  The two 
  openly hold themselves out to the public as an amorous couple.Â  Throughout their 
  relationship, they have owned joint property and held joint mortgages.Â  The 
  two often travel and dine out together, and their luxurious home was the subject 
  of a life and style article in the Greenville News.Â  They have never, however, 
  participated in a marriage ceremony, and it is undisputed that the couple is 
  not married under common law.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In 2002, Husband brought an action seeking the termination 
  of his alimony obligation to Wife on the ground that Wifeâ€™s cohabitating relationship 
  is tantamount to marriage.Â  The family court determined it did not have subject 
  matter jurisdiction to modify the settlement agreement.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEWÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In appeals from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts 
  in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Woodall 
  v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  Questions concerning 
  alimony, however, rest within the sound discretion of the family court judge, 
  whose conclusions will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  
  Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App. 2001); 
  Bannen v.Bannen, 286 S.C. 24, 26, 331 S.E.2d 379, 380 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  
  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by some error 
  of law or is based on findings of fact that are without evidentiary support.Â  
  Bryson, 347 S.C. at 224, 553 S.E.2d at 495; McKnight v. McKnight, 
  283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred in determining it lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction to interpret his alimony obligations under the property settlement 
  agreement.Â  We disagree.
Prior to 1983, it was the law of this state that the family court lacked jurisdiction 
  to interpret, enforce, or modify a separation agreement â€œincorporated but not 
  mergedâ€ into a divorce decree.Â  Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 352, 
  306 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1983); Bryant v. Varat, 278 S.C. 77, 77, 292 S.E.2d 
  298, 299 (1982); Kelly v. Edwards, 276 S.C. 368, 370, 278 S.E.2d 773, 
  774 (1981).Â  In 1983, hoping to lessen the legal import of â€œwords of artâ€ such 
  as â€œratified,â€ â€œapproved,â€ â€œincorporated,â€ and â€œmerged,â€ the supreme court decided 
  Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 306 S.E.2d 624 (1983).Â  In Moseley, 
  the court held jurisdiction for all domestic matters, whether by decree or by 
  agreement, vested in the family court.Â  Id. at 353, 306 S.E.2d at 627.Â  
  Following Moseley, all settlement agreements, once approved, were modifiable 
  by the court and enforceable by contempt, unless the agreement unambiguously 
  denied the family court jurisdiction.Â  Id.
The holding of Moseley, however, was expressly limited to those divorce 
  decrees entered after the decision.Â  Id.Â  When faced with a pre-Moseley 
  separation agreement that is â€œincorporated but not mergedâ€ into the divorce 
  decree, the family courtâ€™s jurisdiction remains restricted to its pre-Moseley 
  boundaries, and the agreement is enforceable only by resort to ordinary contract 
  remedies.Â  See Peterson v. Peterson, 333 S.C. 538, 541-543, 510 
  S.E.2d 426, 427-428 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Because the settlement agreement at issue 
  in this case was entered into prior to Moseley and â€œincorporated but 
  not mergedâ€ into the divorce decree, the family court properly found it lacked 
  jurisdiction. [2] 
Furthermore, the agreement in the case at bar states, â€œthe payment of such 
  amounts herein provided shall not in any manner be modified by the court.â€Â  
  Although recent case law and statutory amendments alter the family courtâ€™s analysis 
  of cohabitation as a ground for alimony termination when modification is allowed, 
  [3]  the parties may still agree to deny the family court the authority 
  to modify alimony.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(G) (Supp. 2003) (â€œThe 
  parties may agree in writing if properly approved by the court to make the payment 
  of alimony as set forth [in this statute] nonmodifiable and not subject to subsequent 
  modification by the court.â€); Moseley, 279 S.C. at 353, 306 S.E.2d at 
  627 (â€œThe parties may specifically agree that the amount of alimony may not 
  ever be modified by the court . . . .â€).Â  In the recent case of Degenhart 
  v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 602 S.E.2d 96 (Ct. App. 2004), this court determined 
  that language strikingly similar to that employed in this settlement agreement 
  denied the family court the authority to modify alimony in any manner.Â  The 
  family court, therefore, would lack jurisdiction to modify alimony payments 
  here even if the agreement was entered into following the Moseley decision.
For the foregoing reasons, 
  the family courtâ€™s order isÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED.Â Â  
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  Husband argues that, even if the family court 
    lacks jurisdiction to modify or enforce a pre-Moseley 
    agreement, it may still interpret the agreement.Â  We find no merit 
    in this semantic distinction.Â  Pre-Moseley, the family court lacked 
    jurisdiction to enforce, modify or interpret settlement agreements 
    like the one at issue.Â  See Kelly v. Edwards, 276 S.C. 368, 
    370, 278 S.E.2d 773, 774 (1981) (â€œ[O]nly the interpretation of the 
    [settlement agreement] was in issue, therefore, the family court was without 
    subject matter jurisdiction to determine contractual obligations.â€(emphasis 
    added)).Â  

 
   [3] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-150 (Supp. 2003); 
    Bryson, 347 S.C. at 224-25, 553 S.E.2d at 494 (Ct. App. 2001).

title: State v. Brown
description: Appellant appeals his conviction for distribution of cocaine. He argues the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury the defense of entrapment.
text:
SCREENING MEMORANDUM


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Charles Brown, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3912
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
James Arthur Brown, Jr., of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Senior Assistant 
  Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Randolph 
  Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Charles Brown appeals his conviction for distribution of 
  cocaine.Â  He argues the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury the 
  defense of entrapment.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTS
On March 13, 2002, SLED Agent William Kimble met with a paid confidential informant, 
  Harold David Anderson, to conduct a controlled purchase of cocaine from Charles 
  Brown in Beaufort.Â  Anderson was subject to pending criminal charges 
  in Georgia and had aspirations of attending the Georgia Police Academy.Â  The 
  operation was initiated by SLED as a result of a discussion with the Georgia 
  Bureau of Investigations, the organization for which Anderson primarily worked.Â  
  Although several officers with the narcotics division of the Beaufort County 
  Sheriffâ€™s Department assisted in the operation, they had no prior knowledge 
  of any alleged drug dealing by Brown.Â  At the time of the incident, Anderson 
  and Brown had casually known each other for about a year.Â  Anderson spoke with 
  Brown several times by telephone during the day of the controlled buy to arrange 
  the deal.Â Â  
As a result of the telephone conversations, Kimble and Anderson drove together 
  to Brownâ€™s place of employment.Â  Brown met with them inside but did not conduct 
  the requested transaction.Â  Instead, he asked Anderson and Kimble to wait forty 
  minutes to an hour so that he could retrieve the drugs.Â  Brown called after 
  that time and the group agreed to meet at Burger King.Â  Because Brown refused 
  to deal directly with Kimble, Kimble gave Anderson $200 in marked cash to complete 
  the transaction.Â Â  When Anderson got into the car with Brown, he gave Brown 
  the money in exchange for 3.16 grams of cocaine.Â  Subsequently, Brown was arrested 
  and indicted for distribution of cocaine.Â  
At trial, Brownâ€™s counsel moved for a directed verdict and requested a charge 
  of entrapment after the close of the evidence.Â  Counsel argued that law enforcement 
  in Beaufort County was not familiar with Brown until the Georgia Bureau of Investigations 
  prompted the drug operation.Â  Counsel further asserted the State failed to present 
  evidence that Brown was a drug dealer.Â  The judge denied the motion and the 
  request to charge.Â  Because Brown failed to testify or present evidence to support 
  the affirmative defense of entrapment, the judge found Brown was not entitled 
  to the requested charge. [1] Â  
  The judge further ruled there was no evidence in the record to support the 
  defense.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The jury convicted Brown of distribution 
  of cocaine.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to nine years imprisonment.Â  Brown 
  appeals.
DISCUSSION
Brown asserts the trial judge erred in declining to instruct 
  the jury regarding the defense of entrapment.Â  He contends the evidence supporting 
  his entrapment defense was presented through cross-examination of the Stateâ€™s 
  witnesses and based on the Stateâ€™s evidence.Â  We agree.
Generally, the trial judge is required to charge only the current 
  and correct law of South Carolina.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 
  261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 302 (2002).Â  â€œThe law to be charged to the jury is determined 
  by the evidence presented at trial.â€ State v. Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 262, 
  433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993).Â  If there is any evidence to support a jury charge, 
  the trial judge should grant the request.Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 
  604, 632, 545 S.E.2d 805, 819 (2001), cert. denied, 534 U.S. 977 (2001).Â  
  To warrant reversal, a trial judgeâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge 
  must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State v. Hughey, 
  339 S.C. 439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000), cert. denied, 531 U.S. 
  946 (2000).
â€œThe affirmative defense of entrapment is available where there is the â€˜conception 
  and planning of an offense by an officer, and his procurement of its commission 
  by one who would not have perpetrated it except for trickery, persuasion, or 
  fraud of the officer.â€™â€Â  State v. Johnson, 295 S.C. 215, 216, 367 S.E.2d 
  700, 701 (1988) (quoting State v. Jacobs, 238 S.C. 234, 244, 119 S.E.2d 
  735, 740 (1961)).Â  â€œIt is a well settled principle of law that the defense of 
  entrapment is not available to a defendant exhibiting a predisposition to commit 
  a crime independent of governmental inducement and influence.â€ Johnson, 
  295 S.C. at 217, 367 S.E.2d at 701.Â  Thus, the entrapment defense consists of 
  two elements:Â  (1) government inducement, and (2) lack of predisposition.Â  Matthews 
  v. United States, 485 U.S. 58, 63 (1988).Â  The United States Supreme Court 
  explained the rationale underlying the defense of entrapment as follows:

When the criminal design originates, not with the accused, but is conceived 
  in the mind of the government officers, and the accused is by persuasion, deceitful 
  representation, or inducement lured into the commission of a criminal act, the 
  government is estopped by sound public policy from prosecution therefor. 

Sorrells v. United States, 287 U.S. 435, 445 (1932).
â€œOne pleading entrapment has the burden of showing that he was induced, tricked 
  or incited to commit a crime, which he would not otherwise have committed.â€Â  
  Johnson, 295 S.C. at 217, 367 S.E.2d at 701; Babb v. State, 240 
  S.C. 235, 237, 125 S.E.2d 467, 467 (1962), cert. denied, 375 U.S. 979 
  (1964) (â€œEntrapment is an affirmative defense to the crime charged and imposes 
  upon the accused the burden of showing that he was induced to commit the act 
  for which he is being prosecuted.â€).Â  â€œ[T]he defendant has the initial burden 
  to produce more than a scintilla of evidence that the government induced him 
  to commit the charged offense, before the burden shifts to the government to 
  prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant was predisposed to commit 
  the crime.â€Â  United States v. Sligh, 142 F.3d 761, 762 (4th Cir. 1998) 
  (citations omitted).Â  â€œA defendant is not entitled to an entrapment instruction 
  unless he can meet this initial burden of producing some evidence of government 
  inducement.â€Â  Id. at 762-63.Â  Thus, â€œ[t]he court may find as a matter 
  of law that no entrapment existed, when there is no evidence in the record that, 
  if believed by the jury, would show that the governmentâ€™s conduct created a 
  substantial risk that the offense would be committed by a person other than 
  one ready and willing to commit it.â€Â  United States v. Osborne, 935 F.2d 
  32, 38 (4th Cir. 1991).
As a threshold 
  matter, Brownâ€™s decision not to testify or call witnesses did not automatically 
  preclude him from receiving the requested charge on entrapment.Â  The United 
  States Supreme Court has ruled that it is not necessary for a defendant to testify 
  or present any evidence to invoke the defense of entrapment.Â  Sherman v. 
  United States, 356 U.S. 369, 373 (1958).Â  In Sherman, the defense 
  called no witnesses.Â  The Court concluded from the evidence that entrapment 
  was established as a matter of law.Â  In so holding, the Court stated that it 
  was â€œnot choosing between conflicting witnesses, nor judging credibility . . 
  . We reach our conclusion from the undisputed testimony of the prosecutionâ€™s 
  witnesses.â€ Id. (emphasis added). Therefore, the trial judge erred, 
  as a matter of law, when he denied the charge on the ground Brown did not testify, 
  call witnesses, or present any evidence other than through the prosecution witnesses.
The question then 
  becomes whether there was sufficient evidence to support the affirmative defense 
  of entrapment.Â  In analyzing this issue, we must consider Brownâ€™s version of 
  the facts as true.Â  See United States v. Trejo, 136 F.3d 826, 
  827 (D.C. Cir. 1998) (â€œIn determining whether an entrapment defense is warranted, 
  the court considers appellantâ€™s version of the facts to be true.â€).Â  Because 
  the question of entrapment is generally one for the jury, an appellate court 
  reviews the trial courtâ€™s decision not to give an entrapment instruction de 
  novo.Â  United States v. Singh, 54 F.3d 1182, 1189 (4th Cir. 1995) 
  (â€œThe district courtâ€™s decision not to give an entrapment instruction is a question 
  of law which we review de novo.â€).
In terms of inducement, 
  there was evidence to suggest that law enforcement instigated the drug transaction.Â  
  Anderson, a friend of Brownâ€™s and a paid confidential informant, initiated the 
  meeting by calling Brown several times the day of the transaction.Â  Brown chose 
  only to deal with Anderson and specifically refused to sell to Kimble.Â  Because 
  Anderson was subject to pending criminal charges and had aspirations of attending 
  the Georgia Police Academy, he had the incentive to set up the drug deal.Â  SLED 
  Agent Kimble testified that he intended to give Anderson a favorable recommendation 
  to the Georgia Bureau of Investigations in exchange for his cooperation. 
There is also 
  evidence that indicates Brownâ€™s lack of predisposition to commit the offense 
  of distribution of cocaine.Â  The Stateâ€™s witnesses acknowledged that Brown was 
  a retired Army first sergeant who was honorably discharged.Â  Brown was also 
  gainfully employed and declined to conduct the transaction at his place of business.Â  
  The cocaine was not readily accessible to Brown given Anderson and Kimble had 
  to wait approximately an hour and a half between the time of the request and 
  the actual sale.Â  At the time of his arrest, Brown did not have any other drugs 
  in his possession.Â  Nor did he have a significant amount of cash other than 
  the $200 in marked money.Â  Furthermore, aside from the controlled buy, SLED 
  agents and officers with the Beaufort County Sheriffâ€™s Department had not previously 
  purchased drugs from Brown nor did they have any knowledge that Brown had engaged 
  in drug activity.Â  Moreover, there was no evidence of any prior drug transactions 
  between Anderson and Brown.Â  When Brown gave a statement to investigating officers, 
  he denied being a drug dealer and claimed that he made the sale for a friend.Â  
  Brown also made this same comment to Anderson on the day of the sale.
Based on our review 
  of the record, we find there was evidence to support the presentation of the 
  defense of entrapment to the jury.Â  See Sorrells, 287 U.S. at 
  440-41 (finding trial judge erred in refusing to submit issue of entrapment 
  to the jury in trial for possession and sale of intoxicating liquor where:Â  
  prohibition agent befriended defendant; agent made repeated requests to defendant 
  for liquor; defendant did not have liquor in his immediate possession at the 
  time of the request; there was no evidence that defendant ever possessed or 
  sold liquor prior to the transaction in question; the defendant was gainfully 
  employed; and there was testimony the defendant possessed â€œgood characterâ€); 
  see also Johnson, 295 S.C. at 217, 367 S.E.2d at 701 (â€œThe issue 
  of whether or not the defense of entrapment has been established is ordinarily 
  a question of fact for a jury unless there is undisputed evidence and only one 
  reasonable conclusion can be reached.â€); cf. State v. Cooper, 
  302 S.C. 184, 186, 394 S.E.2d 717, 718 (Ct. App. 1990) (holding, in case involving 
  convictions for criminal conspiracy and distribution of crack cocaine, defendant 
  was not entitled to a jury instruction on entrapment where defendant engaged 
  in the illegal activity â€œbecause of her own preexisting readiness to do so and 
  not because of incessant demands made upon her by the undercover agentâ€ or close 
  personal relationship given defendant was an admitted purchaser and regular 
  user of crack cocaine, participated in the drug buy to share in the purchase, 
  and received a portion of the crack cocaine).Â  Accordingly, the judge erred 
  in declining to charge the law of entrapment.Â  Because entrapment was Brownâ€™s 
  only defense, the prejudice from this error was significant and, thus, warrants 
  a new trial.
CONCLUSION
We find the evidence presented was sufficient to entitle Brown to the requested 
  charge of entrapment.Â  The judgeâ€™s refusal to instruct the jury on this defense 
  constituted error and warrants a new trial.Â  Accordingly, Brownâ€™s conviction 
  is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  The record reflects the judge was initially inclined to give 
    the charge of entrapment until the Solicitor alluded that the predisposition 
    element of the offense of entrapment was satisfied by Brownâ€™s prior drug dealing.Â  
    However, there is no evidence contained in the record indicating that Brown 
    had a drug dealing history.

title: Sides v. Greenville Hospital System
description: Dorothy Sides and her husband, Arthur, brought this action after Dorothy Sides fell at the Greenville Memorial Hospital.  They sued the Greenville Hospital System, as well as the general contractor, Rodgers Builders, Inc., and a subcontractor, F.T. Williams Co., Inc.  Mr. and Mrs. Sides appeal from an order granting summary judgment to both the contractor and the subcontractor.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Dorothy L. Sides and Arthur W. Sides, Appellants,
v.
Greenville Hospital System, Rodgers Builders Inc., and
F.T. Williams 
        Co., Inc., Defendants,
of whom Rodgers Builders Inc. and F.T. Williams Co., Inc. are
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3913
Heard November 16, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Grady Jordan, of Easley, for Appellants.
John P. Riordan and N. Heyward Clarkson, III, both of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Dorothy Sides and her husband, Arthur, brought this action 
  after Dorothy Sides fell at the Greenville Memorial Hospital while visiting 
  her husband.Â  The accident occurred near a construction area in the parking 
  lot.Â  They sued the Greenville Hospital System, as well as the general contractor, 
  Rodgers Builders, Inc., and a subcontractor, F.T. Williams Co., Inc.Â  The trial 
  court granted summary judgment to both the contractor and the subcontractor, 
  and Mr. and Mrs. Sides appeal.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
In late 2000, Greenville Memorial Hospital was undergoing Phase V of a construction 
  project, which included the addition of around 184,000 square feet of construction.Â  
  Rodgers Builders was the general contractor for Phase V.Â  F.T. Williams was 
  a subcontractor for the project and was responsible for site preparation and 
  construction, which consisted of demolition of the existing parking lot and 
  pouring concrete.Â Â Â  
On November 28, 2000, Mrs. Sides visited her husband at Greenville Memorial 
  Hospital.Â  Her daughter, Theresa Allen, accompanied her.Â  They were parked in 
  a hospital parking lot across from the emergency room.Â  Mrs. Sides and Ms. Allen 
  left the hospital after dark at around 7:00 p.m. and walked through an area 
  in the parking lot where concrete had recently been poured, requiring them to 
  follow a designated path.Â  According to Mrs. Sides and Ms. Allen, the path was 
  unlit because the bollard lights [1] 
   in this area were not working.Â  Mrs. Sides fell when she suddenly stepped 
  off a curb that she could not see in the darkness.Â  Ms. Allen also stumbled 
  on the curb, but did not fall.Â Â Â  
After the accident, a person identifying herself as a hospital employee called 
  Ms. Allen to ask how Mrs. Sides was doing and where she had fallen.Â  When Ms. 
  Allen told her the fall had occurred where the lights were out, the employee 
  allegedly stated, â€œYes, weâ€™ve had a problem with those lights.Â  Weâ€™ve been meaning 
  to get them fixed and we havenâ€™t been able to get them fixed yet.â€Â Â Â  
Frederick Scott McMillan, a hospital employee who was the Project Coordinator 
  for Phase V, testified in his deposition that something appeared to be cracked 
  inside the lower casing of the bollard light near where Mrs. Sides fell.Â  He 
  noted concrete had recently been poured in the same area.Â  Mr. McMillan admitted 
  the Engineering and Security divisions of the hospital were responsible for, 
  and maintained control of, the lighting in the area where Mrs. Sides fell.Â Â Â Â Â  

Mr. and Mrs. Sides filed suit against the hospital, Rodgers Builders, and F.T. 
  Williams.Â  All defendants moved for summary judgment.Â  The trial court denied 
  the hospitalâ€™s motion, but granted summary judgment to both Rodgers Builders 
  and F.T. Williams.Â  The court subsequently denied a motion to reconsider by 
  Mr. and Mrs. Sides, and this appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn appellate court reviews a grant of summary judgment under the same standard 
  applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP.â€Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross 
  & Blue Shield of S.C., Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 
  (2002).Â  â€œSummary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue of material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.Â  
  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all 
  inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light 
  most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Id. at 361-62, 563 S.E.2d at 
  333.Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, an appellate court 
  will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence 
  in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.; see also 
  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mr. and Mrs. Sides argue the trial court erred in ruling on the motions for 
  summary judgment because Rodgers Builders and F.T. Williams presented no evidence 
  in support of their motions.Â  They further argue the trial court erred in granting 
  summary judgment to both Rodgers Builders and F.T. Williams.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Evidence to Support a Motion for Summary Judgment
Mr. and Mrs. Sides submit that, because Rodgers Builders and F.T. Williams 
  did not offer evidence in support of their respective motions for summary judgment, 
  the trial court should not have granted the motions.Â  They further argue the 
  trial court erred in relying upon only the evidence they themselves submitted.Â Â Â  

Rule 56 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides that a party 
  may move, with or without supporting affidavits, for summary judgment in his 
  favor as to all or part of a claim.Â  Rule 56(a), SCRCP.Â  The trial court shall 
  grant the motion â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, 
  and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there 
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled 
  to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Id. Rule 56(c).
â€œUnder Rule 56(c), the party seeking summary judgment has the initial responsibility 
  of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.â€Â  Baughman 
  v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  
  â€œWith respect to an issue upon which the nonmoving party bears the burden of 
  proof, this initial responsibility â€˜may be discharged by â€œshowingâ€--that is, 
  pointing out to the [trial] court--that there is an absence of evidence to support 
  the nonmoving partyâ€™s case.â€™â€Â  Id. (alteration in original) (quoting 
  Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 325 (1986)).Â  â€œThe moving party 
  need not â€˜support its motion with affidavits or other similar materials negating 
  the opponentâ€™s claim.â€™â€Â  Id.Â  (quoting Celotex, 477 U.S. at 323); 
  see also Richardson v. State-Record Co., 330 S.C. 562, 499 S.E.2d 
  822 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Once the moving party carries its initial burden, the 
  opposing party must come forward with specific facts that show there is a genuine 
  issue of fact remaining for trial.Â  Baughman, 306 S.C. at 115, 410 S.E.2d 
  at 545. 
Both Rodgers Builders and F.T. Williams brought to the attention of the trial 
  court the absence of evidence to support their opponentsâ€™ case.Â  The burden 
  then shifted to Mr. and Mrs. Sides to prove that a genuine issue of material 
  fact did indeed exist.Â  The trial courtâ€™s consideration of evidence presented 
  by Mr. and Mrs. Sides was appropriate and provides no grounds for reversal as 
  the trial court must consider all of the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the non-moving party in ruling on a motion for summary judgment.Â  Although 
  Mr. and Mrs. Sides were not required to make a submission, the trial court need 
  not have excluded that evidence in determining whether any triable issues of 
  fact existed.
II.Â  Rodgers Builders
Mr. and Mrs. Sides contend sufficient evidence was presented to survive summary 
  judgment regarding the potential liability of Rodgers Builders for the accident 
  under the premises liability theory that a contractor owes an invitee the same 
  duties as a landowner owes an invitee.Â  They further argue summary judgment 
  as to Rodgers Builders was improper because the trial court did not grant summary 
  judgment to the hospital.Â  
A property owner owes an invitee or business visitor the duty of exercising 
  reasonable or ordinary care for his safety and is liable for injuries resulting 
  from any breach of such duty.Â  Larimore v. Carolina Power & Light, 
  340 S.C. 438, 531 S.E.2d 535 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The property owner has a duty 
  to warn an invitee only of latent or hidden dangers of which the property owner 
  has or should have knowledge.Â  Id. at 445, 531 S.E.2d at 538.Â  A property
